author: Mrcl K
comment:
You should do more actual research on Bitcoin and the difference between Bitcoin and all other crypto coins.. because it is obvious that you didn't. You create a nice to view documentary, but are obviously not an expert on the subject. That is what bitcoiners mean when they say 'you don't understand' and 'ngmi'.

At the beginning you just repeat all the heavily debunked arguments against Bitcoin like transaction throughput, energy usage and ponzi scheme bullshit.
Even if all the arguments against Bitcoin would be factually true, Bitcoin is still literally a live saver for lots of people in the world that live under heavy inflation and/or corrupt governments with Turkey, Nigeria and Argentina as current examples.

NFT's, Web3 and all other things that spouted from Bitcoin are just distracting from what Bitcoin is actually trying to achieve which is taking control of money out of the hands of governments and banks and give it back to the people.
Bitcoin is MONEY and a counter against fiat currency that keeps being debased by their issue-ers, but it has to go through different fases (respectively store of value, means of exchange and unit of account) before it actually reaches the unit of account fase. Every new technology went through different adoption fases and where heavily criticized before they reached their full potential. For example the car, the internet, tv, phones, even electricity was useless because we had horses, letters and candles so why do we need those diabolical new technologies?

author: captain awesome 2023
comment: the funniest thing about NFTs is that you don't actually own the art, you just own a link to a piece of art on the blockchain. People are so keen to get rich quick, or so ignorant about what the thing is they are buying, they don't even bother to find out or do any homework. There is a fantastic use case for Bitcoin and crypto that continues to this day. Criminals and scammers can use it to extract value from people in the course of conducting their crimes. Scammers ask for payments to bitcoin wallets, and so do extortionists, exactly because of its anonymous and decentralised nature. Crypto currency is the best mechanism for money laundering ever invented. They have moved heavily into gaming now, with insane amounts of money to develop games that are tied in some way to blockchain. These games end up being nothing but hype, do not meet even minimum users, and the original developers run away with millions in their pocket. Each time this happened, many consumers gets burned, and the reputation gets damaged. That's why they have to keep rebranding, but at some point, everyone in the world is going to get wise and associate 'blockchain' with fraud, criminality, and scams.

A lot of people are buying crypto NOT to get rich quick. But as a tool to maintain their value against fiat currency and inflation. That’s why after 12 years it’s still holding value. My $25,000 bank savings account took 6 months to earn thirteen cents. When I went to transfer funds the bank charged me $5 transfer fee. . They convinced me to move that money from chequing to savings to earn interest and it ended up costing me money . I felt duked. It’s a small amount but the principle of it that pissed me off. 

 The banking system is corrupt. My mutual fund took 10 years to make $4000 in what today is only $200 shy of one mortgage payment for me. Investment funds are not keeping up with inflation. Why is gold worth so much? There is no cap on gold because we can keep mining it. Yet it’s the faith of the people that give it value that is the same principle for Bitcoin but the difference Bitcoin is capped!
. You can’t move gold or store it in your wallet yet people still buy in. Gold goes up and down in value daily and at the end of the day the year a decade it is still WAY behind inflation. 
Wall Street caused the 2008 crash because it’s a big ponzi  scheme too. Why would anybody trust Wall Street again? Huge chunks of your money end up going into fees for service and returns are often just keeping up with true inflation. 

People are looking for a way to store their money that will keep up with the true cost of inflation not what the feds report as we know those numbers are bullshit. 

This is a decentralized currency that can not be manipulated by feds the banks or governments . This was a great tutorial but you are missing a lot of true facts. I would not bother with any other crypto other than Bitcoin it’s the gold of crypto. but like the gold standard the oldest commodity in the world that the dollar is no longer backed by since 1971. How is till holding value? Because the people say it has value. 
With double digit trillions of US deficits why is the US one of the richest countries in the world? Because they say the US dollar holds value and has a strong currency because they say so.

author: Kaizen
comment: Bitcoin has nothing to do with NFTs dude. It is backed by energy (proof of work) and is using energy from up to 60% renewable energies (and it will only rise). Do you even know how much energy our current banking system needs? And on top of that, the currency is backed by guns, not with kinetic energy like bitcoin is. Bitcoin is and will always rise in value, because its NOT a scam, it is a true revolution of a ponzi fiat scheme. It is the best idea humans ever had since money exists. Bitcoin isnt about Nfts or scams like you describe. And also: Bitcoin isnt supposed to be scalable, because in that way it can really be a secure network. The scalabality can be solved by layer2 solutions like the lightning network. And no, ethereum isnt revolutionary. Proof of stake (or scam) just leads to the same principles we have now: The people with the most money, can do whatever the hell they want. Really really poor researching.

author: Manuel Cristopher
comment:
I really can't figure all of this out, bitcoin is quite confusing, well the BS is. I was so impatient to carry out necessary research but i really wanted to jump on the crypto trading and investment buzz.
Unfortunately for me, I invested 80,000
GBP worth of bitcoin with a fraudulent company. I was happy to watch my account grow to 280,000 GBP within a couple of weeks. But i didn't realize i was dealing with a scam company, until i tried to make an attempt to withdraw. I made a withdrawal request, and noticed my account was suddenly blocked for no apparent reason. I tried contacting customer support, but all to no avail. I needed my money back at all cost, because i could not afford to let it go. So i tried all possible means to make sure i recovered my scammed bitcoin. I did a lot of online search for help, and tried to see if there were other people who had any similar experience. I stumbled upon a cryptocurrency forum were a couple of people mentioned that they had been through the same process but were able to recover their lost cryptocurrency, funds with the help of FirstMan. So i file a report and he was able to help me get back all my lost funds within two weeks. I will recommend anybody who wants to recover scammed bitcoin, stolen cryptocurrency, funds lost to binary options forex, investment and any other form of online scam, reach out to felixfirstman(At)Gmail.

author: heh
comment:
Just wow.

Guess we can villify the forex market and the stock exchanges too given how much in common crypto has with those. 

Ppl only lose money they were stupid or bought into the idiocy of money with no work. They did not do due diligence to read the ebb and flow of their asset then lost liquidity. This applies to all 3 markets. 

Did the individual that lost money do their due diligence before they made the purchase? Yes or no? How much study did they do? What indicators were used? When did they buy, sell, short? 

Like buying a house in a sense. If you don't know the market, bought at a bad time, etc. No one to blame but yourself. Or should we pretend 2008 didn't happen? Or the housing crash prior to it?

Investing money without doing your research is akin to using it to wipe your ass.

author: GregGore
comment: Hey Hey James (and pals), I have some horrible news for you. But first I must say I enjoyed your video, and agree with most of it. NFTs and all these sh|tcoins are total rubbish and yeah a lot of people lost money playing with them. There are a lot of desperate people out there, look at those videos of those guys hounding Elon Musk asking him to mention some sh|tcoin or other so they can hype it and try make a buck. The whole industry is floored because the sh|t is in there diluting the good. But I have to ask you one thing, if you're so against this crypto industry, what are you going to do when your own government bans cash and issues you essentially "digital credits" direct to your bank? Well I hope you're in a better financial situation than I am because if you're not financially independent of "the system" which is shortly going to be going digital with all these CBDCs that are being treated and developed and planned, them you're going to be trapped with no other option than to use their digital currencies. And as it stands most of the "money" (IE. Currency) in circulation is digital, only a fraction of the total (money) in the system is cash. The rest is numbers put into the system by some bank clerk or trader etc. Creating "profit" by lending non existent money out. Yes crypto might be flawed but CBDCs and the actual FIAT money system is far worse!

author: CHR15B01
comment:
Once when I was in secondary school, one of our teachers was talking to my class about how he used to trade bitcoin (I'm 100% serious.). When he was done explaining how it worked, one of my classmates said something along the lines of, "That sounds like scamming, you're selling someone something that you know isn't worth it so that you can profit.". The teacher then went into full defensive mode, explaining how it was all legal and shit like that.

If even a teenager can recognise that crypto is bullshit, then I don't have much hope for the 'crypto industry'.

author: Leon Gregory
comment:
Granted, there is lots of corruption in crypto, just like any other financial system. 

Bitcoin however is still a revolutionary, decentralised technology/protocol that ultimately serves humanity. 

Being out of bitcoin is now riskier than being in bitcoin. Central banks cannot be trusted and inflation is a very serious issue.

author: Jazil Zaim
comment:
Really good video on the downside of crypto. However there are still a lot of engineers working in this space that is far past this meme hype side of the industry which actually makes crypto look pretty bad. The benefits of blockchain such as proof of ownership is going to come once we have scalable blockchains (Solana and Flow are getting close) and once we have good infrastructure such as what Threshold Network did for Ethereum network for encrypting content. There is a ton of development but a lot of the development is being done behind the scenes and away from the noise. I think more of the serious web3/crypto founders need to bound together to denounce these grifters because a lot of them are obsessing with crypto because they think it is easy money. The grifters are deceiving more people and not contributing much at all.

Overall I do see this as an exciting space to be in. But definitely very technical. The 13 years that you spoke about is something that can be said for AI as well. AI in the 1980s died down for nearly a decade and came back and forth because the use cases were very minor. Then now in 2023, we are in the 4th hype cycle of AI which has been going on since mid-2010s. Really complex tech does take time to develop. Crypto is just one of those. As an engineer in this space, I do have to say that I am with you on the grifters and absolutely despise them and I believe they should be condemned.

author: Sam Kuniholm
comment: This video highlights what is actually the biggest weakness of Bitcoin, and that is its neutrality. Because there is no company or person pushing a narrative about it, it's a free for all of content creators, writers, economists, Redditors, etc. to make up whatever narrative they like. It is a contest between the pro-s and the anti-s to and much like the price of Bitcoin, the market will decide which narrative takes precedence. The only objective truth is the value that it continues to hold. The market will decide.

Any scam exists as long as there's a sufficiently large crowd of uneducated, naive morons willing to fuel this latest multi-level, cyclical, non-stop lottery with real money, without understanding that the lottery itself _doesn't generate_ any money, leaving the naive morons to rely _exclusively_ on more naive morons to come in and hand over their money.

author: Matt
comment: One of the easiest ways to see that crypto has no genuine value outside of optimism when it’s traded to try and profit is to simply look at the multiple token crashes over the prior year or so. Take an FTX as an example. They bailed out a bunch of currencies but the acquisitions were always done with their coin. But one of the clearest demonstrations of how these coins have no genuine value is that the almost instant crash that forced their bankruptcy was largely because their balance sheet and the sister company they didn’t disclose their ties too had their assets almost predominately in the FTT token which immediately freaked everybody out since liquidating it would tank it’s price. And there was immense concern since it allowed manipulation of the prior to prop up the value. That is a demonstration that there really wasn’t a true value to it outside of manipulation and mania. Or other examples of how so many tokens have to hold other non token assets on their books and how quickly they crash when it’s discovered that their assets are largely in various tokens. The tokens have value during good times but as soon as there’s any down turns where there needs to be faith in the value of the tokens to weather a storm they consistently tank as people run the bank time after time. Crypto appeals to people not as a true new currency but as a method to ideally make giant profits quickly but people often won’t come out to say that.

author: Sandwich
comment: Great production quality, but borderline J.P. Morgan propaganda. Timelines are conveniently shifted around to support the narrative, facts omitted and lopsided claims. Lots of valid points that had me cheering followed by confusion as you claim jpgs were the original use case of NFTs and everything else followed. When the verifiable history was that it was the other way around. JPG opportunists co-opted NFTs in 2017, months before ERC-721 was even completed. JPGs were not the ideas that brought the standard to life, it was digital ownership. Whether or not that is feasible is a good discussion. Conflating NFTs and Bitcoin is dishonest. Mentioning greater fools theory, without acknowledging that you are describing the entire global economy and more specifically the inflationary fractional reserve system is disingenuous. You mention the waste of energy as though the only energy with value is made with fossil fuels, without acknowledging the energy of humans whose limited time on this planet is devalued the moment they cash their paycheck. It's a shame really, you had an opportunity to propose an honest critique, instead you just produced an advertisement for the status quo.

author: FreeSpeechIsDead
comment:
I would say the whole banking and finance system is the worlds greatest scam. You only have to look where it originated from and the systems it employs.
Its basically a debt driven system where the only winners are the banks.
Fancy creating a banking system where you pay 'interest'. Its basically a system that is printing money from nothing and then adding interest to create more money from nothing, hence ever increasing debt that will never be paid back. 
Well in todays world they dont need to even print money. Someone in the bank just goes onto the computer, punches in a few numbers and VOILA, you have money that has come from nowhere, you then get a glorified IOU to give banks the availability to then lend out more fake money and for you to pay it back through hard labour and also pay interest on it.
Once the world goes full digital in currency the corruption and fraud will be astronomical and this is what they want.
The stock market in itself is just another ponzi scheme. The big players cash out and the small investors lose everything. There are numerous market crashes every single year where billions just disappear. The whole monetary system is a scam, its not just one form or currency.

This is why no country has wealth as every country and its consumers are in perpetual DEBT.
At the end of the day, many have made a lot of money through crypto and continue to do so. I myself could have doubled my money this year alone depending how much I was willing to put in because at its current rate it has more than doubled to what it was at the start of the year.
And everything you went through on this video, pretty much just explains how the world has become disillusioned with life in general through celebrities and 'influencers' where society has lost all touch with reality and obsessed into a digital future. 
All I gotta say is Im not concerned with crypto, its the very existence of the human race into the next 50yrs where humans will become nothing but cyborgs and controlled by microchips and computers.
Im just curious whether you yourself have crypto, because if you have then this whole video is kinda hypocritical.
Then again, isnt it actually a good thing if someone buys into crypto just to make some money and just allow all these other sheep follow the leader into buying into crypto to only raise your profits and then just pull out while the others behind you that keep buying into it led by all these celebs to raise its value just crash and burn.

author: nemejebatkaj
comment: Bitcoin is the original and very different from “crypto” projects, which are all basically cheap knockoffs. Bitcoin has no central controller, there aren’t misaligned incentives, the people involved have no special rights and there’s no marketing team. Bitcoin is a monetary asset that achieves immutability through a decentralized governance protocol. Such immutability is, in theory, the primary reason behind blockchain technology in the first place. However, besides Bitcoin, what we see across the industry are blockchain-based tokens offering diluted or spurious decentralization, thereby contradicting and defeating the purpose of immutability altogether. Keep learning

author: Tom Azepam
comment: The simplest hint that this was always based on nothing is that as soon as the profit becomes large enough these “investors” sell the Bitcoin for dollars, the FIAT money they all lambasted as centralised, corrupt & untrustworthy. If it’s the future then why sell? Why not wait until it’s taken up by the whole world? Because that was never the plan. At its worst, real world currency, backed by gold reserves (an ACTUAL rare resource), fluctuates by minimal amounts over long timescales. Crypto fluctuations are large & can happen in minutes. None of it ever made sense except to the whales that knew there are always bigger fools to be left holding the bag in this zero sum game. There are no free lunches.

author: promoMax italia
comment:
Well, this is undoubtedly an outstanding piece of work. A lot of research went into it, it shows.

Nevertheless despite all, and I'll give you that, the dramatic soundtrack, the flat-tragic tone of voice, the meticulous details really make it sound like this is the bible of the shrewd, smart guy, it might be that you're missing the point, or you're seeing everything in black or white.

Same happened in late 1990s. The dotcom bubble and the thousands  of dodgy projects that went burst, which turned out to be scam projects.

That bubble gave birth to Google, apple, Amazon, Microsoft and so on.
But hey, I was already around, and sure enough there were James Janis writing about the scam that was going on and how could people even think if investing in such an obvious Ponzi.

The point being, you might be right, or maybe in part. Maybe you have a clear idea of what your message has to sound like but not ready enough to accept the changes the future brings.

I'm sure you carry a mobile phone, and probably use for calls and messages. Watch YouTube vids but also take pictures (not using a Polaroid, are you?).

Technology development happens in layers. Have a look at what the lightning network is.

80% of crypto projects are useless/scam.
20% of the space is innovation.

AI, also will prove desruptive . Any thoughts?

author: Thilo Ilg
comment: Bitcoin, just like all the other currencies used globally, doesn't need another use case besides serving as a currency. Moreover, it's broadly accepted in that capacity. If we follow your line of reasoning, we could also label the dollar as a Ponzi scheme, considering it gains in value when demand increases. Being the most highly decentralized asset in the world, Bitcoin is arguably the safest existing asset. It would be naive to predict that Bitcoin won't be around in the next century, given its resilient network. Conversely, a centralized currency like the dollar is far more susceptible to failure due to centralized control.

So yeah, this doesn't just apply to cryptocurrency or 'NFT's'.

author: James Smith
comment:
I was banned on most crypto exchanges because of the war in Ukraine (I am Russian).
It's funny how with so called free, democratic, unbannable crypto I was banned from using it within the first 10 years, but with heavily controlled, centralized local FIAT currency I never had such issues in my entire life.
Not to mention that bitcoin is not fungible (each unit is not the same as any other unit), you can get "tinted" coins without even knowing it, and as soon as they hit some big exchange or a service they will be seized from you.
Exchenges are centralized and require KYC, yet provide little to no legal guarantees.
Sorry but it's just dumb, I can open a brokerage account in my local bank and get the same thing but with legal protection by the government and the court.
Crypto is only slightly less toxic for people outside of the US than the US dollar itself.

author: Seppl XY
comment: "Ok, let's make it clear that you didn't understand Bitcoin. And with spooky music in the background, you might be fooling people, but you certainly aren't fooling me. If you claim that Bitcoin is a waste of energy, you can certainly say it like that. However, the justification is not provided. You can probably imagine how much energy traditional banking requires. Also, dismissing the entire narrative of NFTs and lumping everything together to create a negative impression of Bitcoin right from the start is quite thoughtless in my opinion. Well, I can recall that one of the greatest economists, Adam Smith, said: wealth should arise from labor. Can't that be digital, do you think? If you consume goods and require energy, and then perform work to obtain new energy in the form of a currency, is that considered energy waste? Okay, you also claim that Bitcoin is a Ponzi scheme. And of course, there's no anti-Bitcoin video without mentioning Bernie Madoff XD. However, the catch is who started it and who continues to participate. Apparently, there is a marketplace that sells something and buyers who accept it. Just a normal trading day for me, where I can choose to participate or abstain. The problem with your assumption is that if Bitcoin resembles a Ponzi scheme, you fail to understand that only Bitcoin provides an economic incentive. As I said, if the whole world is built on labor, why shouldn't our money be too? All other projects are simply not good, and every Bitcoiner knows that. 98% will not be needed in the future. The statement that I need a third party for, let's say, government documents is not entirely correct. Digitization will play a significant role in the future, whether it works with blockchain or not, as the blockchain itself is an inefficient technology for data storage. All in all, one can only say that your reporting raises more questions than it answers, which can be seen as poor reporting. Everything around Bitcoin (Altcoins)  is simply not economically correct, and I can agree with you on that. If you are confident about the things you say, then you must also be willing to listen to other opinions that are supported not only by narratives but also by logical reasoning. Nonetheless, thank you for your video.

author: Derek Djons
comment:
Since a year or ten ago I switched to being self-employed.
That fact alone has multiplied my income. Through the years my hourly / daily wages kept going up and I had the choice, work less or work even more.
Through the years I've become part of a few groups that tightly work together to get projects done. 

To date I'm earning more than needed for a comfortable life. Since I own and manage my own skills, physique, working hours and wage. I'm less vulnerable to circumstantial coincidences and middle-mans.  

Believe in yourself and keep yourself schooled, educated and healthy. 
The government, blockchain, gold... it's all well designed and puts you in front of a mirror.

I can honestly see in my own environment people getting into all this start taking more dangerous decisions and lose focus in the now because they are occupied with what could be in the future.
For me, ten years ago I only had debts, never could predict that through sheer hard work I would be where I am today, financially independent.

author: M S
comment:
Blockchain is incredibly clever & powerful

It might just be the perfect digital virus

Cryptocurrencies are a human creation & digital medium of exchange that sits outside many existing legal frameworks & therefore have quickly become an extension of human psyche & like everything else that is marketable crypto has become a proxy for human behaviour - greed, deception, narrative, marketing, inflated valuations.....

It's just a modern & digital platform that allows people to exchange currency without government intervention or taxation - to a point

It can be argued that the price of gold is overinflated & will become less relevant as advances in asteroid mining & nuclear fusion progress

It can be argued that national borders & countries with governments are the ultimate Ponzi scheme where a ruling class inflicts it's will on the majority of citizens despite not really contributing anything to GDP, health, commerce, agriculture or science.... 

Courts of law & the ability of politicians to create laws is only possible due to armed forces - police & armies & prisons - without weapons & enough people unwittingly playing a small part in keeping communities focused on economic activity & commerce - how would governments collect taxes & enforce punishments for crimes against people & the fictitious nation

It will be incredibly difficult to stop existing & new cryptocurrency coins - especially as the world becomes more digitised - maybe at some point if most humans are replaced by robots & AI there could be an end to the inflated values attached to cryptocurrency - but when this occurs it will likely impact other asset classes on similarly overpriced garbage

Humans have created cryptocurrency & blockchain & humans have attributed value to crypto coins just as humans have drawn lines on pieces of paper & erected fences that signify ownership of parts of Earth as if they will exist forever.....

Where do you draw the line?

Why do people buy soft drink & alcohol?

Why do people gamble?

Why do people still allow themselves to become sunburnt?

Why do people smoke cigarettes?

Why can you buy a petrol car that is capable of exceeding the legal speed limit by 100km+?

Why are there so many successful criminals?

It's all because most humans are animals & flawed & driven by primal urges & instincts that are difficult to master or tame & indeed for the majority of people it seems too difficult to even try & think deeply about modern life, daily choices & acting with morals & respect

Crypto is simply another game which most people lose because they don't really understand it or need it or have much idea about how technology, economics & politics shape modern life.....

Maybe crypto is a scam?

Maybe politics is a scam?

It's not hard to see the appeal of crypto in a corrupt & corporate controlled modern world & crypto is just another part of corrupt & corporate systems despite trying to exist outside of modern government restrictions

Funny how BTC is quoted in USD!!!

USD is backed by weapons & infrastructure & legal & political guilds & games

Crypto is not governed by these systems but to say it exists without interacting with corporations & governments is naive

Crypto does not exist without networked computers running on the internet using government & corporate infrastructure.....

Everything is an illusion to some extent - it all just depends on if individuals have a choice to ignore or are forced to keep participate in games & systems that perpetuate, sustain & contribute to keeping alive the biggest illusions backed by weapons & laws & money.....

Crypto is a scam

Inflation is a scam

Politics is a scam

Consciousness is an illusion that allows infinite stacking of increasingly complex energy systems & illusions.....

author: FreeFlyer
comment:
What a load of rubbish. Blockchain technology simply allows anyone with programming skills to create any financial product they want. In addition to that, owning something on the blockchain is the digital version of owning and transferring a physical object (it requires no 3rd party). Why should these abilities be reserved for a tiny select few?

It's early days and very experimental. Everyone is playing with the tech, nerds getting rich and the world is full of dumbasses. Of course scams are out there and things get crazy and ridiculous. This is how the internet was in the early 90s.

EDIT: Originally Bitcoin was 7 transactions per second, it's now far greater. Will update with any further false info as I go through :P

EDIT2: Christ... "Only make money because someone else lost more". That is not how markets work. Every stock uses the same model. The whole world is run on this model. Buy orders and sell orders in the order book can move the price without any actual executions. But obviously you knew this before releasing the video.

EDIT3: Pretty good coverage of NFT artwork though. The way NFTs are being used is completely bogus really. But the technology isn't "bad", it's just a way to store a certificate on-chain. Think concert tickets. I was buying concert tickets, selling them and making sure I was towards the front in line to get in before the buyer before crypto even existed. The tickets were just PDF files, they can be copied. If tickets were NFTs, that solves that issue without a centralised platform which tickets are sold through today and can only be bought / sold within that platform for that reason.

Whats going on now with NFTs is pure hype and speculation yes. But there are good uses for having a certificate which you own, and can transfer without a 3rd party intermediary. If we ever expect virtual worlds and 3D internet in the future as opposed to flat 2D web pages, this is necessary technology.

author: Danny P
comment:
No no no no no. This is not a scam at all. Its just a clear way of understanding why money in general has value.

Some people believe that money has power, and others believe that belief has power. If you believe something has value, then it will. Money is just the accumulation of everyones beliefs. The more people that believe, the more value it has. The less people believe, the less value it has. This is exactly why some currencies loose there power of value, while others gain.

Cryptocurrency is in a sense, the most perfect set of money ghe world has ever known. Its because, (unlike goverment money) atkeast all the people of the world has full control of it, and there is nothing governments can do about it. 

Your video can be applied to all forms of currency in a sence, but you need to include the accumulated beliefs of individuals to increase the value of a certain currency and make that the foundation of your understanding of it. Then you will have a much mire clearer picture of exactly what currency and vakue if monye really is. That makes all the difference.

Its not a scam at all. Scams are designed to scam, don't do that at all. Its just a system of accumulated value. If its a scam, who looses? Fact is that the only way someone looses is if people stop believing it has value. 

It really is that simple. Its why you need a one hour documentary describing it, its because your logic is theory based, with little foundation. You're creating theories out of thin air, then your linking the theories together without a foundation and calling it circumstantial evidence that proves your right. But you are leaving out the foundation of exactly what money really is. 

Build your theories from the true foundation of what money really is and your picture will be clear. Then you can describe it with a couple of paragraphs of words like i am now.

The simplest explanation tends to be the correct explanation

author: lmotaku
comment: I started when BTC was released, by some random developer with a Japanese name. Not actually known where or who they are. author: TIXE RIGHT
comment: lol, cryptocurrencies brought back commemorative plates, and arcade loonies. People are such rubes, it's amazing we are not all homeless. I do like that these collectible manias create hard to regulate pawn-trade communities though. It's like nomadic tribe trades of pottery, guns, drugs, instruments, jewelry, and art, but for digital nomads, and without dealing with antiquity police who are like Indiana Jones screaming, "THAT BELONGS IN MY MEUSEUM" and third-party appraisals. Like all ketch and camp though, such products are money taken out of the banking system, but are still essentially on your smart phone, which you can take anywhere... SO. there is value in that, if there is value in the product. I think there will eventually be a blockchain product I buy, probably transferable licensing agreements, or property deeds for places and vehicles, and creating digitally acceptable copies of legal records, and such. (Basically, a digital legal file cabinet / safety deposit-box, handling real property, but the technology has not been utilized for civil-law / common-law purposes yet.)  So, I can't scoff the technology despite the earliest iterations and utilizations being weak and very scam-like, but there's things I don't like about it... the energy requirements and intentional increasing difficulty that will eventually bottleneck transaction speeds. I could have made a radical fortune on these technologies, but I just didn't believe in them, I believed the UN would absolutely crush crypto-market over environmental reasons, or sanction-enforcement reasons, and it still might. But at least one nation has made Bitcoin it's official currency, so what we are looking at is a black-swan event with a very uncertain future. And AI is another black-swan event. And if life-extending anti-aging drugs are highly effective, and become widely available, that will be another black-swan event... all in the same century. We are clearly living at the beginning of a new age for humanity, and it's producing some dystopian dark mirror realities.

author: Mach Fiver
comment:
Want to hear lame? I opened a coinbase account and bitcoin wallet back when bitcoin was worth aproximatley $3.25 CAD (2011 era) and thought meh I'll wait till it drops back down to a buck each or so. I even downloaded a miner and set it up on a desktop I wasn't using but never started the mining proccess after the initial setup and test to see if it was working. Yup I could have used my home desktop to mine bitcoin back when that was possible. AND I DIDN'T DO IT OR BUY ANY AT ALL. FML I deserve to be forever poor. What a fuck up.

Anyway today I have become disillusined with what bitcoin has become or maybe I just realized what it actually is. It doesn't make buying online faster or cheaper at all and going from fiat to bitcoin to fiat again just eats away at your money way more than any bank fee or paypal fee could ever do. And that's before you get scammed and robbed or your computer HDD dies along with your wallet and it's keys and all you bitcoin is lost forever or until quantum computers become powerful and accessible to the masses so you can crack your wallet open. I mean how awesome is it that $500 of bitcoin costs you more than %10 to buy? At the bitcoin ATM in my local grocery store it was around 25% of the amount you were buying and to sell back again was even worse. And if you accidentally tap send instead of cancel when you realize the other guy is a scammer youre unable to cancel the transaction or even know who they were. The only true owners of bitcoin that use it to buy htngs are criminals spending their illegal earnings. And now they can buy prepaid visas that allow atm cash withdrawls they don't even need to cash out to a bank thriugh an exchange that uses KYC protocols for users. It is a joke. And the resources to mine a bitcoin just in electricity is beyond profitable unless you are able to set up in Iceland and get cheap power or steal hydro but don;t bother mining if you don;t own a couple hundred ASICs that cost $50k each and expect to have ti buy them all over again once someone invents a better ASIC miner system and your couple mil investment in hardware is obsolete. Just how is mining profitable at all especially with the recent plumet in bitcoins price. It can;t be profitable today but only on the gamble that bitcoin will go back up or surpass it's previous price and hiit a mil percoin one day. I laugh at the price predictors that say by 2030 bitcoin will be at 750k USD I find that very hard to believe. 

And finally just actually what is bitcoin? It's electronic pretend money that has zero tangible backup to an asset like gold. It;s electronic pretend money that someone created and made a funky enticing way for people to be able to create more and also take care of all the accounting and bookkeeping at no cost to themselves. They took a gamble and boy did it pay off and as long as they don;t sell off their holdings in huge chunks but little by little they won;t cause the price to totally tank rendering them just as broke as before. They live like a king and personally I'm in awe of them and thiunk it;s amazing that they accomplished what they did. I wish I had done more to get some way back when but I didnt. I could gamble today but I'd like my odds better buying the occassional lottery ticket and hitting the proggressive slots at my local casino.

author: Goddesses StarTrek Online Fleet
comment: The truth of BitCoin. BitCoin was invented in the late 1990's, it was formed as a company offering a "digital currency for games". BitCoin was a single company but it had invented a software system that could scale by adding new 'nodes' into the network. They also were consious that in assigning a physical value to a digital asset, hacking would happen, so, they made a very specific protection mechanism. Firstly, the more nodes that where added to the network the more complex and larger the crytogaphic calculation; Secondly, they presumed people would try to "brute force" their way to try to falsely generate coins and thus devalue the currency. They put in place two safe guards, firstly, every time new BitCoin transactions are created it changes the cryptographic key and secondly it increases the cryptographic difficulty in brute forcing the key. Thus, at the system operated it was though to be defended against hacking and "as safe as real money" (so they felt). This company gained a mild success, associating itself with popular games of the time. Gamer's used it as a "intermediary" currency, as a mechanism to "safeguard" a transaction. BitCoin the company did well. However, hackers where not to be beaten. Hackers worked out a way to continiously generate new coins using processor intensive mathematics and effectively bankruppted BitCoin. This meant the hackers had reverse engineered its operation. BitCoin went quietly away (as a company) and the creators where lost to time. Roll on the 2000's, presumably one of the hackers who had compromised the original coin network, had a bunch of BitCoins left, which where now valueless without a company to back them. Assumably they where trying to figure a way to make these BitCoins have value again, and invented the myth of Satoshi Nakamoto. Also, as hackers, wanted to promote the idea of a currency which was outside the control of corporations (which also neatly falls into how they got burned when the BitCoin corporation went bankruptt). From there forward, the "hacking" of BitCoin was "mythologised" as "Mining" and said to be "by design"! It was of course not intended for "mining" but they re-skinned the original security feature as an intentional system to "make coins" as this was largely the only way the hackers knew how to generate coins. There's alot more following that, and you pick up that part of the story pretty well.

author: st. lamplight
comment:
What is gold?  Why is it valuable? Ultimately, its value is determined by supply and demand in the market. It doesn't really have any intrinsic value. Its value is determined by supply and demand. The reasons behind the demand are almost entirely superficial (status, symbol of wealth, hard to mine, limited supply). The demand for Bitcoin is similar, but I would say slightly more interesting. It comes from a collective desire to carry out transactions that bypass political controls, banking controls, and to have an inflation-resistant store of value. What does Bitcoin do? Well, what does gold do? It doesn't matter. It comes back to human psychology and supply and demand. Honestly, was a little disappointed with the research in this one. Production was great. But the content was shallow. Didn't go into economic theories, the history of money and value, inflation, trade, government managed money supplies, etc. He had a theory and kept his blinders on and didn't consider the non-hype reasons why people like Bitcoin.

Also how is it a ponzi scheme? How is Bitcoin a ponzi scheme if anyone can buy or sell freely in the market, and there is no central authority or organization that controls or manages its price? Bitcoin does not promise guaranteed returns or payouts to investors using the capital from new investors. Like gold, which doesn't promise guaranteed returns or payouts, people buy bitcoin because it's in demand.

author: FalcoGer
comment:
Well the banks ARE untrustworthy. They're gamblers, only they gamble with your money and if they loose it, it's your loss. And if they win some, they take a cut. And if they loose everything, they get bailed by tax money.
The problem is that crypto is not better nor is it practical. When was the last time you bought a pack of cheese with bitcoin? Or filled your car's tank with gas with bitcoin? It just doesn't work. You can't rent hotels, buy plane tickets, buy bread, or order a book from amazon with bitcoin. And of course your employer will still pay you in your native currency, too. It's completely worthless. And those computer generated ape pictures are even less than worthless. I'd actively avoid being associated with those unsightly things.
But even if it did work, what does bitcoin achieve? A waste of resources is what it does. Terrawatts of power, better spent on weather predictions or scientific simulations are going down the drain. Entire industries get created wasting thousands of manhours. I want a new graphics card and have to pay 3 times the price. And who gets rich? Who owns the most bitcoin? The chineese government, because they can afford to buy up all those graphics cards and stamp out data centers with slave labor to mine bitcoins and power them with coal power plants. Currency of the people my rear end.

author: mehtasid
comment: I don't have a firm view either way, but if crypto is a scam, then expensive paintings, old postage stamps, vintage cars etc. that have much lower utility value than they sell for, should also be a scam.  However we are comfortable that these sell for millions because we grew up with these.   OTOH, if you agree that a rare vintage Ferrari can be worth a million, then so can crypto.  For anything to have value, all it takes is millions of people agreeing it has value.  For example the same house in an expensive neighborhood is double the price because everyone accepts that.  If so, it's the same for crypto.  Once millions accept that it has value, then it does, because there will always be buyers and sellers at that price.   You can argue that one day there might not be buyers.  Well, when the earthquake hit San Francisco in 1989 there were no buyers so the houses suddenly went down in value.   But no one says houses are a scam.   Please feel free to post opposite views if you are logical, polite / civil.   PS.  using celebrities to endorse cosmetics for example happens all the time.

author: Oliver L.
comment: I don't want to burst anyone's bubble but let's just say that bitcoin, or cryptocurrency's inception was likely created by people who are anti-government who clearly doesn't want to pay taxes or give governments knowledge of their business, which clearly shows it's something sketchy. I think it's safe to assume that those who are into cryptocurrency are those who are tech savvy who earn a living mainly through the net where anything goes (whatever criminal activity) and somehow they get away with it. Imagine if cryptocurrency becomes the norm, they can easily steal your money (or rather, coins) by hacking which is very common among tech savvy people. Now, imagine that the tech savvy person in question is a thief, the risk is even much higher. It's like giving a gun to a crazy person, or animal, perhaps a monkey. If they could steal data from you, they could steal anything. And because these transactions aren't reported to the government, you can't get any help when things fall apart. Perhaps the biggest consequence of cryptocurrency is that, when no one pays taxes anymore, then society would eventually deteriorate. Who would pay for hospitals,  roads, general maintenance and basic amenities that generally come from taxes? Yes, it is true that most governments are infested by corruption, but that's not to say they're all bad. And I don't believe that the best approach is to overturn any government because when that happens, crimes rise, and society becomes a total dystopia.

author: Jupiter Eye
comment: Dead wrong on this one. It isn't a solution looking for a problem. It is paramount for any serious country with robust infrastructure to hold control over, hopefully, every aspect of its economy. Blockchain offers that, and more. It offers a tap into statistics on the scale and timeline unparallel. It offers switches for manipulation, which every big country has, only now it would be partially automated. It offers a connection to machine learning and AI, and it offers anything and everything one would hope for, from the aspect of governance. How people use it now is silly, it is like using a bulldozer in playground sand and charging a million dollars for a sand-made castle, it is silly. Blockchain is scary, it can and will track genetic lineages, social status, communication, and transactions. It sucks that this is our future, but in this game of societies, land, and resources, it was always going to get more complex, not less. Crypto is not a scam, it is an ultimate tool used to scam people, but its future will dominate absolutely.

author: coffeegator
comment:
I don't think it's entirely accurate to say that all cryptocurrencies and anything associated with them is evil and a scam. For instance, let's say you lived in a country where the value of your nation's currency dropped tremendously. If you had part of your portfolio hedged with a solid crypto (yeah I'm mentioning it as an investment, but it's my money, and I'll do what I want with it, and bear with me a sec), it would then (here's where the currency payoff part comes in) be worth lots of spendable cash for you if you were able to access it in your country and living situation or were able to cross into another country to access it. It is currency. It's just mainly used as a savings and/or investment account. Investing in forex is very foreign and intimidating to most people, but I'm sure that more people know how to buy bitcoin or know someone who can help them especially when compared to people who invest in stock markets.

I think the crypto trend has awoken many new investors in stock markets now since it definitely introduced new investing concepts to them. If that ends up putting more money into the market eventually then great. I like a more stable economy and hope that I'll never be in a situation where my crypto investments were all that I had left in the world.

author: Fabian
comment:
So the thing is.. this is done really well. It's entertaining. But it's also clearly biased and follows a narrative. 
Or in other words, it's one of those videos which could convince the audience of any given opinion, unrelated to the actual facts.

As someone with a masters degree in computer sciences, i at least understand the majority of what's happening under the hood. 
That doesnt mean i necessarily disagree on a few key points here, so let me quickly clarify that:
* Bitcoin is trash. It was a proof of concept, and a successful one. But it never had a chance to become a global currency and serves no real purpose nowadays.
* The images *are not* NFTs. NFTs are digital certificates of ownership, nothing more and nothing less. The payload, so to speak, is irrelevant. You simply verifiably own that. That's it.
* Crypto does cause a few manias here and there. A lot of people make, and many more lose money on that. However, one should *never* invest based on FOMO alone. 
* Manias and FOMO, or bad investment strategies in general, are not unique to the crypto scene. 
* As with anything else, if money is to be made, people will do what it takes to profit on it. People are bad, and love to profit off of others. That doesnt mean the tech is bad.
* Crypto does however indeed attract a lot of scammers, and many projects are scams. We are at an early stage which is easy to abuse, but that's not the techs fault either.
* "For them to get rich others are left without their investments" - yes thats how markets work. Like all of them. Somebody always buys at a higher price, for someone else to be able to sell.

With that out of the way: blockchain technology such as crypto currencies or NFTs are not scams. The story you deliver has a very strong bias against such technology. That much should be clear from the phrasing alone. You compare Bitcoin transactions to VISA, rightfully concluding that it doesnt stand a chance. I agree. It sucks. Few with half a clue would argue against that. However, what about less prehistoric solutions, which outshadow the performance of VISA nearly as much as VISA outshadows Bitcoin? Nah, that doesnt fit the narrative being pushed here, huh. The same with the power consumption. Yes, we get it, and i agree: Bitcoin sucks. It was a proof of concept, and it did its job. It has no real usecase anymore and wont scale to global usecases. But just like with the transactions.. what about those that can? Proof of work is very energy hungry. People realised that pretty quickly. Proof of stake, one of its successors, is orders of magnitudes less energy hungry, and there is even newer models being tested which reduce energy consumption even further. Compared to the banking system we got now, a final product will likely end up being orders of magnitudes cheaper and better for the planet. But that doesnt fit the narrative either.

Now, i dont really care about crypto currencies specifically. They will eventually replace fiat money, but whether that happens in a decade or a millenia, i neither know nor care. The banking system is worth billions, rather trillions, so even if some crypto currency, hypothetically speaking, was superior in every aspect, it would have a hard time replacing the current system - just like oil and coal companies do all they can to slow green energy nowadays. 
Blockchain technology itself is however revolutionary. It allows trustless certification of digital ownership. People have always spend tons of money on digital assets. Whales in MMORPGs oftentimes spend thousands, if not tens of thousands per month. Some CSGO players spend hundreds of thousands, or even millions, on skins. Digital assets are worth whatever people are willing to pay for them, just like real art. There isnt really any difference here.. except that you *do not* actually own these assets, and you can lose them with no trace left. The company providing the service can go bankrupt and turn off the servers. Your account may be banned, even undeservedly so. All you get for buying a game is the right to play. You dont actually own anything, even if you buy it. You also cant, legally, sell it, even if that's oftentimes done. 
If only we had technology allowing us to verify ownership of digital assets, enabling us to truly own something we paid or worked for, and as a byproduct enabling us to sell it externally, legally. Oh wait. We do. Digital ownership is required for certain tech, and will eventually be commonplace. So much so that you wont notice you are using it. Many things will be NFTs, and noone will have to use the term or care about the topic at all. After all, it's just fancy, fantastic technology.. nothing more, and nothing less. What people do with it on the way there, that's a whole other story. But is anybody really arguing against people being assholes?

TL;DR: The technology itself is not a scam. How could it be? The statement itself is ridiculous, ignorant even. The scene is however infested with scammers. That is the case for various reasons, but mainly because a) the tech is new, b) the tech is extremely complicated, making it easy to fool people and c) people loving the idea of making a quick buck by investing in something they dont understand are the exact type of "customer" scammers are looking for. Easy to scam, gullible people. As complex as the technology is, i wont say it's anybodys fault for being scammed. That's just not the case. However, most people who get scammed invested into technology they dont understand, for reasons they shouldnt have. The tech is complicated. If you invest in something this early you have to know what you are doing. Eventually you wont have to know how a wallet works or what a blockchain is any more than you currently have to know how a client server architecture works, or what happens internally between you swiping your card and money being transfered from your bank account. That is a consumer-grade technology stage. Crypto simply is not there yet, but people act like it magically would have to be there, just to counteract their own mistakes and.. quite frankly: stupidity.

author: Captain Falcon
comment: People that believe in the concept, implementation, or simply the idea of Cryptocurrency love to tell you how it's so useful and promising because it's decentralized but it is centralized just in a radically different way. But nobody really seems to realize that. The current Blockchain ledger is, at the end of the day, only the "official" ledger being used because that's the one that an overwhelming majority of people or computers are agreeing upon and if 80% of the crypto community decided that a different version was the legitimate one and decided to skew from the original and have a tangent ledger branched off from the original then everyone who's transactions and coins were tied to the original branch would be immediately considered illegitimate and would be forced to comply to whatever rules are being imposed due to the specific information and transaction chains recorded in the new ledger.

author: Mijc Osis
comment:
One of the really crappy things about blockchain is that we REALLY do need a decentralised system for tracking asset rights between online services (think the ability to move your avatars appearance and outfit etc, all of which are copyrighted digital art, between virtual spaces), the metaverse may be a ridiculous buzzword but it is clearly a part of our future, that much has been clear for decades since the success and failure of SecondLife, the ongoing success of Minecreaft, Roblox, VR Chat etc etc. People DO want a frictionless way to transfer assets between digital worlds, and honestly blockchain is such an integrally flawed tech that the hype round it has set this back probably decades. 
Append only transaction databases are almost as insane as the concept of eternal growth that underlies our economy - exponential growth and finite resources just doesnt math.
Its also really ironic that every modern 'metaverse' looks and seemingly works so much worse than SecondLife.

author: Mijc Osis
comment:
I have to object to the anarchist thing, I know a hell of a lot of leftist anarchists and none of them went down the crypto rabbit hole, we all saw it was a ponzi scheme, and in general we dont believe in supply and demand token economy - much more labour economics. We also had better things to do with out GPU/server downtime (ie BOINC).
I also kind of object to your characterisation of Beeple, within the digital art world his work was well known enough to be considered cliche, VJs would joke about newbies just using free Beeple loops rather than creating their own work for years before the NFT thing.
Something else you seemingly missed - in tech FUD also equally means 'Fear Uncertainty Disinformation' and has been used for decades as a shorthand for corporate disinformation (initially by IBM in the tech context), whichever definition you use the implication of disinformation is strong in a modern context.

author: Jean
comment:
The simple fact I can send whatever amount of money, wherever in the world, whenever I want, and in addition having it done without a third party is revolutionary. this has simply never been done, or made possible in history before bitcoin.

Second simple fact, Bitcoin is the only asset system that can't be hacked, banned, or replaced/copied, making it an extremely attractive store of value, especially since it holds a fixed amount of coins and therefore can not be inflated. 

Next, it can't be stolen, considering you have your bitcoin away from centralized exchanges.

While most other crypto projects can rightly be referred to as Ponzi schemes, rightly criticized as in the video, to refer to bitcoin as such is misguided. 

But thanks for the video! Was looking for the critical arguments against bitcoin and I finally found a proper opinion on it!

author: Stephen Davidson
comment: First let me say great video. Bitcoin was doomed from the start in both design and application. There's too many mistakes to list here but the biggest ones was allowing it on the stock market which subjected Bitcoin to government rules and regulations it was designed to go against and the other was asigning a fiat currency value to Bitcoin itself. We was NOT supposed to price Bitcoin in Dollars, Yen, Yuan, Euros etc. It was supposed to stand on its own math value. The Bitcoin supply is also a problem and due to the way the code was written, it can NOT be changed without Bitcoin destroying itself. As far as excessive energy consumption goes, no not really. That was just someone spreading climate change BS. Visa and MasterCard alone consume 10 times more energy than Bitcoin mining does.

author: Michael Harris

I don’t usually comment on videos. But it’s really sad to see so many views on a video with such a narrow perspective. It feels like you made this video with a lot of resentment towards the crypto industry.

I also got hurt badly by the crypto industry but I personally have grown and learned a lot about how to manage my personal finances throughout all the mistakes I’ve made. School never taught me that.

author: Lola Dog
comment: You went into the creation of this project with your mind made up that crypto is bad. Then created a narrative to support it. This documentary is factually light, heavy on opinion, generalizations, and dozens of omissions designed to skew details in his favor. Bitcoin & Ethereum have completed 1.8 Billion combined transactions. The ledgers are transparent and available for anybody to personally review. Crypto is not anonymous like the myth suggested. It is highly volatile as any new sector is. Because all blockchain software is Open Source, anybody can download a copy of Bitcoin or Ethereum's clients and run nodes. You yourself can see what's happening. That is the very antithesis of a Ponzi. A Ponzi scheme requires opaque conditions where the investor doesn't know what's being done with their money. Bitcoin is the exact opposite. I've already given you more verifiable facts than this video did.

author: Left _Ventricle
comment:
There seem to be quite a few people pointing out James’ points of view not being strictly factual, but that in turn reveals those were missing the argument of this video.

The point he makes is how the tech, wherever it comes from, is utilised in ways that are more in alignment with ponzi scheme, than any legitimate use cases the inventor(s) has/have initially imagined. This is a good argument in itself. Perhaps more so, this means the understanding of tech itself is not as fundamental as it otherwise would have been. 

You can apply this core argument of ‘it’s used wrong no matter the origin narrative’ to various historical fields. Especially the WW2 era aviation tech. Not sure I can fully explain why, without having to write an essay-length comment though.


P.S.  If you ever feel the need for ferocious defense against any oppositions to whatever you protest for, it’s about time to pause a little, and evaluate if you are shaping facts around your belief, instead of creating beliefs around the observable facts.

author: OutOfTheBoxThinker
comment:
As a software developer, I don't consider Bitcoin impressive in the slightest. It's very poorly designed in many different ways. Its limited number of transactions makes it impossible to use as a currency at scale. Its requirement for miners to process transactions while requiring more and more resources from miners to get fewer and fewer rewards makes it fundamentally unsustainable in more than just one way. Add to this the complete and utter lack of stability of crypto's value, and you have several reasons this can't ever work as a currency and it's only really good for speculation.
I can't think of any other uses for blockchain that don't have many of those same issues, and that aren't also inferior to whatever it's supposed to replace.

There's a big difference between crypto investment schemes and crypto itself*. The former is where the scams happen. Bitcoin's price has risen and fallen in a boom/bust cycle since its creation. * there have been loads of worthless coins created, that people have jumped on, only to find they were worthless after all.

author: wrfootball
comment:
Good video I must say, but a few things he is incorrect on (IMO):
1. A bubble is not a scam.....its just hype and people buying in....nobody forces you to invest, so stop taking the easy path and blaming others...its YOUR responsibility.
2. There is nothing wrong with new technology and innovation...if its masked with a token (possibly a scam) then again DYOR.
3. There is alot of overlap with AI here in the WEB 3.0 narrative, it makes sense...we can see where its all heading. Do we seriously think that all technology stops here at web 2.0?! Yes its a risk, but no risk no reward....you're crazy if you go all in! 
4. Bitcoin uses lots of energy yes, but miners are now looking for cheaper solutions to lower their costs which creates innovation for cheaper energy! Michael Saylor has talked lots on this....its great idea!
5. Any asset you buy relies on someone paying a higher price, thats not unique to crypto. Remember these are NOT companies so of course there is no revenue generated. One can justify stocks because they generate profit....but thats just a way to justify it. Many things go up in price that are not companies, like old antiques sitting on your shelf at home. 

Crypto imo has value because I can send money instantly and dead cheap........cant do that easily with fiat! Theres value and a use case right there! Then you got self custody with hardware wallets and so many other use cases....its definitely valuable and the market shows that.

Its a very exciting time, but if you dont want to get "scammed".......then dont invest....simple.

author: Strath Attack
comment:
There is one cryptocurrency that is actually useful and is pretty much everything that bitcoin was meant to be: private, decentralized, and you can actually use it as a currency much more efficiently than bitcoin. However most exchanges refuse to list it, governments are desperately trying to either ban it or at the very least de-anonymize it and currently most use of it seems to just be for the black market.

This just shows that even when a digital currency that could possibly replace a country's current currency, the government is gonna do all it can to stop people knowing about it and either banning or limiting how people can use it. The reason why bitcoin is okay in the government's eyes is because they know it's on a public blockchain therefore all transactions are public and not private, they also know it's not a threat to the existing currency. However as we move towards a cashless society, privacy coins such as monero does actually pose a threat, because if they take away cash, currently the one way we can make transactions privately, people will naturally move towards privacy coins to buy certain things they don't want anyone else knowing about. Even though I agree with this video that most cryptocurrencies are a scam, I do believe that a cashless society is unfortunately going to be here soon, and when that happens people will be looking for alternatives in order to make transactions anonymously, without the government seeing everything they're buying or selling.

author: Ryan
comment:
So I sat through this video and didn't see you go over what Blockchain and crypto was initially even created to solve and do... The main purpose was to remove the need for an intermediary trust (banks), but still have a trusted ledger of transactions, total assets etc. Right now we are at the mercy of a few elite families and people who run the banks. Because of them the economy tanks, or businesses fail. They control it all. Now, we have other Blockchains that are here to solve cross border payments. So right now it takes up to a week to move money from USD to Pesos. With crypto, this can happen in seconds. Not to mention there would be no need for banks to hold excessive amounts of USD in order to complete these transactions. I could go on, but all you did was scratch the surface and cherry pick your argument against it. 
Now let's get to "you only make money because you sell to others who lose". Wow, that sounds like EVERY OTHER MARKET. Real estate, stocks, Forex? I mean c'mon. Maybe interview some actual Blockchain experts instead of some biased influencers.

author: Cam Fuzzy
comment: "Bitcoin has no inherent value".......you are correct.  However, neither does....gold....or a Picasso......or that $10 bill in your pocket.  Cryptocurrency vs stocks vs gold.....what makes it valuable? What makes it valuable is what people are willing to pay for it or what a society perceives its value is.  Wheat, nothing says that a plant has ANY intrinsic monetary value.  However, if one person feels they have a greater need for it than whatever that person has on them that other people see as valuable, they will give that up to get the wheat.  If the person across the street is hungrier though, they may offer something that has a value more than the first person...all of the sudden the "wheat" is valuable.  So, the person across the street hands the vendor his $100 bill....that vendor just traded something that is needed to sustain life for a small piece of paper.  That small piece of paper has as much use cases as Bitcoin does, society just perceives that it differently, literally....that is it....end of story.  Difference is one is the government saying "trust us, that useless piece of paper has value" while the other is as valuable as a population is willing to back it.  Crypto, yep, tons of scams...just like anything involving large amounts of currency in a new fledgling development.  But, what it ALL comes down to....wanna know why an NFT is worth so much?....cause someone was willing to pay that much for it. Wanna know why a physical piece of art is worth so much?.....cause someone is willing to pay that much for it. That painting is, literally, absolutely worthless in the grand scheme of things. You cannot eat, you cannot drink it, it does not provide you with shelter, it does not carry out a specific job that benefits society....it is absolutely no different than an NFT, except you can carry your NFT around in your pocket, while the portrait  you paid 37 million dollars for, sits on a wall....doing absolutely nothing and having absolutely zero value....unless someone else is willing to pay you for that piece of parchment stuck to your wall that does nothing to sustain you.  All money is a giant Ponzi scheme or a giant con.....I just know if I was on a stranded Island, a barrel of water and a crate of food would have a much higher value than a crate of green paper with portraits of dead government offials stamped onto it.

The biggest scam is the banks and governments of the world, but we have been brought up with them all our lives and have not known any different. My bank has stopped me from sending my own money from my account to an exchange on the pretext of “protecting” me. That’s BS, what they and others are trying to do is stop their avenue of wealth from deteriorating. 

There are thousands of crypto tokens / coins and many are rubbish/scams, but not all, and there is a very good user case for some. 

Let’s not forget, that when the internet was born many questioned the reason for it and concluded that it was only for porn, drugs and money laundering. Now the same excuses are being levied at crypto!

If you think crypto is for crime only, just search for your bank and find out how many millions it has paid in penalties for breaching the regulations that are supposedly in place to protect us all.

author: Marek Nipca
comment: I agree with 90 percent of  otherwise great video. I have a few comments about the Bitcoin section. As for the problem with the deflationary nature of Bitcoin. Before the Bretton Woods system was abolished, all currencies were inherently deflationary and this was not a problem. People knew that it pays to save, and by moving their consumption into the future, they created reserves for future economic growth. So, thanks to Bitcoin, we are going back to real sound money. The energy demand of Bitcoin is not a problem if we consider that the cost of running an ordinary average bank is much higher. In addition, Bitcoin enables better management of electricity consumption, which fluctuates and rises throughout the day. Thanks to Bitcoin, excess energy in low traffic can be used to validate transactions in its network.

author: Interesting Times
comment: When I first started watching, I was thinking "this guy probably doesn't understand why bitcoin has such a revolutionary concept, but all the other coins and nft's are clearly a scam, but if he really understood how the banks and financial system worked and how bitcoin worked, he wouldn't be calling it a scam" and about 30 minutes in, I am starting to see how even though I do not believe bitcoin was created with the intent to become a scam, but thats what it became due to the nature of how people interpreted and adopted it. The sad thing is that the financial system is still extremely corrupt and leaving the vast majority of people vulnerable to negligence or even intentional harm. Something like bitcoin, combined with different networks like litecoin or others, make it scalable to fulfill the need for a decentralized, incorruptible system, but the truth is that the whole crypto ecosystem has become corrupted via the interpretation and the behavior that is now associated with it. The hope is that some kind of decentralized currency can be formed, but it would likely have the same tech behind it to make it work (hence, bitcoin looking so attractive). Unfortunately, the central powers will likely create a CBDC before that happens and then they will have even more ability to control the financial system to corrupt it in their interests and have more tools to control society. Tbh, I still have hope that bitcoin will become what it was intended, when regular life becomes more controlled and less free. It is the currency of the black market, so it will not shine like the big believers hope it will until everything that we enjoy about contemporary life becomes part of the black market, and we will have to use it to have the things we do now. But really I just hope that it never actually gets to that point. Im just glad that we have some form of infrastructure to facilitate a way around a future with an extreme form of corruption and manipulation of the masses, if that does ever happen. This was a great video and brought a lot of attention to what has happened in this space, from the genuine to the deceitful. Bravo

author: Stefan müller
comment: i think James must have been scammed with Bitcoin earlier and unloads all his anger. His depiction lacks of core fundamental on Bitcoin, especially 2nd layer. How can you talk about small first layer block size being too small with fractional transactions per second compared to visa and Mastercard. Do your job and educate before publishing. Bitcoin lightning has transaction capacity of more than 1.2 mil per seconds and hence way larger than visa and mastercard combined. Lightning network growing exponential. Such a one sided negative view on Bitcoin without any positives at all is just embarrassing. Bitcoin is designed to be a store of value not a currency though its monetary policy is better than any fiat currency existing. Fiat is about trust only, btc as well but based on math and the most secure protocol network human race has ever seen. Superior technology requires energy thats a law of nature. James puts nft, crypto scams and eth into one basket with Bitcoin proofs his lack of fundamental knowledge. Transferring digital property around the world at the speed of light is just revolutionary. No any other energy consuming technology can be used better with renewables than Bitcoin. Tons of daily wire transactions facing problems with intermediaries where no problems at all suppose to occur. Bitcoin will eat all of it. Hard money always beats soft money, period. El Salvador, Central African republic, brazil the list goes on. James you are dead wrong on Bitcoin, and face reality next years again. Go and educate sovern instead of counting off innovation.

author: David Salami
comment:
As a blockchain engineer myself, you are right in saying that 99% of the crypto industry is a scam, but blockchain still has a solid use case as a private payment network, to me that's really the best use case that makes sense, there's no scalable platform that has achieved that yet, but there will be soon.

I live in a country where making international transactions is a hassle, and the government constantly tries to lock citizens out of international commerce, stable coins have been the best way out for most citizens and this is because they exist on the blockchain that the government has no power over.
A lot of things have no business being on the blockchain, and they work just fine or even better with centralized systems, but centralized financial systems are never good for anyone. Blockchain tech has not solved the money problem  yet, but it has the potential to solve it permanently.

author: TruSam
comment:
I agree with the scepticism about NFTs and ICOs. But calling the whole Crypto space „scam“ is a bit far fetched. Bitcoin for example has its problems and negativ aspect like the huge energy consumption. But so has the monetary system, which more so deserved being called “scam”. At the end of the day there is nothing that has intrinsic value. Every value is perceived value. If everyone tomorrow would decide that dollar, bitcoin or gold is worthless, well then it would be worthless. Same goes for NFTs, even tough I don’t see any value in them too. But that is just me. 

I think the problem lies in us humans, trying to get rich quick. It may work, most likely it wont. But if you for example trust bitcoin or gold as a store of value, because you researched the topic and history of other currencies and money, and your expectation is to at least outplay inflation: i think is a completely different story, which wasn’t even mentioned in this video. You made it highly polarising, and I which you would have shed light to all the different aspects of crypto and it’s use cases. Not just a few. Or at least wouldn’t call the whole crypto space “scam” when you only talk about a few aspects.
We definitely need an alternative monetary system that is not controlled by centralised entities to store whatever we traded our time and work for in and not have it stolen by war, gambling of big banks etc.

See, your audience doesn’t even know about this kind of stuff, because you were so focused on the “scam” narrative. You also completely leave out some of the actual innovations technology wise that has happened. People just think it’s only money. That’s selling short what the technology actually does. Your video will likely convince others that’s what it’s all about. You don’t have to like crypto, but you should have brought a more complete and balanced perspective. This video clearly is not that, though you might want to think otherwise. It presents only a small pipiece of the picture. Sadly, this video will be the beginning and end of some of your audience’s knowledge journey. They will move on while the war for technology and the financial system continues unnoticed by them. You hardly even talked about this at all as well.
