author: Stefano Murcia
comment:
This content was good in pointing out the scam scheme that original Bitcoin purists have pointed out since the beginning. To unpack the statement above, we have to make an attempt to understand the original Bitcoin protocol and the path it was intended to follow. I am of the understanding that BTC the way we know it today is not the original protocol. The original code still exists, has been updated to allow for the original vision, and continues to stress that everything presented in this video is true.

Where I would like you all to do your due diligence in is in the attempt to understand what happened ahead of BTC forking to Bitcoin Cash and then again to Bitcoin Satoshi Vision (BSV).
Dr. Craig S Wright is someone worth listening to.

author: N
comment: You aren't describing "Crypto". You are mostly describing the scams in crypto. You could say the same thing about the internet and all the scams running on the internet. You are also mostly focussing on the money part, which is totally irrelevant. It's the same as talking about Facebook and only think about the stock price, it's not what it's about! It's about the tech. You think the world is only the USA, but there is more in the world where decentralized networks are a big solution. Even some governments are using it. Also a lot of big companies are using it, and that's why it's possible you have used crypto or NFT's without even knowing it. I actually find out a couple of weeks ago I used a NFT ticket without knowing it. It was from a party a couple of years a go and it was just a normal ticket, but with the information stored on the blockchain. It was from Guts Tickets and they used GET Protocol. The user won't even notice it. But it's also used in cars for example, like Alfa Romeo is using it in their cars. But there are a lot of other examples and use cases, and a lot of companies are already using it. So please, get your facts straight. It's not just all scams.

author: Andrew Schneider
comment: Very well done. I think much of crypto gets a well deserved bad rap. That said, the base use case of crypto is to simply relace USD as the global reserve asset, which is currently valued at hundreds of trillions of dollars. Our current fiat money has major, major flaws: It's forced upon people, it can only become more inflationary over time, and has very limited transparency to the very people is it meant to serve. All of these limitations with fiat can be solved by blockchain based money. Additionally, I think the critique of web 3 here is missing the potential pros that could result from all this. There are actually very real and very valuable use cases that will be enabled through transparent guarantees and ownership of assets that blockchains can enable. Regardless of all this, it's nearly impossible to convince anyone of their stance on this topic, they either hate it or love it, like Trump and vaccines. 🤣🤣

author: Mustafa Dağ
comment: I do think that you are 99% right. There is a BUT coming :). Firstly, most of the projects are absolutely scam. As you mentioned before to make some cash. But Web 3.0 is not just a myth. Think about it. All the data you have right now, where do you keep it? As an example, I guess you keep most of your passwords on Google Passwords and you do not even remember most of them. I know companies like Google and Microsoft are reliable but can you guarantee that you can trust them forever? Just assume that one of your mails have been modified without your consent. Can you prove that you haven't send that mail? Absolutely NO. Why? Because the mail is kept in Google/Microsoft or whichever service providers you have used databases. Hence they can modify it without your consent and you have no way to prove that they did modify it. I know this is a bit forced but is it really that much impossible? You can think other scenarios too. But in these blockchains, the code is open source for most of them. If you do understand coding you can just go and check whether they keep your data behind the scenes. You own your data because the blockchain systems do not run in one centralised server. In PoW it works on all the miners computers. In PoS it runs on all validators which are in most cases permissionless meaning everyone can be a validator as long as he owns some "shares" of that project. As long as less than a percentage of validators are malicious, majority can detect the action and prevent it and punish them. In PoW the punishment is waste of energy spent on Work part. In PoS, it is the "shares". They slice your shares according to ruleset which are determined while deploying code in other words when the blockchain started to operate. Hence, although you do not lose your "reputation" like right now, you loss money if you are malicious. This is why it is called "Trustless". You do not need to trust anyone. You only need to trust/understand code. If somebody tries to act smart, the code will punish him accordingly. It was quite a long writing, but I hope people who read can understand what Web 3.0 is about. As I mentioned at the start you are 99% right but this technology is not as trash as you mentioned :). Just wanted to inform people who are interested. Have a great day!

author: Alien Wizards
comment:
These new technologies and materials included the use of high-temperature superconducting magnets, vacuum-sealed switches and special ceramic insulators. 
The magnets were designed to help maintain a constant and consistent magnetic field, even when high stress levels were present. 
The vacuum-sealed switches were designed to reduce the potential for electrical arcing, which could cause damage to the switch. 
Finally, the ceramic insulators were designed to protect the switch from high temperature variations and prevent any electrical shorts.

author: Drupe pong
comment:
Here's a question that I have for the people who believe in crypto and the decentralised currency thing. 
Basically a group of people coming together creating something new that they all believe has value, and a tech that can be used to confirm and keep a record of all transactions. 
You don't want to believe in the centralised money. But if you don't want to believe in the centralised money, why should the state/center regulate your space for you? If it does start regulating then wouldn't it just become similar to centralised money again? The very thing that you were trying to avoid?

I think in any form of money, you could always have bad actors and people with power. 
What happens when they misuse this power?
You can check their transactions and you can even prove that they acted fraudulently.
But what next? without also having access to a centralised means of coercion/force, you cannot get them to change or do anything.

So a decentralised money exchange also means you don't have access to the centralised means of coercion. 
You can't gain full freedom from state regulation but also want to have it when things go wrong.

With that being said, I think the best way we can go about this is to make the centralised money/coercion system as democratic as possible. 
One thing that stands in between us doing this is the present form of Capitalism.

author: James Brown
comment:
Gonna have to disagree with the conclusion, along with a lot of the assumptions made along the way, particularly regarding Bitcoin.  To say that it 's only a Ponzi Scheme is to imply that it has no value aside from people trying to make more money on it (which is apparently Jame's conclusion), which really isn't the case.  

People see value in a digital asset that can't be frozen or seized at will by an outside entity (government or otherwise), particularly in countries like North Korea, wherein the leaders have implemented all types of draconian laws regarding how everyone's "own" money (their country's fiat currency) can be spent.  And I don't think I need to point out the cons of an inflationary currency like those used by nations around the word.  We can all look to the rising prices of food and about everything else, to the tune of about 8% in one year, in the US (that's nearly an 8% loss of purchasing power in one year's time!), and MUCH worse in other countries.

To simply gloss over real value propositions like this have me wondering just how much actual research went into making this documentary.  It certainly isn't unbiased in how it's presented, at the very least.

Also, to act like 13 years is long enough to close the book on an emerging tech simply demonstrates naivety in how the adoption of new tech generally works.  The Internet was around for a LOT longer than 13 years before your average person considered it a mainstay and/or a valuable technology.  You're always going to find that a large portion of the population will push back against technology that threatens to significantly change the "known" and familiar.  It's human nature to fear change.

author: Jiří Šebek
comment:
NO HATE, but from your commentary it's clear that you don't really understand the PoW cryptocurrency, or WEB 3.0 itself and how things work in terms of safety.
You just don't understand how big Web 3.0 can be, but it still has a long way to go and no one knows what the real uses and all the security benefits will be. 

The funny thing is that you say it's not appropriate to trust code, yet you run a banking system that also depends on someone else's code, particularly easy to attack and rob. If selling bitcoin in profit is a scam, then whole stock market trading is a scam / ponzi scheme :D You are right that there is a disgusting amount of scammers and frauds in the cryptos, especially the NFT wave.
But from a technology perspective, it all makes sense, but governments are unlikely to give up the power they have through control of fiat finance, so it's unlikely or any other cryptocurrency should or will replace "money". Most likely they will create their own digital currency instead with some particular functions. 


The biggest problem with the whole video is that you refer to the entire crypto as a scam, even though you only point to NFT scams. 
It's like saying that the banking system is the biggest scam in the world because the bank I had money with went bankrupt and won't pay out all my funds, because every bank is contractually obligated to pay out only 10% of your total savings. But that's not true, it's just that I chose the wrong bank. My own decision, and what could have influenced me? 
Ads, recommendations, previous experience, references, exactly the same as with any crypto project. 

Cryptocurrencies are at an early stage and the only reason why BTC is constantly increasing in price is because the amount of it is not increasing, but the "real" money is constantly being printed => thus devaluing. I am not an advocate of either extreme view. I'm a simple realist... 

Market trading (stocks / cc / etc.) is about buying cheap and selling expensive. It's all about timing. For example...How long were electric cars built before they went into mass production? 
Do you think it's easy with such massively used software to avoid all the problems and create error-free code that is completely unbreakable? It is still in the phase of developing and most probably will be for a loooong time. Even NFT can have some kind of usage as a technology, but people are just stupid. 

Luckily for me, in 6 years of investing in cryptocurrencies, I've only gotten burned once on TERRA LUNA. The only reason I sell cryptocurrencies is so I can buy more for the same amount, just like I do in the stock market. They follow the same trading rules, paterns and global economic situation.
The only reason there are so many cryptocurrency scams is because people are too stupid and lazy to study the project they are investing in. Everything is super complicated, so they believe what sounds good to them, but if they trust everyone, especially influencers like Logan Paul, then they most likely deserve such a lesson.



I would sum it up by saying that it is a unique and great debatable technology that may have great uses, but no one knows if it will really be used and in what form. 
Before investing, you need to study everything thoroughly and decide if it all makes sense as with everything else. Cheers

author: Oliver Glendenning
comment:
I like this video, as it highlights some of the dangers involved in speculative investments that I've faced in the cryptocurrency space that have zero utility.  

However consider that the central banks are making their own central bank digital currencies based on block chain technology because many cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin is on a public ledger making transfers more transparent. 

I originally didn't see the point of NFTs now I see them adding utility to a business and value to brand ambassadors. Consider you buy and online ticket then it's gone imagine tokenising that ticket and creating value  also helps the environment compared to paper ticketing. It's also  been  proposed to tokenise  property like title deeds etc and other things.

Another big benefit of crypto currency in my Opinion  its quicker to transfer at a fraction of a penny compared to banks, literally some people have sent $hundreds of thousands abroad for cents on the dollar and some of these money transfer cryptos are able to process tens of thousands of transactions per second.  There's plenty of Ponzi schemes in cryptocurrency undeniably but we can't rely on at system that endlessly prints money, every currency in the world on a long enough time line goes to zero and becomes super inflationery.

author: Daniel
comment:
Very good video - not in agreement on the full story, but definitely agree there are a lot  of bad actors in this industry. 

One area that was left out are macroeconomic realities. For example, the excessive increase in global government debt, which can lead to defaulting states. This is one actual reason to have globally decentralized currency. For example, Argentina defaulted on its debt in 2001, 2014, and was on the edge in 2019/2020. Ask folks from there how their savings fared vs. BTC in those years. 

Regarding NFTs: there are artists featured in this video (Vinnie Hager for example on the HBR article flashed up) who are decent people building community. Wondering if this video could have benefited from another perspective ❤

author: Rebecca W
comment: So I agree with this entirely and I have been in crypto space since 2018. One thing I wonder though, is what about the countries that are adopting Bitcoin as their official currency which I know one is El Salvador, then there was the Central Africa Republic but I heard they switched and banned it so not sure, and I heard about Venezuela but not sure. On the other side of that coin is the counties that have banned crypto, which are many. Does the counties who ban it seem smart like they don’t want their country or their people to lose all their wealth in a scam (when the volcano explodes), or are the countries that made it legal smart? I got out cause all the regulations at tax time, why trade crypto with a nightmare at tax time when you can just trade with a broker that automatically gives you a form. Or even a prop firm. Plus why on earth would I use crypto on a Visa card to make everyday purchases when the SEC declared every sale of crypto is a taxable transaction, I was waiting for you to mention that, but I guess you were too busy talking about the bigger picture. Really though how Bitcoin could never be a currency now. I know people in the space say when one Bitcoin is worth 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 million  then the value of it will stabilize so people will transact with it, even if it was a stablecoin, it’s still a taxable transaction. Not to mention too that the military is developing a super computer and when that thing is capable of hacking the blockchain all crypto will be history!

author: jaydy71
comment:
It's a well made video, but I don't agree with the argumentation. 
Yes, there's a lot of horrendous scamming using crypto currencies but that doesn't make the technology itself a scam. There are lots of ponzi schemes using fiat currency too, and that's also not the fault of fiat currencies.
There's absolutely nothing in crypto that inherently makes it a ponzi scheme.
What crypto/blockchain enables is a secure way to do online transactions without a middleman. That is in itself a clear use case that has clear value. 
Yes, that also makes it attractive to scammers and other criminals, but guess what: scammers are gonna scam and criminals are gonna crime no matter what, it's a different problem. 
One could outlaw crypto outright, but that wouldn't solve any crime (and it wouldn't actually even be the reason to outlaw it).


Of course NFTs of pictures of bored apes and other Trumps-depicted-as-superheroes pics are cringy as f*ck. I can easily waste my money on similar stupidity without getting near crypto technology too. I've got a thousand baseballs for sale, signed by Babe Ruth, J.F. Kennedy and Einstein. The first buyer will get an actual bridge thrown in. You can pay me in gold.
Just don't be stupid with whatever you invest in, crypto-enabled or not.

author: Mateusz Borczyk
comment:
Let's assume that cryptocurrencies are a scam, a ponzi scheme, and it is certain that their value will fall dramatically. Therefore, it is logical that you should short them. But if so, and a lot of people will short them, it means that they are obliged to buy them back in the future. And this will make their value rise again! 
My conclusion is that cryptocurrencies value will never fall totally just because they can be shorted! Unlike other ponzi schemes which cannot be shorted. 
In my opinion, this is a gap in logic that most people do not realize! You can make money on dips as well as rises, that is why cryptocurrencies will never collapse! Just because of the ability to make money on dips. Come to think of it, I believe it is possible to create a mathematical model that confirms my reasoning. Futures will save cryptocurrencies as long as you can make money on dips. Without contracts - agree, perhaps the value of cryptocurrencies will collapse.

author: Scott Vermast
comment:
first of all, 60% of the video you are talking about nfts.. 
people are dumb and buy in to stuff because others do, thats just how humans work.. 
if you think its crazy people pay millions for a digital signature on a random meme picture, you are completely right.. 
but thats just how the art world works in general.. if you pay millions for a painting you are the same amount of crazy imo.. 
nfts got overhyped, just like anything can really.. and people just buy it because its "cool". its not a scam.. 
if you buy in late or that specific hype is over, thats on you..

second, you talk about bitcoin being used as the global currency.. 
nakamoto had a vision and yes that was the first premise.. but just like anything in this world, things evolve.. 
people create newer and better things, things that are more efficient, easier to use etc.. 
bitcoin was revolutionary, and yes its true, people that are in from the start benefit the most.. 
just like anything in the investing world.. that doesnt mean that it is a ponzi scheme.. 
people build on the idea of decentralizing and automating real world problems into a computer program that keeps running and cant be stopped by anyone! 
yes, 95% of the crypto projects dont really have utlity and are just hype and thats possible because its decentralized.. 
and yes, shady stuff is happening every day just like in our current financial system.. 
but i really do believe the other 5% is working on technologies that a lot of people just cant get their grasp on yet.. 

people tend to invest in crypto when everything is going up, cause thats when you see everyone talking about it in social media etc.. 
which means most people buy in late to the party.. which in turn makes people lose money and call it a scam.. 
while others sit on massive profits cause they stick around during the hard times.. investing 101.. 
i might be completely wrong, and crypto might be the biggest ponzi scheme of all time.. 
but think about the potential it has.. 
we are not just gonna be using crypto for sending money accross the globe, we are creating and automating solutions for real world problems and if people cant see that yet, i get it.. 
but most of us cant even imagine what this technology is gonna be used for in the future, including me.. 
it might be a bumpy road but i'd stick around cause what if the critics are wrong.. crypto is still so new and is slowly entering our world, adaption is inevitable imo, its just getting started. :)

author: cen10ium
comment: Saying that Bitcoin is like a spreadsheet is a bit reductive. The difference between a blockchain and a database of spreadsheets is the distributed trustless consensus algorithm, which is a conceptually significant distinction. On the issue of mining and energy consumption: yes, there is a real world "cost" to Bitcoin, i.e. it is (effectively) backed by energy (hence proof-of-work...work in the physics sense of the word). That is indeed how a hard money should function. Gold (the quintessential hard money) mining is even more energy intensive; a hard money that is easily minted is oxymoronic.

author: marvin maali
comment:
I was expecting great stuff only until he said a deflationary currency is not good for running a global economy.
Look, it is simple.
A deflationary currency looks bad because it will (also) be held for it's mere value increase tomorrow. Fair enough. But at the margin, people still have to buy food, water, and other necessities. 
So it doesn't matter if it is so scarse it will double in value every other day. Still, one has to let some of it go  so as to buy food.
Now, when it goes up in value because the economy is actually growing, I think that is a good thing. Everything else gets cheaper, abundance can be felt.
Contrast with an inflationary money system that robs people of their wealth by leadin to either price increase in goods so that the avergae perosn can no longer afford them, or a deflation in the size of goods (scarcity of wealth instead of abundance) and you know the inflationary money is worse.
I'm going to finish this, then I'll make a rebuttal video where I disagree. Bitcoin is not Crypto.
Do more research. But great video.

author: Hey Jude
comment:
This video is very poorly made and lacks a lot of key points of what Bitcoin, NFTs, and Blockchain is all about.. Remember it is a tool not a replacement!!

If Your asking, in what context have you been framed to buy bitcoin.. Well That depends on your everyday living situation.. If you live in the US where everything is a the tip of your finger then sure Bitcoin is a speculative asset and has no use case.. 

But if your in Kiev, Ukraine and are trying to get your wealth out of the country, Bitcoin is your best option.. All you need to do is remember 12 words... Unless you want to cross the Polish border caring a bag of cash or a suitcase of Gold..  You have this opinion about crypto because you have no use for it currently..

Soon you will be forced to use blockchain technology and NFTs will be in your everyday life... Your I.D., House Dead, Car Title will all one day be represented by a NFT... All a NFT is, is a way prove ownership on the blockchain.

Also you say Bitcoin is a decentralized Ponzi scheme.. Bitcoin was created with no price attached to it.. The first use of Bitcoin as a currency was when someone used it to buy Pizza.. So through supply and demand of an asset the market gave Bitcoin a price.. You can still send bitcoin free with no miner fee and no electricity burned..

And of coarse with any new industry THERE WILL BE SCAMS.. I have been in the space since 2016 and have never lost my funds or been scammed.. Because most people who lose money are Greedy Fools

author: Transcendent
comment:
I doubt my voice will be heard in an ocean of sceptics, but here goes my 2 cents. I mean this to be constructive criticism and hope it doesn't fall on deaf ears. 
While I agree with you on everything you say about NFTs, scamcoins, ICO mania, and the likes of it, I do not agree with what you say on bitcoin and how you put it in the same bag. Some of your points are lies, some are lies by omission but lies nonetheless, and it obfuscates the truth, quite the opposite of what you'd be trying to achieve with an educational documentary. I'm worried that this information will go as the "truth" on bitcoin, however I view the truth to be a process rather than a state so I hope my input will steer at least some people towards it.

- You mention that bitcoin "wastes" (instead of "uses" for example) energy without mentioning the fact that it is the MOST secure network on earth. Bitcoin being a financial network, that is a pretty import fact.

- Bitcoin indeed has only 7 transactions per second, but those transactions are final (i.e. can not be modified, ever), so you can not compare it to VISA where transactions can be rolled back even days after. Let's take the tx/s argument anyway: you make no mention of the lightning network which is EXPONENTIALLY (it can process millions of transactions already) faster than VISA and the likes and is just as secure as bitcoin because it is built on top of it.

- The big talking point of bitcoin being a Ponzi because "to make money on it, someone has to lose it", if you think about it, that is how a market simply works. Take gold, silver, any other precious metal that is also traded speculatively, take even stocks, they work on the same principle, yet they're not called Ponzi schemes. The price in a market goes higher because of 2 things: (new) people buying and inflation.

- You liken Satoshi to Madoff, while not said explicitly, it is implied and is a manipulation tactic to tarnish Satoshi's and bitcoin's reputation but since you are convinced that bitcoin is a Ponzi scheme I can see where you are coming from. Either way, the comparison is not honest on another front: Satoshi made bitcoin and just vanished and never, ever, mentioned that it will make you rich. He hoped that his invention might help humanity after seeing the corruption of the financial system, that's a lot more humble than what you make it out to be. Madoff was a criminal running his Ponzi and promising returns until the end, it doesn't fit you see?

- You say that bitcoin is a failed revolution while ignoring how much people in South America and Africa are starting to use it. It is not obvious for people living in Western countries where the currencies are relatively stable but in countries where the currency is a lot less stable, using bitcoin is already making sense. Yet you assert multiple times that it has no real use cases. What do you say to those people, that have no real alternative because of inexistant banking system, corrupt government and/or unstable currency? Is their POSITIVE opinion on bitcoin insignificant or worth less than yours?
You declare bitcoin a failed revolution while it has existed only for 14 years. For comparison, the internet started in 1983, by the same logic you'd declare it a failed tech in the dot com crash in 2000 (17 years after inception), now look how much it has changed everything. It started to really accelerate in 2010, almost 30 years after creation. I think you see why calling bitcoin a fail is hasty conclusion.

- You mention the Winklevoss twins, and how these two well-educated folks started stockpiling bitcoin, what is the issue of highly educated people realising that bitcoin is something great? If anything, you'd expect more educated individuals to understand why bitcoin is useful, how it works and why it will catch on. However, I do agree that the likes of Blackrock now investing in it is not ideal and doesn't make me ecstatic because of all the history of big banks/ asset managers manipulation markets, but oh well, it was bound to happen at some point.

- Finally, we invest in bitcoin because number go up, yes, as with any investment, but that is not the sole reason. We, bitcoiners, believe that bitcoin is something that can truly free us from the government-owned currencies, we have had enough of the corruption of the government and hope that bitcoin will be the separation of state and money the same way we had separation from church and state. The greed will always be present, even in the most idealistic communities, but the greediest people in crypto have moved on from bitcoin to some scams likes NFTs, scam coins etc. Therefore, today, there are a lot more people buying it for idealistic reasons than because of greed. Will we still buy low and sell high to acquire more bitcoin? Of course, as any logical individual would do in a market, but greed is not our guiding force because of it.

To conclude, I think that the part on bitcoin was intellectually unhonest as is evidently implied by my lengthy comment on such a small fraction of the video. However, the video is very well made, easy to follow, exposes what needs to exposed, so good job for that. With great following comes great responsibility, so be careful what you say and how you say it.

author: Rudolph Teperberry
comment:
Nice video! I'd mostly consider myself a bitcoin maximalist these days so agree most cryptos are scams., but it might have been more balanced if you'd talked about some of the problems with current monetary system, especially inflation and money printing and the ways bitcoin can solve those issues. The use case pushed for bitcoin now is not so much as a currency but as a store of value, hence the term "digital gold". Might also have been worth talking about the lightning network which does allow bitcoin to be used more like a currency for small, fast transactions.

Also, a mention of CBDC's could have been a good idea. That is, Central Bank Digital Currencies - basically a government run cryptocurrency. There's a lot of talk about governments sneaking these into use in their path to cashless societies. If governments do take control of your cash away from you like this, then bitcoin becomes an even more attractive alternative!

author: UIM Loki
comment:
I watched this as someone who is heavily interested in bitcoin, not crypto, as I’m constantly trying to poke holes in the bitcoin narrative, as anyone with conviction in anything should do.

I agree that every clone of bitcoin, which are often referred to as alt coins, are indeed scams. However, I don’t see bitcoin as a scam at all. 

It wouldn’t be productive to refute every point you made about bitcoin in a YouTube comment, however I will say that you did a poor job outlining satoshi’s vision of what bitcoin is. You mentioned it’s deflationary, which it is, and that in terms of being a currency, being deflationary is bad because “why would you want to spend something that’s going to go up in value?” 

First of all, bitcoin is not simply a currency. The concept of a currency is something that can be applied to most anything. For example, in prisons cigarettes are a currency, in kindergarten, Pokémon cards are a currency, etc. bitcoin is useable as a currency, but a more apt name would be “digitized energy”. You can convert physical joules into a scarce digital asset through thermodynamics. That is the real innovation of bitcoin, that is proof of work. 

Secondly, everyone has sold something that would’ve gone up in value if they hadn’t sold in, in order to buy something in the present. Stocks, property, art, commodities such as gold and silver, collectibles, etc. 

I wish you went into more specifics on the claims you made, but had you done that the title of the video would end up being the opposite.

author: David
comment: Very well explained.  I understood from the beginning how the whole system of cryptocurrencies, NFTs and games based on digital cryptocurrencies works, and when I told people they laughed, they thought I was delirious.  I'm glad that you made this material very well explained and documented and I hope that more and more people will wake up to reality!  I personally have never used Bitcoin as an investment but as a currency to play in online casinos because I could quickly withdraw my winnings, but I did this consciously because of what cryptocurrency is and how it works, I didn't buy for the mirage of getting rich overnight.  And yes, cryptocurrencies are useful if they are treated as what they were meant to be: money transfer with lower fees than at banks and the possibility to buy products and services with them.  If you consider them as a start-up investment, you have lost your way and this is where the disappointment begins!

author: Nathaniel Wildstone
comment:
Enter now Web 3.0, crypto, and blockchain: The latest “farts in a jar” craze that’s all style and instant gratification and no real substance. A trend that looks at the Bernie Madeoff’s of the NYSE and the Elizabeth Holmes/Theranos of Silicon Valley and says, “What great and perfectly evil distributors of absolutely nothing in exchange for great wealth for a handful at the cost of untold suffering for everyone else, but we can do it faster?”

Just what the world needs to emerge from the financial crisis of 2008: Bitcoin, which promised democratization of the Internet whilst building an even bigger, emptier house of cards.

Great video. Very insightful

author: bla ba
comment:
09:40 you should use your money on the things you need, not throw it away on bullshit out of fear it not holding its value.
the idea of our hard earned money value being slowly eroded be presented as a good thing is insane to me, how can we save value for later in life? how can we pass it on to our children without gambling it away in the stock market? whats the point of money if its value is not kept?
if you build an economy built on stuff people dont really need, dont be surprised to find it wasteful and controlled by consumerism 

10:01 bitcoin is not going to replace visa, it will be the method by which you keep the value of your earnings, once you want to spend it, you can transact some of it to the less trustworthy currency and make as many transaction as you want with vise or whatever 

10:58 what is the sum total of bank energy consumption around the world? servers, real world working people, driving to workplaces, branches, programmers, fraud detection, regulation, is that free of energy use? no, a stable financial system comes with a cost, this is not new.

10:18 to talk about bernie madoff right after talking about bitcoin is kinda manipulative, unlike banks, people control the bitcoin in their wallets, where if too many people will ask the banks for the money they have placed there, the banks will say "sorry we dont have it" just the same as in the case of Madoff, the real ponzy is in the banks who dont really hold and safeguard your money, the play with it, gamble with it, yes, they are mostly transparent about it, but the fact is that the money you placed in the bank is not really there, just like madoff

13:30 some people buy bitcoin as an investment, some as a hedge against fiat currency, some as a store of value,  none of it really changes what bitcoin is.

14:20 no, that is not the only way for bitcoin to get more valuable, printing money also strengthens bitcoin for example, currency collapse is not a new phenomena, governments can be irresponsible and we have ample examples in the past. 

16:25 dunking on 'the nerd' for being invested in something is a bully move, trying to undermine the credibility of some one for liking world of warcraft is pretty cheap, did you check what other people in powerful positions like video games? lawyers, judges,  politicians, bankers, leading tech and scientists

im a bit tired and honestly doubt many people are going to read this so im not going to continue,  but there is to say, 'crypto' has its flaws, it is far from being a perfect system and it is definitely far for maturity, there are thousands of fraudsters out there, you should be extra careful and doubtful, most coins will crash at some point, but the big ones will probably last forever and out live the dollar, and thats the point, with all of the flaws in bitcoin, it should be compared to the alternative, a government, maybe not even your government who can freely print itself currency which is equivalent to stealing from you, banks that dont really hold of the money you have given them, and state laws that allow some organization to take your money from you.

bitcoin has it flaws, but they are not as bad as the current financial system.

author: Tom Cuthbert-Sayers
comment: A lot of this seems to rely on bad-faith arguments. For example, crypto is bad and a scam because capitalists invest in it as a way to make more money. That seems to say more about the enduring malleability of capitalism, than anything about crypto. Hence, your criticism is not about crypto, per se, but rather capitalism. The same can be said about the "wild-wild-west" days of crypto and celebrity endorsed rug pulls. True, certainly these are scams, but again to say crypto is inherently bad and a scam only because of some douchebags see an oppertunity to make millions is, again, more of a critique of capitalism than crypto, per se. Regulation will help do away with all that and most, if not all, crpto enthusiasts want regulation to some degree. What extent exactly is another conversation all together, however. Thirdly, your claim that crypto mining uses huge amounts of energy is a known fallacy. The environmental impacts of mining is negligible comparative to most "big businesses". Fourth, NFT's are a part of crypto, perhaps. But it certainly does not exhaust it. They are not equivalent nor identical and to simply lump them together as one big scam is ridiculous.

author: David Rowlands
comment:
The crypto market experienced a bubble in 2020-2021 as did many asset categories such as tech stocks. This was caused by low interest rates and government money printing. The crypto bubble was exacerbated by the Bitcoin halving which created a supply shock for Bitcoin its issuance rate halved leading to a mania. If you cherry pick the starting and ending dates as Jan 2021 and Jan  2023 then of course it is easy to make Crypto look like a ponzi scheme. But If you were to other dates such as Jan 2019 and Jan 2023, for example, you will see that the market cap of Crypto has tripled.

If Bitcoin were a ponzi, I beleive that it would have ended in 2017/18 after the bubble of that year popped.

Whenever I saw artists and non-tech people promoting NFT's and Crypto coins I kinda assumed those were a scam. My friend got into them and is in the hole right now. I think NFT's have a great use case if it was used with physical services, but I would never pay a lot of money for a picture that anyone else can see online, that ISN'T physical at all. I was trying to sell my Art AND also give people prints with a purchase but I guess since I wasn't a ponzi scheme no one would help hype my NFT's up. I don't think ALL crypto is a scam. author: Brett Denaro
comment: An NFT allows you to digitize any physical asset. Think real estate for example. A thousand people can take ownership in a block of condos. Ownership is broken up through NF Tokens and those tokens increase in price as real estate prices increase, but each token receives income from rent.  NFT's, while they started out as simple JPG's, will morph into so much more in the coming years. Another use case that is going to turn finance upside down is something like Ripples cross-border payments technology. They have a messaging system (like SWIFT) but also use the XRP token which enables instant settlement (which SWIFT can not do). So this enables banks to eliminate Nostro-Vostro accounts and use that locked up money for other investments (billions of dollars are locked up in Nostro/Vostro accounts) . This technology goes far beyond what is used today, but Ripple has onboarded a few hundred banks and payment providers all over the world (not to mention, Countries are looking at Ripple technology for their CBDC).  I did not watch the video above, but based on the comments below, there is a lot of uneducated people leaving comments about technology to which they are clueless about.

author: Jake O
comment:
I loved this video. You still need some knowledge to fully understand what he is describing, but it is comprehensive. 

Just one thing. Blockchain is not new. It's a new and improved mousetrap, something that was based on the principle created over 60 years old. We, old computer programmers, knew it as a linked list. Lined lists used pointers to connect links in both directions. Blockchain uses has to connect links in just one direction. It was in the mid-1960s when IBM created a database that was structured as a linked list.

author: Elisio Lopez
comment: First of all I apologize if my english is not perfect, I'm not a native. However, I've been an investor for the past five years now, always holding. All of the content in the documentary is very accurate. Nontheless, it's too focused on the obviously scam, the NFTs, which as it's very clearly said it's all about promoting the mass adoption. Well, everyone who has been in the space for more than 4-5 years now knows about this. And also that all this subject is just the beginning of the real point, which we are all going to watch happening in the next 30 years, probably. But we have to make clear that most of the people who is watching this does not even understand the magnitude of the whole thing. Once you reach a proper amount of money to provide yourself and your beloved ones a pretty easier life, (and it does not matter if you have cash or crypto, if you worked it or you recieved it as a gift) you will necessary need to pass through the wolves who reside within each one of our countries, the central banks. They will take, in most of the cases, 25% of the amount that you invested, plus 25% of the amount you recieved or made through your work, which leaves you with a tiny part of what's truly yours. It's not a fucking secret, we've been stolen by them for the last 300 years this way. The only thing happening here is people being aware now of what they are loosing every single day of their lives. In my country, for example, if you are a business person you won't start taking profits from your work until june, considering a natural year from january to december. It does not matter if you put that money into stocks, bonds, yields, gold, start a new business, buy a house... whatever. I know all this sounds apocalyptical economically for someone who is not very into it, but wait for the crypto money from the central banks (CDCs). It will be then when people will understand the real meaning and difference between bitcoin and the rest. We always need the practical method to understand things.

author: Walter M
comment: I think what is frustrating is that blockchain actually does have some interesting use cases but 99% of what blockchain tech gets used for is money. There are some interesting projects out there that do make use of blockchain and unfortunately what you will see (or not see) is how these projects will integrate into our daily lives without us even knowing we are using them. I really do believe that decentralized currency is a system that will ultimately replace traditional money backed by governments. It is absurd in the modern era to have a vaccine or insulin shot cost drastically different amounts in other parts of the world. Crypto will ultimately bring equality to markets and consumers. Yes, there are scams, a metric shit ton of them, but the idea will ultimately win out and become mainstream. Bitcoin is not sustainable and its own market is starting to realize it. I don't think people should avoid crypto but I would say that they should understand the serious risks involved. Great video here. Obviously this guy has some skin in the game. He's not a hater or whatever. He has experience as an investor and has done his research.

author: Jay Glascoe
comment:
Well, you certainly challenged my belief in Bitcoin.  But I'm onboard with all the other "shitcoins" being Ponzi schemes (yes, ETH is a "shitcoin").

You make the point that no one transacts using BTC.  Well, people who invest in gold don't make transactions directly in gold either.  

BTC is kind of like gold but better.  Gold has an annual devaluation of about 4% due to more gold being mined every year (and gold mining technology improving every year, so it remains at 4% year after year).  Then there's also the likelihood that a few decades from now some space cowboy is going to lasso a heavy metals asteroid into earth orbit (the ultimate gold mining technology) and mine the shit out of it.  At that point, I expect for the price of gold (and platinum, and uranium, ...) to plummet due to a huge increase in supply.  But BTC will endure.

Buying BTC is not my only investment strategy.  Needless to say, everyone should diversify their investments.  The bulk of my strategy is a Roth IRA and standard 401k.

author: chino1127
comment:
Bitcoin gets a huge amount of attention from content creators, the press, media, analysts, investors and so called experts, but the reality is it's a relatively small financial phenomena.  The current market cap sits around $450B.  That's about 1/5 the size of Apple, alone.  Perhaps it's worth making a similar video about gold, which is estimated to be worth $12T in total yet has limited utility uses other than being a good conductor. Most of its value is attributed to its perceived scarcity, which is why we wear it around our necks, on our fingers, etc.  It's a stranger concept to me, that someone can hand you a block of mined metal as payment - yet we accept this as truth. 

The entire premise around the world's equity markets is predicated on the idea that the earliest buyer wins.  The notional value of the derivatives market is over $600T and that is an entirely zero sum game.  There's always a loser to every winner, but we don't call that a scam, rather we see it as a legalized way for investors to make bets against each other.  If I buy bitcoin today, I take just as much risk as everyone else.  Do I make money if many more people after me buy it?  Sure.  Do I lose, if the many others who bought/mined before me sell?  Yes.  Is it fair to call that a scam?

author: James Ode
comment:
I would like anyone reading this comment to append the fact that this video focuses on the absolute worst parts of crypto. 

Most people who are in crypto for legitimate reasons would agree with everything in this video, myself included. However, these same people would also point you in the direction of great projects building and communities who want nothing to do with these Ponzi schemes and cash grabs. 

You must also realise that crypto is essentially in its beta form. Each dumpster fire, from the ICO mania to axie infinity's SLP token mechanism, were failed attempts that have since been improved upon. This is conveniently left out of the video. 

I know it's a big ask, but if you read this comment I encourage you to go out and try and find your own information, but don't frame your search on finding the worst parts of crypto. Actively look for the best parts, see what they have to say, then make up your mind juxtaposing this video with what you find. It's easy to be swayed by a well produced YouTube video.

author: nl hn
comment:
The big problem with crypto is it poses to be a money, or a stock, with no actual value behind it.
In the real world, money or a stock represent a portion of some real thing.  Money is the value of a country's economy.  Stock is a portion of a company.  These things all have real dollar values; they are valuable.  Demand for a stock, on the other hand, inflates the value so that it is worth a bit more than it actually is.  However, making more portions of one thing lowers the value.
An object typically gains real value because it can do something that benefits people, or because it is made of a material; generally both.  Note that neither of these things rely on the perception of value.

Of course, crypto starts off with no value.  It is valueless, literally just the state of memory that can't be used to do anything.  It serves no purpose.
It can't serve the purpose of money, because what money is is a portion of an economy, and this has no economy.
It can't be stock because stock is the portion of a company which makes a product or provides a service that already makes money.  That isn't what crypto is.

So crypto has no real value.  It is worth $0, maybe even $- because it costs energy to run it all.  

That means crypto makes all of its value from demand, purely demand.  That isn't stable.  If it loses demand, the value will drop to $0, and then it will be a net cost on everyone that still has it, since they are losing money.  Everything about crypto is superficial.

author: UnderTheGoldenGate
comment: OK, so an NFT on a digital asset - the rights are enforced by who? If you purchase it, do you own the copyright/trademark? I assume you do, correct, or is that not even true?  There isn't any digital enforcement of this at this time in scale, or anytime in the near future that I can see.  So in order to enforce it (assuming you own the copyright/trademark) you need to get the law involved.  So why is the NFT better than a regular contract?  OK, so maybe you don't need a hire a lawyer, but how much does a lawyer cost, given that you can download the relevant legal docs yourself. And is is there any legal precedent to use an NFT to sue somebody for copyright infringement?  The fact that I have NEVER, EVER seen anybody talk about this, and explain it, is extremely suspicious.  Yea Ethereum has contracts, but prove that this works in scale, right now or will sometime in the next 5 years....I seriously doubt it. It looks like the geeks that WORSHIP crypto are swimming in an ocean full of dangerous creatures (i.e. scams, lack of enforcement, etc.) and they are too IN LOVE with the technology or the prospect of high returns from these things to think in terms of reality. They WORSHIP something they have no understanding of.  If I had some extra money I would only buy one of these hoping to get lucky...but then again why don't I just goto Las Vegas and put the money on a roulette wheel.

author: HawkGodMan & Lucy Lastic
comment: Ths is too daft to laf at. sorry, great video but the actual.. bitcoin stuff is beyond ridiculous. jesus coin. WTF?

A lot of things you said are correct, however, crypto does have a utility, especially for online shops. When I buy software or license keys for programs and such, many individual sellers accept multiple coins and it's way simpler to send crypto to someone than with credit cards, especially where sometimes payment processors take a way bigger fee than crypto gas fees.

For trading crypto, many people analyze the market and buy/sell based on the current situation. Different people see crypto value differently, and just like with stocks, some people do buy at the top and sell at the bottom, so the losers give money to the winners in both cases. With crypto, it is a fight between who buys the lowest and trading is guessing where the buyers will stop buying and selling then, but buying again  when people stop selling and start buying. I don't see the crypto market collapsing as people will always buy and accumulate when the price is low, and will always sell when the price is high. Some buy high and lose, but the price will restore some day, because more people will buy it at a lower price. Other people buy high again and the cycle repeats. When no one has the majority of supply, millions of people would have to sell at lower and lower prices for a coin to collapse, but they won't, as it will rise again from people buying.

author: Paul Scott
comment:
nah USD is the biggest scam...they can print any amount any time for free...devalue the currency 98% and everyone is happy. Nothing backs it up (Gold standard long gone) and USD is 95% transacted Digitally vs 100% for btc, but you cant see the workings behind it whereas u can for Bitcoin.  NFT is smoke like Art is ...is a painting worth 160 million usd?  Clearly NFT /usd/paintings/gold are only worth what people think its worth.  NFT is ridiculous, i would agree.....but BTC/ETHER is like gold , a store of value...,. albeit gold at least has a physical use.  But still, there is no shortage of gold OR OIl, yet the price is way higher than supply and demand should show....There IS a limited supply of BTC.   As for scam artist there were plenty in crypto due to the naivety of the public, but there are scams every day in dollar, art, 2nd hand car transactions...its not a CRYPTO issue, its the issue of naive consumers....

Crypto is based on a a blockchain which is essentially a sequential database.  There are not many use cases that really benefit from a public blockchain for the database...a good one would be election voting records for example or car and house sales records - house deeds etc.  There are therefore only a certain number of crypto projects that are legit and have value and many other entrepreneurs or scammers have  tried to jump on the bandwagon an come up with some crackpot scheme to sell worthless tokens to the public.  There ARE some worthwhile ones....need to look carefully at the economic case.

author: Vito C
comment:
From The Little Prince (1943):

“And what do you do with these stars?" 

"What do I do with them?" 

"Yes." 

"Nothing. I own them." 

"You own the stars?" 

"Yes" 

"But I have already seen a king who--

" "Kings do not own, they reign over. It is a very different matter." 

"And what good does it do you to own the stars?" 

"It does me the good of making me rich." 

"And what good does it do you to be rich?" 

"It makes it possible for me to buy more stars, if any are ever discovered." 

"This man," said the little prince to himself, "reasons a little like my poor tippler..." Nevertheless, he still had some more questions. 

"How is it possible for one to own the stars?" 

"To whom do they belong?" the businessman retorted, peevishly. 

"I don't know. To nobody." 

"Then they belong to me, because I was the first person to think of it." 

"Is that all that is necessary?" 

"Certainly. When you find a diamond that belongs to nobody, it is yours. When you discover an island that belongs to nobody, it is yours. When you get an idea before any one else , you take out a patent on it: it is yours. So with me: I own the stars, because nobody else before me ever though about owning them." "Yes, that is true," said the little prince. "And what do you do with them?" "I administer them, " replied the businessman. "I count them and recount them. It is difficult. But I am a man who is naturally interested in matters of consequence." 

The little prince was still not satisfied. "If I owned a silk scarf," he said, "I could put it around my neck and take it away with me. If I owned a flower, I could pluck that flower and take it away with me. But you cannot pluck the stars from heaven..." 

"No. But I can put them in the bank." 

"Whatever does that mean?" 

"That means I write down the number of my stars on a little paper. And then I put this paper in a drawer and lock it with a key." 

"And that is all?" "That is enough," said the businessman. 

"It is entertaining," thought the little prince. "It is rather poetic. But it is of no great consequence." On matters of consequence the little prince had ideas which were very different from those of the grown-ups. "I myself own a flower," he continued his conversation with the businessman, "which I water every day. I own three volcanoes, which I clean out every week (for I also clean out the one that is extinct; one never knows). It is of some use to my volcanoes, and it is of some use to my flower, that I own them. But you are of no use to the stars..." 

The businessman opened his mouth, but he found nothing to say in answer. And the little prince went away.

author: Matthew VanBiene
comment:
Bitcoin not crypto. Crypto is a scam. You completely fail to address the evolution of bitcoin, its layered network with lightning, its adoption and direct use for human rights activists, people under authoritarian rule, etc. Africa has been adopting bitcoin as a preferred currency in droves. Lightning network allows millions of transactions a second. Nostr is quickly bootstrapping itself as a a decentralized social media protocol that natively uses lightning for instant micro payments to anybody on the network. 
You also get much wrong about  bitcoin and energy. The energy use is what protects the network and renders it as the only viable decentralized network that we have today, while it also is undergoing innovation with a trajectory for net negative carbon output in a few years (bitcoin miners are capturing methane emissions as the largest reducer of methane gas than any other application as an example). All the copycats and nonsense of crypto is literally an affinity scam from bitcoin. Bitcoin remains the only true decentralized network that solves the one problem it absolutely needs to: the separation of money and state, which just like religion, is too powerful for a monolithic institution to wield power over.

author: The French Monkey
comment:
I'm one of those artists who got into the first big wave of NFT creations, being friend with Beeple and all the big names out there for years and into the 3D designing space, I kinda loved the idea of selling artwork as a 1/1 (the collections and opensea were not a thing yet) to collectors loving my work! I did sell a lot of pieces, I was on the top 10 most artwork sold list on Foundation in the early days, already had a community. 

My initial investment into crytpo was just 200$ to initialize the first mints and transactions, I probably made around 70K from selling artworks BUT i never cached out any of it... instead I supported other artists who had amazing arts, bought some pieces I loved and wanted to own, it was never about the money and for me it never will.

However, those good days didn't last long in that space... it rapidly began to just be about the hype the fomo and the gain... I've seen SO MANY SCAMS, a lot of artists ended up with hacked wallets and so many shitty projects, new blockchains and promises everywhere! everything felt like a scam... 6 months into it i got tired of the NFT shilling nonsense and the twitter mentality, so i just stopped trying to promote anything of my own or even follow the artists and pages that got me into this space.

It's so sad, but it is was it is i guess, people...

P.S. please, don't buy NFT's or if you do make sure it's from a reliable artist you want to support, and not those shitty 10000000 collectable bullshit that ALWAYS gets cancelled and rugged pull... And if someone posts anything crypto wise... it's a scam.... 1000000% be careful.

loved the video, so many insights.

author: OffKi Official
comment:
Back when the pandemic was just coming into fashion, a lot of people started becoming interested in investing in traditional markets off of the back of the crash... myself included. After all, the prices of stocks across the board were available to buy for low, once-in-a-lifetime, prices. So, I ditched my cocaine habit and opened up my first ever Stocks & Shares ISA and started saving earnestly.

I worked with a guy that also took an interest in investing,,.. but he chose crypto. Knowing full well that crypto was junk, I stayed away from it - after all, there was NO real-world use case for ANY digital currency when you got down to the real truth behind the myriad of projects. 

I managed to save a couple of thousand pounds for the first time ever in my life - which was a massive personal achievement for me. But I was impatient to see the value of my investments increase. I asked my colleague about his gains in crypto, and when he told me I was absolutely shocked! It was this that made me cast off the traditional market for this new, explosive, digital currency market - even though I knew it to be trash - and I put everything I had into it....right around the time that Bitcoin was hitting global headlines for breaking the $50,000 mark for the first time (I actually watched it do this on a live chart!)

It was also a couple of weeks before THAT day.....  

May 19th 2021. 

So, while I had just pumped all my savings into crypto.. the smart money and the more savvy retail investors were walking away with their gains; while the dumb money was being told to HODL... 

..... and HODL I did.

Move forward to today.. and instead of having a reasonably well balanced portfolio - I have a reasonably well balanced crack pipe that can stand upright on my table allowing me to use both hands to flick two lighters together to get a flame.. one lighter has gas, but no flint.. the other has flint, but no gas..... 

So that brings an end to my tale folks. What is the moral of the story here, do you think??

I'll tell you....

Eating too much sugar really is likely to be the cause of your future Diabetes diagnosis and you should have made the switch to sweeteners when you had the chance.

Calling bitcoin a failed financial revolution seems like a straw man argument. Of course the flipside is that if your are a drug dealer try and sell your product if there is no such thing as cash and the only currency is a digital and controlled by the Government. Crypto/blockchain is the future just be wary about what you get told and always do your research.

author: Occam's Razor
comment:
0:01It's sorta both. It's an interesting experiment into anonymous currency to prevent government control (as in, for example, the CCP and the Uighur population. Not that BitCoin would help them, even if it worked, just an example of what it's an attempt to fix). But it's biggest pro is also its biggest con. Because it's anonymous, it can't be regulated. Which means all the stock scams that don't work on the stock market anymore because of regulation will work on the unregulated BitCoin market (or any cryptocurrency).

1:55 NFTs are an interesting idea, but they're being misused. It might be possible to use it to as a form of verification of the authenticity of a photo or video to help combat deep fakes and media manipulation

comment: The future is decentralization, which means you own and control your own data.  For decentralization to work, there needs to be some store of value to power it, to incentivize people to contribute resources to be a part of it.  What makes blockchain tech fascinating is not an immutable, public ledger, but the consensus algorithms that power it.  It's the best conception of digital value for creating decentralized products that we've seen so far.  Once we get passed the apes and kitties and all the other garbage, you will start seeing real utility.  It's just a matter of time.  Saying that crypto is doomed to fail is like saying the internet itself is doomed to fail.  Not going to happen.

author: Jasper Kerkhof
comment:
Nice video. I agree with most things except for the part that covers Axie Infinity. The token is just the mechanism there, not the cause. The real problem is that game companies are linking in-game currency with actual money because for them it's lucrative business. But it really doesn't matter if these currencies are using blockchain/NFT's or are just managed on a server of the company itself. It's moving your economy to a virtual world which is less regulated in hopes of getting away with things you would never get away with if you did those things in the real world.

Usually it works by allowing a person to buy tokens/gems/trophies (or Axies in this case) or some other form of 'currency' for a certain amount of real life money causing virtual assets in-game to have real value. There are other examples of centralized games where the exact same thing happens and people grind out in-game things in exchange for money in hopes of earning more than what is possible with the opportunities they have back home. 

It's just that the barrier to entry is usually smaller with these games so you don't need this 'Scholar' system which is another layer of evil on top of it, but again this has not that much to do with blockchain. You can just as well make a regular game that is too expensive for poor people and be like 'Hey, I'll provide you with the funds to start playing this game, if in return you give me a percentage of the money you make with it.' 

I think this problem is more a symptom of the direction that games are going into than it is that of cryptocurrencies, although both go hand-in-hand to a certain extent.

author: humbllbug
comment:
Yahshua - you know Him as Jesus - was born to a virgin, turned water to wine, taught, healed the sick, raised the dead, casted out demons, walked on water, calmed the storm, and fed a crowd of thousands with a few fish and a few loaves of bread on two separate occasions, among many other things. He was killed on the cross as payment for the sins of all mankind, three days later He rose from the dead. Forty days later He ascended into heaven where He sits at the right hand of the Father. He is returning very soon, but before He does, Satan, the devil, is coming to pretend to be Jesus/God (2 Thessalonians 2:1-4 and Revelation 2:10). Satan is an angel, and he will have certain supernatural powers with which to try to fool everyone. He will, for example, be able to make fire come down from heaven in the sight of men. He will only be on earth a short time before the real King of Kings, Jesus Christ, God in the flesh, returns. if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved. - Romans 10:9

Now when Jesus was in Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper, There came unto him a woman having an alabaster box of very precious ointment, and poured it on his head, as he sat at meat. But when his disciples saw it, they had indignation, saying, To what purpose is this waste? For this ointment might have been sold for much, and given to the poor. When Jesus understood it, he said unto them, Why trouble ye the woman? for she hath wrought a good work upon me. For ye have the poor always with you; but me ye have not always. Be ye also patient; stablish your hearts: for the coming of the Lord draweth nigh.

author: Enlightened
comment:
4820: This is exactly how the VC world works. VCs fund a seed pitch, the business is built, funding rounds A-X happen, the company goes public, and the owners dump on retail while market markers manipulate the prices. There is 0 difference between NFTs, video games, digital securities, or physical securities. The only difference is that 99% of crypto currencies violate security laws. However, BTC is a property. Any coin that has an ICO and is an investment for monetary gain is a security and must file with the SEC. Bitcoin, not this. It is more similar to real estate and will be taxed in accordance with property tax code, while EPIC cash is a commodity because it's a fungible bitcoin and can not be taxed because it cannot be traced. 

EPIC is what people think BTC is.

author: Mark Rocks
comment: Yeah, mixed feelings about this video. I agree that there are a lot of garbage coins/apps/idea's in crypto, but how many bad companies are started worldwide that never make it, and investors loose there money. I never got why anyone would invest in something only because a "famous" person thinks it is a good idea. The direct line you draw between obvious scams and the whole crypto market isn't well done. There are a whole lot more good actors than the few bad actors you like to display in your video. What's even worse in my opinion is your shortsighted explanation of Bitcoin, and the well informed people in Bitcoin. For the people who don't like this comment: No, I am not right winged. No, I am not anti government, No I am not a Bitcoin maxi. I'm just a guy interested in the technology and what it might bring as an alternative (not replacement) of store of value and currency. It might fail, true.... but it sure as hell is not a scam or a ponzi scheme.

I asked anyone that I could find with crypto experience or "knowledge" what gave it value. The responses were somewhat varied, but were usually "algorithmic calculations" or "blockchain" or "non-centralized" or even that the USD had no value either. When I pointed out that the USD had value because of the US government's legal authority to tax it's constituents' labor and production, they would shrug and claim another ambiguous crypto trait. The ONLY thing that gives crypto value is the BIGGER FOOL theory. When these all go to zero, you won't even have a tulip to console your mania.

All these weird derivatives and loan products are useless to me and I've been in the blockchain space for 12 years. I tried using one of these yield projects once, Thyme Wonderland and it didn't work. I just don't really care about defi. Bitcoin is great for transferring value. Smart contracts are great for storing data, payroll, and other things, but financial derivatives in crypto are just a way for finance bros to pull over their same old boring games from walstreet on to crypto.

author: Bogdan Dumitrescu
comment:
Unfortunately this is a very narrow sighted view on the topic. Yes, I can agree that this side of the story is as real as it can be, but to totally miss the other one is similar to what Edison was doing to discredit Tesla's version of electricity. The most important point missed here is the human nature and the way modern society has changed versus let's say 100 years ago.

We shouldn't blame the new idea, the new invention, the new tool. Here we should only blame ourselves and our modern nature and modern priorities. There are hundreds or maybe even thousands of examples on how an invention or a concept has found a critical use case years after it's inception.

What James is portraying this technology to be is actually the behavior of the people that consume it and it's in no way a different one than the people that are consuming his content.
I'm scrolling down the comment section and I can't help not to see how comments like "Best video of 2023, pack it up." have the most likes probably just because they were among the first ones submitted or by a very popular person, and are just snowballing, racking up "likes" thanks to our behavior and not real informational value.

author: Mart Menz
comment:
In the first world you can't see the use case.

- How do you address the issue of corporate land acquisition through corrupt registry practices in your community, like bribing workers at the registry and erasing your property to build a factory on top of it? Decentralized Blockchain

- How do you solve servers in your country being attacked during a war and losing all records of your academic achievements, making it impossible for you to start a decent life in another country because you have no way of proving anything? Decentralized Blockchain

- How can one mitigate the financial burden of exorbitant interest rates (up to 40%) on small business loans? Decentralized P2P Loans

- How can monetary policy be reformed to promote savings and protect against inflation  in a way that doesn't make saving feel like wasting one's hard-earned money?? Decentralized Blockchain

author: Jared East
comment:
Very informative video. I know everyone has their opinions, but there are actual use cases for crypto that have already proven themselves, like sending it across the globe in seconds, or being able to store it more securely than any other asset or having public transactions to identify senders/receivers, etc. Most of the use cases rely on adoption with companies accepting it as payment, but adoption was also exactly what the internet needed in order to work.

Also a reminder that the point of "people who buy intend to sell to someone else at a later date" is the exact way the entire stock market works, except the stock market has far less use cases. So either both the stock market and crypto are a big ponzi, or neither are.

comment: Very well produced video, and without a doubt crypto has been a smear on society for the last few years.  But it also has some use cases that are truthfully viable.  Gold still has a use in our society today -- bitcoin is a much more practical form of gold.  Admittedly, bitcoin has serious energy issues to resolve,.  However if you do research it, Bitcoin likely consumes much less energy than the current banking or gold industries do right now.  The reason it's inconclusive is because Bitcoin's energy usage can be accurately calculated, since all transactions are recorded.  Banking and gold do not boast that.  And .  Ethereum has potential to spawn a new secure voting system, which would be highly beneficial for the world now -- election accuracy has caused marked controversy as recently as this year in Brazil, and clarity in this area would hopefully serve to dispel some of the tribalism that cripples our society now.

author: Daniel Harrison
comment:
Venture firms are interested in exactly one thing and that’s literally the biggest profit in the smallest amount of time. I worked at few Andreesson Horowitz startups in the late 90s and mid-2k. While I learned a ton, and made some life long friends, I want to say that I’m surprised by their investing in the NFT/Web3 (absolutely hate this term), but I’m not. VC firms tend to shift to the latest craze so they can exploit whatever that craze is and bring a profit.

I’m in the infosec space and the number of ‘blockchain’ security startups is absolutely ridiculous. I tend to troll them by asking when they’re going to add the terms quantum and machine learning/AI to their press kits. I’m sure there’s a novel and productive use of the blockchain in infosec, but I’ve yet to be convinced by any of the product demos.

author: Martin Obert
comment: This was an awesome video. I invested myself in crypto a couple of years back. Since I travel a lot, I thought that the best use of crypto would be to use one currency across the globe and make transactions in seconds to people living on the other side of the planet. However, once you get money into crypto, which can take days as you have to verify wallets and stuff, sending money is even worse as the other party uses a different blockchain, thus you have to first transfer to that and then transfer the money, all with cost involved. I hoped this could bring the US banking system into the 21st century but it failed miserably. For now, I think crypto is only good for day trading as it still has not solved any problem yet.

author: dog
comment:
Considering that we live in such an unequal time financially, where wages haven't met growth since the 70s, where costs are going up and up. No wonder young people (mostly men) bought into this - the American Dream 'go to college, work the 9 to 5 at the high paying job, get married, have kids' playbook just doesn't work anymore. You have to be the miracle 'from nothing to something' grindset playboy or you're a loser who missed their chance.

All the wealth and power has been scrounged up and the already wealthy are very careful not to lose out on what could be a system-shifting technology that reorganises wealth in society (like what happened in the early days of the internet and computers, and smartphones), there is increasingly less and less that ordinary people can afford to own - unless you inherit or use your fat trust fund to get you halfway.

As it becomes more and more obvious to more and more young people that it was and will always be rigged from the start, and as people get more and more aware of what capitalism is and who is powerful and why - people will be more attracted to socialism and fascism again. And while the former could be genuinely transformative in a positive way, the later is probably more likely sadly.

author: Steven Baum
comment:
Crypto works the same way, fundamentally, as any currency has worked in the history of economics.  From Cuneform Tablets, to Tally Sticks, to Tulips, to Coinage an Precious Metals, to Paper Money. It is essentially no different, fundamentally.

  Can ill-informed  people, eager for a quick way to expan their imcome be ill-advised into risky hair-brained schemes,  losing large amounts of money investing in something they hardly understand?..  Sure. 

 Even the well-informed and innitiated can be on the losing end of a bad investment that was at best, Risky, an at worst, a Ponzi-Scheme.   That's always been a possibility and always will be in a Free Maket.

author: midnight defi
comment:
I think this video is too one-dimensional. When I was in Buenos Aires in 2022 I saw a lot of people use this technology to exchange their native currency (which was suffering from hyperinflation) into USD-pegged stablecoins (USDC). They could use this as a "flight to safety" to preserve their wealth and this was not possible before. This is one of the real world use cases and it provides a real, tangible benefit. There are more examples, NFTs could make the transfer of ownership (of any object, digital or tangible) much cheaper, faster and easier. 
I do agree that there is a lot of scam in this industry, but this was the case with all bg technological inventions (telephone, internet). Criminals are always among the first adopters of a new technology. But I think it is a mistake to label the whole space as criminal and fraudulent, because this is not the case. I would have wished for a more nuanced discussion from you.

author: Greg Wonders
comment: We are seeing use cases for Bitcoin. It is just extremely simple as opposed to its technology. It is decentralised and has a good and fair economic equation which makes the fact that it is concentrated irrelevant. That is also thanks to its extreme divisibility. Let's not forget that it is robust and self-custodian. It does not need any approval from any third party besides its own network, there are no middlemen. It can also be very fast through the lightning network although greater scalability comes at a cost. After more than 2 years in the space, I am proud to have and hold bitcoin. I still believe that it holds the key to protecting ourselves from the rise of totalitarian governments. I can be both my own banker and agree to my own economic policy, thanks to it. DeFi also has its promises, although it is incredibly early in its conception.

author: Cornelius Servius
comment:
That which exists in the wake of Bitcoin - "Crypto", was surely an unintended consequence. It gave smaller players the opportunity to run the scams previously reserved for wall street without needing to pay the protection fees.

It's a paradox; Bitcoin gives financial freedom to prosper, but also the financial freedom to make mistakes and to get scammed.

Bitcoin is technically functioning as intended, but is inevitably producing unintended consequences which are separate from Bitcoin itself. 

It's a mistake to view Bitcoin as a "get rich quick" vehicle. It is also a mistake to think you can make a clone of Bitcoin and it retain the same value proposition.
