author: Chaz D
comment:
Look man, I’ll start out by saying , good video , and well put together. But your logic is flawed. There is no doubt many many crypto and NFT scams out there and def buyer beware. Where there’s people, there’s corruption because there will always be corrupt people. But to lump Bitcoin in the same basket as the rest is wrong. Bitcoins value lies in the fact that it is all verified by code, not people, and open source code verifiable by anyone who wishes to therefore it takes the corruption out of it. Exchanges maybe centralized sure, but Bitcoin isn’t. Centralized exchanges may fall (FTX) but that will pave the way for Decentralized exchanges to rise. 

My next point is that calling Bitcoin a scam because people buy it with the hope to sell it later for more makes no sense either. By that same rationale is gold a scam? Cause I’m sure as heck people don’t buy gold to hope to sell it for less later. It’s just a natural way of things because what other or better options are there? You didn’t give any alternatives in your video. You suggest holding fiat? Controlled by dirty centralized banks and corrupt governments and which is subject to annual inflation. Keeping your value in cash and you’re losing more than you think. Year over year of compounding inflation and your buying power is falling fast. 

As far as using power, over 50% of Bitcoin is mined using renewable and clean energy. And to say there’s no real use case for it is wrong on so many levels. You believe the internet was a revolution cause you use it on a daily basis. What would you say to the people who called it a scam years ago due to lack of understanding? To me that’s exactly how you sound.

author: J K
comment:
First of all: congrats for the good production.

Unfortunately, this view is very one-sided - you did not even mention one of the positive sides of crypto. And yes, there are quite a few, also from a purely objective point of view (avalability of value transaction for underbanked or heavily censorship-friendly countries - like China, escape from government-caused hyperinflation - for example in Turkey). There are even some governments working together with crypto projects to increase efficiency (Australia for example is working together with Energy Web to revolutionize the energy system and support green energy).


Of course crypto has drawn in a significant amount of bad actors that shed a bad light on crypto, but if you compare it to the traditional financial system - it is exactly the same there, if not even worse. People are just not talking about that and it's not made as visible to the public as crypto scams. 

You should definitely re-evaluate your view on crypto and do less one-sided research on the topic.
I cannot disagree with most of what is said in this video, but as already mentioned, its one-sided and generalizing crypto to be bad as a whole.

author: Emin 893
comment:
Bitcoin being deflationary, isn't that actually a good thing? I mean currencies like the USD, Euro, Yen, etc. ideally want around 2% inflation in order to achieve economic growth. However, isn't economic growth and inflation the main problem (or at least one of the big problems) behind waste? Which in turn has a negative effect on the environment?

Another thing is, by the logic of 'Bitcoin with the intention to sell at a later date for a higher price, and therefore being a Ponzi'. Doesn't this apply to gold and other assets, as well as stocks or any other financial instrument? If that is the case then why is Bitcoin being singled out? Every financial asset has it's own unique selling points, so to does Bitcoin (being decentralized and a being hedge against currencies/monetary policies), right?

Get rich quick schemes are a bane of the financial world. Since crypto is still in the early stages, it is more prevalent. But these schemes used in the crypto space actually originated from the financial world and overall consumerism. How is: "If you own a Louis Vuitton bag, you are in" different from "if you own a NFT, you are in"? How fair is it to then just generalize these arguments over the whole space? Then the same can be said over the overall financial market?

author: Dan You
comment:
I always advised people away from NFTs for the same reason you mentioned, that they are just links to a centralized server holding the image.  

However I invest in crypto because I am more scared of governments and institutions taking power and value away from the people through manipulation of money than I am of falling for online scams.  

In coming years governments will begin to pressure their citizens into their own digital currencies, replacements for the current banking and cash systems, one where they offer no alternative if you want to opt out of their measures of control and destruction of privacy for the masses(but not for the governments and institutions).  

Crypto offers a way to choose the rules you want your money to obey by choosing money with rules you agree with.

comment: Oh the last question is easy, the bomb will go off when one project gets really big and crashes.  When everyone gets their paper hands and tries to cash out, and the money won't be in the liquidity pool.  Then panic will spread, other people will try to cash out, then you got everyone trying to get out with nothing coming in.  In this scenario I assume most NFT creators will attempt to rug pull to get what they can and cash out, leaving alot of people high and dry ontop of everything else, with no money coming in and everything trying to get out the chain goes down and crashes, anything with value at that point will be utterly worthless.  While there has been many rug pulls and large projects failing, nothing has been... big enough to cause that kind of panic.  The delusional cultist talk among investors is... astounding, I am surprised they haven't balked yet.  NFT's don't grow in value or scarcity, there is no return on investment unless you sell so.. the whole diamond hands thing is an utter joke, you should sell as soon as things look like its taking a turn for the best and run.  The longer you hold the more it will collapse.

author: RawDog
comment:
As a crypto invester myself, yes the recent hype around nonsensical particular NFT's that provide nothing to society was abhorent and stupid. Think of it like buying a steak for $10,000... just to say that you can. In reality nobody benefits from that, except maybe the chef...but even they can't belive it. Luckily I never fell into that trap. That said, I still believe that decentralised digital currency is important. It brings democracy to currency, rather than allowing the wealthiest entities in the world to write the monetary rules on behalf of everyone else. Bitcoin is flawed and not the end game, just a stepping stone, and almost everything else in the space is a cash grab. But this is early days, the first steps towards a better system.

Side note: The whole 'the only reason to buy bitcoin is to sell it to some other poor sucker for a profit' (ie a 'Ponsy scheme)...... well, News Flash.. that's exactly how the dollar works. Infact thats how the whole global currency and stock markets works. What do yo think Wall street does? They buy shit and sell it to some poor sucker for a profit... including dollars.

The way I see it, this is just another free market asset, just like the dollar. This time they are limited, and therefore more volatile.

author: Iron Yuppie
comment:
Your conclusion Bitcoin has no use case is based on the assumption inflation is a good thing, or at the very least not necessarily a bad thing. This is as we are seeing inflation at a 40 year high, which has meant middle-income and low-income families have seen their standard of living decrease even further, something that have been on the decline since the 70s. 

It’s been well documented that the legacy financial industry consumes a significant amount of energy, more than the BTC actually. 

I argue with the rest of the conclusion though. The other projects in the space are securities in all but name, looking to make Venture Capitalist  and the like richer. The founders of Ethereum have been in bed with JP Morgan since it’s inception.

author: Alex D
comment: There is only one thing he missed early on, three words. The Silk Road. The use case that propelled BC in the early days was untraceable payments for illegal contraband via dark web marketplaces, primarily The Silk Road. I was an observer at the time. A very large, and very difficult to estimate amount of funds was being funneled into the hands of some very powerful crime organizations. There is a non negligible portion of crypto that continues to serve this function and has expanded beyond hippie dealers in Colorado paying German MDMA labs to ship an ounce or two of moonrocks. People hide dirty money in BC, and use it to do dirty things.

author: SpringInFialta
comment: At its basic level the blockchain is a highly inefficient way to document transactions that trades efficiency for lack of trust.  A system that relies on trust, such as credit card transactions, will always be more efficient than something like the blockchain which requires no trust, but instead relies on multiple copies of the same data.  The blockchain is not revolutionary.  It is as revolutionary as putting your money in a very heavy safe with thick lead walls, a sophisticated locking mechanism and armed security on guard 24/7.

author: martifingers
comment: My understanding is that NFT's do not necessarily convey anything that would normally be construed as "ownership" eg transfer of copyright, ability to use on commercial products etc .  Rather it's the right to have your name (or ID string!) associated with it.   I think this video suggests this is the case but perhaps the exact differences between NFTs and traditional forms of ownership could be made more explicit - the slippery nature of virtual goods is confusing and opaque - which is part of the problem.

author: Michael Wiese
comment: This is not going to age well. I agree that crypto is a bunch of BS but not bitcoin. The speaker promotes much of the same old bitcoin FUD that’s been debunked over the years. Do more research next time to avoid spewing a bunch of disingenuous misinformation. For example you talk about transactions per second but fail to talk about the lightening network which is the layer 2 scaling solution and can easily do 10x the amount of transactions that Visa or Mastercard can do. Also you never touched on how proof of working mining incentivizes using stranded energy such as flared methane from landfills or that it can help greatly build out renewable energy. The last and more important thing is you never once touched on how this technology can help the billions of people in developing countries that live under authoritarian regimes or double digit inflation. Overall very disappointed at the lack of depth this individual takes on the topic of bitcoin.

author: Fugazi Wuzi
comment: The creator of this video is not well informed about Bitcoin. The low number of transactions of bitcoin are not a bug but a feature. It ensures the chain is light enough to be distributed over any device for the foreseable future in order to preserve decentralization and security of the network. There is a second layer in Bitcoin called Lightning that allow much more transactions of any value at very low fees but with less security. Bitcoin is like the digital vault and Lightning the wallet. The revolution is Bitcoin. Not "crypto". Bitcoin is the antidote for fiat currencies (infinite printing of dollars, euros, etc). Now it is also the antidote for crypto. Crypto is fiat 2.0. We are so early ...

author: Andrew Byron
comment:
Great video, but according to this, diamonds, gold, and any other "asset" that has little practical use and is held purely as a store of value to increase wealth is also a ponzi scheme then. In order for any asset to increase in value someone has to lose money. Even houses are a ponzi scheme, why should they ever cost more than the materials and labour to build them.
It's a massive oversimplification to call Bitcoin a ponzi, it is no worse than any of the others I mentioned. Value is purely belief, if everyone thinks it's valuable, it is, if no one thinks it's valuable, it isn't, unless it's an object that can solve a problem. A knife is always valuable, a bar of gold is useless on a dessert Island. Inflation is proof that our whole economy is a ponzi!

author: _Cryptotruth_
comment:
The post that I’ve read seem like a fan club & friend based support group, not genuine responses to the content of the film itself.

The doc focuses on NFT’s, not cryptocurrency.  And, if it had been advertised as such instead of the FUD about cryptocurrency as an economic ecosystem, it might have been worth watching for someone thinking of buying NFT’s (i.e. gambling).

Add to a lack of knowledge in basic economic literacy, it is a clear propaganda piece aimed at discrediting a legitimate & important economic revolution.

It’s going to take a lot more than this shame of a documentary to stop cryptocurrency from being the future of economic commerce.

I’m just sayin..

author: Al's Declassified
comment:
This was an awesome video and I agreed with 99% of it, but I noticed one key mechanic to this video: you spent only a minor portion of the video on bitcoin itself, and spent the majority of time on all of the vapor ware and Ponzi schemes that exist within the crypto space (and rightfully so). 

Bitcoin itself DOES have very real adoption outside of hype and sentiment, but you need to look abroad. People who live in countries with hyper inflating currencies like Venezuela and Lebanon are flocking to bitcoin as a store of value and digital gold. They have the access to buy it in a way that they never would have been able to with physical gold. Power of asset management is now being given access to the world, and it’s hard to appreciate that when living in relatively stable countries/ the western world.

author: Ivan Chernenko
comment: Unfortunately he completely ignored the most compelling use cases for Bitcoin and decentralized finance. Millions of people in Argentina, Turkey, Lebanon and many African countries are using cryptos now to store wealth and use it for transactions. Many millions more cannot get bank accounts and this represents additional growth.  Since its only a matter of when fiat currencies fail, given the exponential growth in both debt, and interest on the debt, there are only 2 mediums of exchange that can replace a fiat currency. One is gold and the other are cryptos. Since we used gold for thousands of years prior to the internet, the next medium of exchange after each countries fiat currency(likely the majority) blows up will be crypto.

author: CMW
comment:
You missed one of the best use cases: 

1) I send you a bunch of contraband or other illegal service.
2) You now owe me $1 million but don't want to be linked to that trade.
3) I create a bunch of rare NFTs
4) I tell you to buy one for $1 million (or better yet 100 for $10k each)
5) Your debt to me is settled and you get to use my NFT as your profile pic and I get to claim my income is from NFTs.
Bonus 1) A bunch of copycats will see those sales and buy even more of them from my collection.
Bonus 2) When the NFTs crash in value you get to write off the loss against tax.

Makes me wonder who owed money to Trump.

author: Chomp Chomp Katze
comment:
Bitcoin and ALL altcoins are definitely a Ponzi scheme. But it has also made billionaires out of thin air. Its hugh volatility enables anyone to speculate and make lots of money (as well as hugh losses) in relatively short periods.

Think of this as a game of mahjong; there's no game that ends with everybody winning or everybody losing. Some will win and some must lose. So long as a greater fool is willing to pump more money into Crypto, this well-greased wheel of Ponzi scheme will keep rolling, possibly forever.... creating more rich population while at the same time creating more brokes and losers!

author: martin Ntuwa
comment:
I believe most people are scammed on the internet just for their luck of knowledge about it, just like any other scam. But when you talk about "Crypto" which I believe should mean Cryptocurrency not Cryptography, then that's something else. Also note that NFTs are mostly purchased by Ethereum not Bitcoin, but of course the word "Bitcoin" represents the cryptocurrency world. Even if you buy Dodgecoin, you can call it Bitcoin. 
In this documentary, there's no mention of what cryptography has done in the world of cyber security and what it can achieve in the future. Web 3.0 is still not decentralized and also uses Ethereum, and have you asked yourself why some people are trying to make the internet decentralized?
All in all, this is a great video about "Cryptocurrency" not "Cryptography" and a lot of internet users can learn from it, especially the dark side.

The black market has largely moved on from Bitcoin, being eclipsed by currencies such as Monero. All of these other currencies besides the big named ones are even worse, as they have no value as currencies whatsoever.

author: Keith P
comment: Another excellent piece of work, as I've come to expect from James.  This piece was well researched, superbly written, and presented with the usual high production values that you associate with James and his work.  It seems to me that crypto is but another cult, but this time one that is founded in cyberspace, rather than in some physical commune that occupies space in the real world.  It has its high priests, and its devoted followers, and, like any other in-group, it has its own set of beliefs, and even a language of its own to differentiate the believers from the non-believers.  Indeed, those who are non-believers are depicted as trouble-makers, and are condemned as being heretics.  As with anything like this, no good will ever come of it.  Indeed, the capacity for harm is really off the scale.  Thanks for this one, James, and thanks for saying what really needed to be said on this subject.

author: DarkMagic666
comment: The problem here is that, ever since the dollar no longer had to be backed by actual gold assets, there is absolutely nothing holding it up but "the full faith of the U.S. government". So if our government fails, so fails the dollar. If the country gets into too much debt such that other countries won't accept the dollar as a world currency, so fails our entire system. The dollar has lost 90% of it's value in a relatively small amount of history. Since I started working in the early 1970's, $1 then equals roughly $7 now. So do the math... that's a loss of 86% of the dollar's value in my lifetime. So exactly what makes anyone think that the U.S. dollar is actually more secure than Bitcoin, or any other coin or currency that is only backed by "the full faith" of any government just because they say it's so? So far, the record is pretty bad for any and all of them. It's about to hit the fan.

author: Iguana Divergent
comment: Your sketching of community cultist behaviors and scammers and then generalizing them to ALL crypto and ALL blockchain technologies show how incompetent this documentary is. Just because there is cultist behavior doesnt mean there are no good debates happening. Just because there are scammers and fraudulent investors does not mean there is no good underlying technology. The fact you write off blockchain as a buzz word shows that you do not understand the advantages of privacy, security and decentralization it can bring as opposed to WEB2 or the current internet model. We live in a society where data leaks and privacy are non existent, perhaps you should do a documentary on that instead and why that is. Perhaps dive a bit deeper into counter arguments and technological debates instead of sketching scammers and community cultist behaviors as the only means being used. As a filmmaker I acknowledge your skills, as a neutral analist you have totally failed. Maybe you should work as a storyteller, like become a politician. Should fit you better.

author: Mitchell Dale
comment:
I think this video moves on too quickly after pointing out that NFTs mostly just consist of a hyperlink on the blockchain. It doesn't matter much that other people can also access that link. However, literally every cryptocurrency or crypto asset is supposed to derive its worth from the decentralisation that comes with blockchain technology. That monkey JPEG might not have any intrinsic value, but at least it's supposed to be YOUR monkey JPEG in a way that no central authority has the power to take away from you. But if the blockchain is just storing a link to it on some image hosting website... Then you're completely reliant on a central authority in the form of whoever's hosting that site. They could take the site down or delete your monkey JPEG or replace it with something else and there's nothing you can do about it. The blockchain does nothing to protect you from that. So what's the fucking point?

Even if we play along and pretend that these pieces of "digital art" have just as much worth as real, tangible goods, this is kind of like paying the price of a Lamborghini for a receipt that only says "I own the contents of the garage at this address" without specifying what those contents are. At the time you made the purchase there was a Lamborghini in there, but somebody else has the keys to both the garage and the Lamborghini and could at any time remove it and replace it with a fucking golf cart or nothing at all and you have zero legal recourse if that happens. You don't have a document saying you own the Lamborghini itself, you just have your little piece of paper that lists the garage's address and no proof that a Lamborghini was ever in there. Even if you can prove it (e.g. Wayback Machine or something), it doesn't matter much because your receipt isn't a legally enforceable document or anything, it's just something you show off for clout.

author: GetGud
comment: Bitcoin did not become something new when Satoshi disappeared.  It still works essentially the same as it did back then.  You can still run a node with 2014 software and it is still compatible.  Bitcoin also has not failed.  Adoption is still increasing as well as the security of the network.  It has not replaced major central bank currencies yet, but the jury is still out on whether or not it ever will.  Also, Bitcoin cannot meet the definition of a Ponzi scheme since there are no expectations of returns.  Ponzi schemes by definition require an expectation of a return and those returns being paid by new investors investing.  If you only buy one bitcoin, you will only ever have one bitcoin.  You might be able to find somebody willing to pay you more than you paid for it, but that is not a ponzi.

author: SonRubs
comment: I really like your video, although I'm a bitcoiner. I also think almost the whole "cryptospace" is a ponzi. NFTs are trash and Web3 are overrated - I'm with you. There is one thing it came way to short in my opinion. Bitcoin isn't the problem - the people are. The idea and usecase with bitcoin is clear and there are many good arguments to the critics like wasting energy and scaling stuff. I'm not the biggest expert, but I can try to explain something if needed. If you take a look what fiat currency is and how it works, you will discover that the money isn't the problem. It's the state and the people again. The most argument against crypto you can use for fiat too and there is more trouble. For example the energy critic for proof of work. Do you think the whole fiat system don't need energy? It's a bit of short thoughts if you bring bitcoin in a context with token, NFTs and Web3. Bitcoin isn't any of this scam stuff. I really think it would have been better to separate this more. Furthermore ask people who haven't bank account or anything. We're looking from a really privileged perspective. You know what I mean? I understand everything in your video and the most time I'm totally with you. But in the end we have to ask for the roots of the problem. And this is, what came to short in my eyes. We have to talk more about behaviour and why the people are so obsessed with money. The people are the problem, not the technology.

author: Ross Stephenson
comment:
I asked ChatGPT

"Is crypto a scam?"

Here's what ChatGPT replied:

"Cryptocurrency, also known as digital or virtual currency, is a form of decentralized currency that uses cryptography for security. Like any investment, there is a risk of losing money. However, not all cryptocurrencies or projects in the cryptocurrency space are scams. It's important to thoroughly research any investment before putting money into it. Some projects may not have a strong team, a viable product, or a solid plan for success, which can increase the risk of the project being a scam. It's also important to note that some countries have a stricter regulations and oversight on crypto than others, so it's always recommended to keep an eye on the legal status of any crypto project you might consider investing in."

author: Karim Abu-Aqel
comment: You mentioned that you may just not understand this technology. To that I say, listen to people who do. On the philosophical front, I would recommend listening to Robert Breedlove, specifically his talk with Lex Friedman. On the technical and humanitarian front, I’d recommend listening to Charles Hoskinson. There are many intelligent and hopeful people working on this technology that believe in a better future for all through blockchain technology and it sounds like to me that you got swept up in the dark side of it. The side you mentioned absolutely does exist and is despicable, but with every new technology, exploits are going to exist. It will take time to iron out all the wrinkles but there is no doubt in my mind that blockchain is going to change the world in a big way, specifically the trustless nature of it.

author: Nik One
comment:
Normie: Bitcoin is based on nothing. It's a Ponzi scheme!

Me: Bitcoin was created as a secure, digital currency, as a way to break away from the Central Banking system that removes 50% of the purchasing value from the US Dollar every 5 years by way of inflation. Bitcoin is decentralized (no CEO or company behind it that can be bribed or threatened) its price is based purely on market forces and the energy required to mine it (which doubles ever 4 years due to the 'halving'), it has a built-in scarcity of only 21M coins (19M mined so far, the last coin is expected to be mined in the year 2140), it cannot be seized or frozen if kept off Exchanges, and is the only asset known to man that has appreciated from $0.01 in 2009 to $21,000 in 2023. While Silver has lost a 3rd of it's value in that time and Gold has remained stagnant in price and actually dropped when inflation is factored it, Bitcoin keeps going up in price. It's the only scarce and desired asset that can be sent to the other side of the earth in minutes for the transfer cost of $0.05. No banks, middle men, paperwork, IRS involved. While telling us to keep away from it, the largest bank in the USA "JP Morgan" has been buying up Bitcoin like crazy, investing in exchanges and funding mining operations. Central Banks have also been doing the same. Like the internet, Bitcoin has had its predictable ups and downs. Never forget the Nobel Prize winning economist Paul Krugman claimed the internet was a fad and by 2005 it would have no larger effect on our lives than the fax machine. And when the dot-com crash happened, many people thought the internet was a dead project. It's now thousands and thousands of times larger and more profitable now than at its highest hay day during the dot com boom.


Normie: Bitcoin created nothing.

Me: Wrong. Satoshi not only created Bitcoin, but also solved the "double spend" problem. Blockchain was also developed with Bitcoin, so there are 3 major inventions there. The double spend problem being solved is already used by websites, banks, credit and debt cards to increase security. Blockchain is being used from everything from inventory cataloging, to social media, to real estate, to eventually the way we vote to prevent voting fraud and to verify votes in a record that will remain forever and cannot be modified; votes could be verified by anyone using the public key and the private key would contain the personal information of the voter.  Each voter will receive a copy of both keys when they vote online or in person. This will be revolutionary to preventing voting fraud, and that's why the elite don't want to see technologies like Bitcoin continue to grow, they know it will lead to a world they don't personally control, a better world imo.


Normie: It can't be valuable as an asset, because Bitcoin crashed during the recession.

Me: Yes, everything crashed. But in the last 2 years, Bitcoin has risen more than stocks, bonds, Gold and Silver COMBINED. At the start of the recession there were approx 250 million Bitcoin wallets. That has risen to over a billion wallets in 2 years. Bitcoin has become the world's fastest and most widely adopted asset. Gold and Silver will never again be used as a currency. We are in the digital age and technology will only increase over time. Other Cryptos may become pennies, nickels, quarters and dollars, but Bitcoin will always wear the crown as digital Gold and a store of value. 

Normie: Yeah, I don't care to learn much about it, so Crypto is a scam.

Me: Crypto may be. There are over 20,000 of those and they are nearly all centralized and controlled. Other cryptos can be shut down by going after the CEO or company behind it. Bitcoin is different than all the other centralized 'copies' out there with a never-ending supply. There is no way to shutdown Bitcoin. You would have to capture the nearly 4 Million mining computers scattered throughout the world to shut it down. As long as there is one computer running mining software that's connected to the internet, Bitcoin will be alive and kicking.

Normie: You planning to sell your Bitcoin for millions one day?

Me: Nope. When it's time, I would no more trade Bitcoin for dollars than someone in Mexico wants you to trade your US Dollars for the Peso and pay them in that. They want USD. Bitcoin will become a world reserve currency eventually. It beats all other Fiat currencies. People will want Bitcoin over cash by 2030.

Normie: Nobody is using it as a currency.

Me: Incorrect. El Salvador made Bitcoin legal tender. At least 5 other countries have followed suit. Russia recently switched to Bitcoin for international trade and to avoid sanctions. Unlike precious metals, they don't have to go through the process of shipping and protecting those rare metals, which is also time consuming. Bitcoin transfers in minutes and there is no worry about it being captured or seized in transit. For example: Recently Germany paid $9 Million to repartate $15 Billion worth of Gold from Paris. It took 5 years to move it, provide security for it, scan it with expensive machines to assure it was pure, not diluted or some of it filled with tungsten. 

Normie: Well, NFT's are a scam!

Me: NFT's are more likely money laundering schemes for the high priced sells. Someone has a bunch of shady money, they decide to launch an NFT and buy it themselves to clean the money, pay themselves, pay taxes, and make it all look legit in the end. NFT's as a technology is legit. It will be incorporated into ticket sales for sports and concerts and have countless other uses in the future.

Normie: The whole crypto scene will fail in the end.

Me: Pattern recognition and similarities between Bitcoin and the internet says no. All new technology, Internet and Bitcoin included, go through an "I & S" curve progression. They start slow, then become wildly popular and trendy so the price spikes before the technology, promises made, and development is ready for it. This creates a crash when there is nothing to latch onto and fall back upon. But the crash is short lived. Development continues. Apps are created. Games are built on it. Eventually it comes back up through the "S" curve upwards. Bitcoin has countless projects being developed for it. We hit the top of the cursive "I" and fell down to the bottom of the "S". And the S is 1,000's of times larger than the boom at the top of the "I'. By 2030 Bitcoin will be wildly popular and cherrished as a reserve asset for all the reasons I specified above. I would not be surprised if a sign of great wealth is owning a single Bitcoin. Bitcoin was created as a currency, but became a reserve asset. Forks like Bitcoin Cash and Bitcoin SV maintain the currency aspect of Bitcoin through faster and cheaper transactions and a much larger blocksize. You are welcome to buy and spend those like cash.

Normie: I don't understand much of the technology you are speaking about, so it's a scam and I will seek out videos like this one to provide the confirmation bias I need to continue staying in the dark about all this.

Me: Ok. But it's very likely you will be unable to ignore Bitcoin in the future. It will be an integral to our lives as the internet, likely more as it becomes a universal world asset. And when you do purchase some when the price is vastly higher, please remember, "you buy Bitcoin at the price you deserve."

😉

author: Имран Ибрагимов
comment:
First of all, there is a really little virtue in flipping your opinion on crypto in the bottom of the market. People needed this outlook 2 years ago, not now. You are not opening eyes, you are following general public opinion and amplifying it, resulting in more people losing money.
Second, crypto already have usecase. It allowing people to own USD and transact it freely within minutes, and even earning interest. There are millions of people in countries with dysfunctional banking systems that benefiting from it right now.
Third, argument about greater fool is silly. For example, people of Argentina are buying USD to flee from constatly detoriating national currency. Does it mean that they are looking for a greater fool to buy their usd later? Governments accumulating gold, does that mean that they are looking for greater fool too? While there is many usecases emerging on Ethereum, Bitcoin is fine as it is and don't need anything else.

Yes, there would be another hysteric trends like NFTs and ICOs. People would use them as casinos and loose money, but this is not what defines crypto as a whole.

author: Huitzi Diaz
comment:
I really love your film James, its very well made. I appreciate your point of view and narrative as it's all true and real, and helps spread awareness.
I understand most NFT's and Cryptos are scams and have no real reason to exist. 

In spite of this I just wanted to share why i currently utilize NFTs, and still find them exciting
As a musician I use NFTs as a way to sell my albums. i don't portray my NFT's as an investment, it's just a way for me to spread my music, and for people to support me similar to having a Patrion.
Like you said there was a lot of mania around the space, which during all the hype allowed me to easily spread my music to  a new audience. 
Smartcontract enabled me to create by own music marketplace without needing a third party
I Copyright my music first the conventional way, because as you said a smart contract is not law
I think the phrase "Code is law" is more a reference to the fact that we can deploy "Solidity code" on  chain without the need of permission. (this means a lot of scams will pop up) 
In some cases the code is unchangeable (immutable) once deployed, hence the phrase "code is law" although it may not be legal no one can stop you from deploying it and using it. 
Now of course there may be legal consequences as to why not to interact with these things. but technically there is no way to stop them.

I also just wanted to mention, you can utilize "proof of stake" chains  in order to be carbon neutral. ( i don't use any proof of work /mining incentivized networks)
 "Zero-Knowledge Proofs" allow for data to be stored privately on chain without IPFS.
"Zero-Knowledge Rollups"  allow for thousands of transactions to be bundled up and recorded as a single transaction and sent to another network inorder to be verified. (cross chain security)

author: Brandon Compton
comment:
NFTs are definitely a scam, no doubt. Crypto really does real world use and can transform the business and financial world. The biggest set back is the ponzi side of it. As a banker, I can say that if crypto can be regulated in a way that still allows it to transfer funds globally in milliseconds for micro fractions of the transfer value with a stable coun or token then wire transfers and ACHs would go extinct. Lots of other uses but in my eyes that is the biggest advantage for businesses, and would help speed up the supply chain regarding funding, and save businesses collectively billions and billions of dollars.

But, as the video outlines crypto has become a huge ponzi scam. I still have hope the crypto world will change for the better but only time will tell.

author: Jorge Inojosa
comment:
It's incredible how someone so smart can make such an extensive research and yet learn nothing, and masterfully paint this technology in the worst light ever...

First off, the title should be "NFT: The World's Greatest Scam", because it's pretty much centered around the subject. And to be fair, on that ground, the essay has some rock solid points.

But man, the "terrible" things "exposed" in this video, like pump and dump, ponzy shcemes, etc... Aren't crypto related they're human related. Yet, since crypto is so transparent and functional, it's actually very noticeable and detectable... Something that would be way harder with cash. This is one of many critical failures in the essay. The very characteristics of blockchain technology allow bad human behavior to be tracked and detected with ease. Specially compared to cash and securities.

Another fatal flaw, is "demonizing" the fact that people get into crypto as an investment and, at some point, some (if not most) of people, plan to "cash out". Well, flash news, that's how EVERY INVESTMENT IN THE WORLD works... You could even oxymoronicly say that in the end, people "cash out" even from cash itself, to buy land, goods, services, etc. And yet, wether you belive it or not, not everyone will 100% cash out of crypto. There are real applications, offering several solutions in this space, and cashing out completely, would be like selling Amazon Action's when they were a book store.

So yeah... Partially well researched video, way too centered on NFTs and labelling that as "CRYPTO" like it's the whole thing, while omiting critical concepts and areas like Decentralized Finance, Tokenization, Store of Value, and much more. An ode to confirmation bias, for both the Content Creator and some viewers.

I have no words to describe how misleading this video is, just trying to mix everything together like the Madoff scandal on Wall Street with crypto and Bitcoin... to give the appearance that Bitcoin founder Satoshi is just like Madoff and the whole thing is just a Get Rich Quick Scheme... because if that is the case then you tell me how many Bitcoins did Satoshi sell from his wallet when we were at the top of last bull run? Zero you fucking idiot. Does that look like a get rich quick scheme?? Huh? When all the bitcoins in Satoshis wallet (the very "early investor" as you would like to call him in your so called bitcoin get rich quick scheme) they just havent moved from that wallet in more than a decade... that would be the worst get rich quick scheme if you have to wait more than a decade to cash out. But obviously this dumbass never mentions this in his video because he knows nothing about bitcoin and Satoshi. And i could go on with all of the fallacies in this video... because seriously this guy just wants to sit comfortably in front of the camera and take advantage of his little fame and reputation to try to trash bitcoin when his knowledge and understanding has no comparison whatsoever with someone who went to MIT like Michael Saylor or someone who builds space rockets like Elon Musk... was someone as intelligent as Elon also  scammed into buying bitcoin?? Haha sure this pathetic influencer has more brains than Elon Musk or Michael Saylor.. yeah right. What is amazing though is amount os stupid people believing this kid and his very poor done research. This video is just about an angry baby whining in front of the camera that he fell for a rug pulled and lost money.. all because he didnt do a "well reasearch" before investing in whatever project or nft he lost money on. But to try to compare any of the scammers he talks about with Satoshi is seriously showing he doesnt understand Bitcoin whatsoever. He just made this video trashing Bitcoin because right now is a hot topic since we were just at the bottom of the bear market and he just wanted some views and monetize on them with whatever lies he could come up with. And just like he finishes his mediocre video... theres only one question left... whether in 5 years and 10 years and 20 years and 50 years bitcoin will be dead for the 400th time or if its value will be in the millions of dollars... thus making this dumbass and his video a fucking clown. We shall see.

author: Welcome to WhateveR
comment:
Just HODL ur btc and time WILL prove u wrong (if u dont believe in it just invest a small amount like 10% of ur portfolio into crypto. The current system we have right now is much worse. I agree tho with the NFTS, its the wildwest where people throw money on stupid pics, This CAN evolve into something much more important then pictures, it just need time to grow and find its place. NFTS are actually a very good system to proof your the owner of product X etc. There is alot to learn about both crypto and NFTs, And ALSO even more important try to understand our current system and you might realise what we have right now is much much worse. There is alot of scams going on within the crypto space so you need to be really careful and do alot of reasearch before you jump onboard. Its like buying a house, Do the reasearch before you buy, dont just jump onboard cous a friend told you about it. IF you understand the whole picture you will understand how good this system can be for alot of countries. 

You said: "the only way to make money from your btc investment is to use money from new investors". Thats LITTERALY HOW THE STOCKMARKET WORKS, its how everything works when it comes to trading stuff. someone sees it has more vaule than you do therefor he/she will buy it for a higher price. 

**The only good advice i can give is do your own reasearch, and do it well cous there is alot of information to take in.**

Your also missing out on some key information here, btc is not meant to be used as a everyday currencis its more of a store of value, But there is also a thing called lightning network which have much more transactions per second (it's built on BTC). Also ~60% is being mined with renewable sources of energy (Green energy), the number is also increasing every day which is good.  Im not a hater or anything i just want the information to be correct. Sry for my broken english!

author: Ken
comment:
For those thinking bitcoin is like stock it isn't. When you buy stock you're buying ownership in the company. So a company like Apple that makes large profits always has the option of selling itself or paying dividends to stockholders.  If Apples stock went to $1 tomorrow Apple would still be making huge profits that those stockholders are entitled to, plus all the assets of the company. The hope in buying stock is that the company will grow profits by outcompeting competitors.  Bitcoin has no profits.  It's not a company. 

If bitcoin goes to $1 you don't have anything. You're just hoping someone else will buy it for more than you bought it for.

author: Eddie Willers
comment:
One might do well to read the famous "Money" speech by the character Francisco D'Anconia in Ayn Rand's "Atlas Shrugged". Here's a relevant excerpt:

"Money will not purchase happiness for the man who has no concept of what he wants; money will not give him a code of values, if he’s evaded the knowledge of what to value, and it will not provide him with a purpose, if he’s evaded the choice of what to seek. Money will not buy intelligence for the fool, or admiration for the coward, or respect for the incompetent. The man who attempts to purchase the brains of his superiors to serve him, with his money replacing his judgment, ends up by becoming the victim of his inferiors. The men of intelligence desert him, but the cheats and the frauds come flocking to him, drawn by a law which he has not discovered: that no man may be smaller than his money."

The space grew allot in 10y and made allot more accessible but its still very experimental. Web 1.0 and 2.0 were created mostly behind closed doors in a 'centralized' way. The crypto space is not and that like you pointed out attracts indeed allot of greed. There is nothing wrong to experiment to make your vision work out. There are allot of problems that need to be fixed in the current web 2.0. The currency aspect built outside of the centralized "offline" world is one of them. The privacy concerns, the ad story and such. Web 3.0 has allot of solutions but its still very experimental everyone who would say otherwise is fooling himself. I hope after some time you will have a more positive look on it and look through the BS and greed :)

Sorry, this composition of Bitcoin, NFTs, ponzi schemes and scams is bullshit. Bitcoin cannot be a ponzi scheme. Because there's no central person or group profiting from it. And this is the fundament of being able to totally fail by bad decisions of these companies. But the only real, decentral Bitcoin ofc didn't fail. Its still on its course even under fire of critics who say all the ponzi-coins and failing trading platforms would be in connection. People are selling Bitcoin in panic because shitcoins fail or others lost theirs on bank-operator-platforms. "Not your key, not your coins". If you give your dollars to a new bank that does bullshit with them, you lose them when they lose. That's all.

many of these celebrities are given free jpegs and they look like investors and supporters. They have nothing to lose, and if that jpeg becomes a few hundred thousand dollars, this is great for them. Some rich people buy a few NFTs, because for them it is chump change and they always buy anything that has the possibility of going up. But the media is all like "Hey, alllll these celebs believe in NFTs and they are the future". First the get rich quick bros jump in. I don't have much pity for them. Then regular people think this is legit and they don't want to miss out. And some gets sucked in and spend all their savings. When they do that, the promoters of the NFTs cash out using these people's money. This is the ponzi part. 

This is indeed a sad story. There are guesstimates that show over 90-95% of people invested in crypto lost money. They fed the top 5%. This is worse than the financial system they like to complain about. This is pure evil.

author: popkian
comment: You are wrong about bitcoin and I think you know it yourself. Bitcoin is a store of value not a currency. And people will spend it in exchange  for another asset such as a piece of land or a house etc. When ever they see fit.  There is no such a thing as intrinsic value! Gold does not have an intrinsic value. We the people give something an intrinsic value. Gold is valuable because to our human eyes it was shinny and it was hard to extract and used for jewelry couple of thousand years a go not because of its electrical properties.  To an alien coming from another world there are other elements that have superior electrical properties compare to Gold. Yet Gold is universally accepted as a valuable asset by humans. Bitcoin is becoming another asset or a store of value. You may not use it for your daily grocery shopping as you dont use gold for that purpose but imagine  two countries can settle a large transaction worth tens of millions of dollar in about 10 minutes, in a safe and decentralized manner without a need to rely on a single point of failure ( U.S. monetary system). Moreover this argument that Bitcoin is used by criminals for illegal transactions is nonsense. Most of the drug trafficking and many more crimes around the world is being done using dollar bills, have we banned dollar?! No. Guns in the U.S. are being used for all sorts of crimes, have we banned guns?! No!. Many criminal activities can be organized online using internet. Have we banned internet?! No! Any new technology brings a lot of uncertainty with it. Some will resist against it some will abuse it but after a while the real potential of that technology will emerge.

author: HEXhibitionist
comment:
Just found out, stocks are one giant Ponzi scheme. It relies on the idea that someone after me, arguably a bigger fool, will buy my stock at a higher price. 
There's real value behind stocks in the form of product creating and thus value creating companies? Think again. You don't own diddly squat with your share in a company. You cant decide what products they make, you can't get their products at a discount, you dont decide who they hire etc. etc. you dont even have posession of the actual paper documents.  The only way you see your 'ownership' go up in value if 'the next guy' buys them from you at a higher price.

And guess what, that has been working ever since the VOC issued the first ever companie shares in the 1600's! The market decides what has value.  The market decided crypto has value. Is there a lot of worthles sh*t arount there? You bet! A scammer's paradise. NFT's are a good example (as far as worhtless JPEG's are concerned) . 

You have to do you due dilligence and find the right projects. Securing life changing wealth in crypto is still possible, especially while we're in a bear market, thats where the wealth is created. Buy when there's blood in the streets and when videos like this appear to make you believe it's all a scam. The blockchain tech is indeed revolutionary and was made to get rid of middlemen. The opposite has happened the last decade, where the usual entities entered the field and once again took custody of peoples money and then loose it all in scams and mismanagement. True crypto, true DEFI will set you free for real, in more than one way. Crypto isnt going away anymore. FIND THE RIGHT CRYPTO. (Hence my avatar.)

Web3 and Web 3.0 are 2 different things, the former is more get quick rich schemes pretending to be useful the second is actually part of what you are using when you use youtube and the current web. author: zaco 2121
comment:
Ponzi schemes aren't pyramid schemes. They are different. They are transfer schemes. The person (man or company) that perpetrates it gets the money. The money doesn't come through the previous investors/victims like it does in a pyramid scheme. A pyramid scheme relies on others bringing in more investors/victims.

The blockchain ISN'T kept together by cryptography. It's kept together through HASHING ALGORITHMS. The name "cryptocurrency" was give by the supporters and it's inaccurate. None of these so called "cryptocurrencies" are currencies, they are tokens. The name "hashtokens" would have been better.

The people who invented penicillin probably weren't important to healthy people.  The lightning network means Bitcoin can transact faster, more secure, cheaper, and more volume than Mastercard. Let's imagine you are the brightest child of a family in Brazil. They send you to the states for university and to get a job.  If you send money $100 home through Western Union, they take 10%. That's not even a good one.  World wide unconfiscatable. No government can take or freeze your assets. Might be handy if you are a Canadain trucker, or any 3 rd world country.  Blackrock, the world's largest company by asset 40 trillion, they are going hard into bitcoin mining.  JPMorgan tells its weathiest clients to own some Bitcoin. author: Diogo Vitorino
comment: I love your content James but I do think the tittle is misleading and your view very narrow. I agree with most things said during the video about the NFTs you referenced. Yes, bayc and kriptokitties were only hype, no real utility and a way for some people to make some money. But just because a percentage of the crypto potential is used for scams, gambling and nonsense, doesn't automatically make everything else worthless. Crypto is helping people in multiple ways: from helping workers in third world countries to avoid the outrageous remittances fees,  to people in the middle of the Ukrainian and Russian conflict to flee the area and truck drivers in canada to protest within their rights after being locked out of their bank accounts, etc, etc. Summing that up to "crypto is a scam cause there are some degenerates playing around with monkey pictures" is very short sighted. Please don´t take it the wrong way. Big fan here but maybe you could dig a little deeper next time. Cheers.

author: ChillyJack
comment: i think the statement that crypto is a scam is a bit miss leading, decentralized currency (block chain technology) provides many benefits over the modern banking systems. Where the word scam came in was when people started exploiting people's lack of understanding by essentially making arbitrary fiat currencies with soul intent of using influence to inflate it's worth than taking everyones money by dumping it on the market. What isn't a scam though is the introduction of (DECENTRALIZED OPEN SOURCE) currencies that are traded for good services and even other currencies. The major differing factor being that there is no single person that can control the market for currencies such as bitcoin without committing an act of market manipulation which is highly ill-eagle whereas whereas scam coins, are made specifically to have a set group of people, (usually the person behind the coin and/or it's other beneficiary's) that are in control the coin in entirety giving them the ability to dump on the market stealing everyone's money.

author: Momchil Andonov
comment:
All one needs to know is that if something is a 0 sum game it's NOT AN INVESTMENT! You are 99% guaranteed to lose. Even playing with leverage is more profitable for retail customers since it's public knowledge only 75% of traders lose money on margin accounts :). 
If one player makes 1$ million from BTC it automatically means that 1000 other players have lost 1000$ each.

There is value in the case where holding crypto on exchange gives interest rates, BUT it's a major red flag when this same exchange doesn't show it's quarterly financial statements to the public! It's not worth it for a silly 12% p.a.

author: MrGtoriginal
comment: The only reason crypto has been overvalued to the extent that it has is because there's a finite quantity of bitcoins, much like there is a finite quantity of gold or real estate. But the problem with overvaluing crypto based on limited supply is that it's NOT tangible, much like an un-backed national currency, which is why we have interest rates that do their best to control the overvaluation or devaluation of a currency. Crypto has no such mechanism in place, which can easily lead to burst bubbles. People need to stop treating crypto like a commodity and start treating it as nothing more than an alternate means of the transferring of funds.

author: Baba Mama
comment: I agree with a lot of the talking points especially with regards to art NFTs being a big hype bubble but there are 2 key points I'd would argue against in the video. The first one being the problemwith BTC and other coins being inherently a ponzi scheme. The problem with this notion is that the "ponzi" narrative can be projected onto vortually any asset in existance. Gold isnt worth x amount of money because thats its real value, its what people believe its value is worth based on supply and demand. Same goes for other forms of assets like stocks and real estate. The other point of disagreement is with regards to smart contracts. Using peer to peer smart contracts for real world events like trading real estate is technically possible if the judicial system gives said smart contracts the legitmacy. In theory its even better than the system currently in place since its harder to forge documents, removes the need for a third party and doesnt even force you to meet in person. Any contract breach can be easily checked and verified the the digital ownership by said smart contract. And as far as the ticking time bomb goes, Im afraid the big dumpening has already happened. Interest in NFTs has dried out, FUD is at an all time high and the hype has been dead for many months.

author: Peter Cooke
comment: Bitcoin is really 3 big technologies all tied into one. Proof of work, encrypted accounts and peer to peer transactions. The fact that it is completely decentralised and the network is so big and still growing is why it’s so secure and so hard to replicate. Putting a value on this is difficult but there’s no denying the fact that there’s a lot of value there. That’s why we see such big bull markets with a lot of hype and big bear markets. author: eCash Germany - Community Channel
comment:
Just go back to the basics. Crypto*CURRENCY* as described in the Bitcoin Whitepaper is a groundbreaking invention and absolutely an important one with civilization changing potential. 
Just because 99% of "crypto" and "blockchain" projects are now riding on the coat tails of this invention and normies who never cared for this invention until they realized they can "get rich quick" focus on those trashy scams, doesn't mean it is all just a scam.

There are differences between corporate "blockchains", nft tokens, web3 crap that doesn't work or has no purpose - and a real open-source public cryptocurrency that scales for super efficient, viable and instant transactions (and information) across borders without central point of failure in a trustless manner.

It's just that most "supporters" and their critics alike only look at those trashy, shiny BS projects, that labeled themselves crypto (note that currency is missing at this point - this is not a coincidence). And that corporate chains have billions to spend in marketing to get on TV shows. And those crappy NFTs that are so far gone from the original idea of cryptocurrency are banking on serving a nihilistic rich elite class of cokaine- and party addicts or soulless influencers, celebrities and tv stars that have no clue what they gotten into. All that does not make the invention of a trustless public ledger far from being worthless or "a scam"

author: Christoph
comment:
52:29 "We were already seeing very clear-cut use cases, even in those early days people COULD get weather reports, they COULD check the news, they COULD send emails and many other uses that we still use to this day." 

Exactly, people could do that, but not everybody did at that time. Not everyone had the means to do it and by no means has it been adopted worldwide as it is today. 

The comparison is lazy, but it's exactly where we stand with Bitcoin today. People CAN (and do) use it as currency for trades. People CAN (and do) use it as a store of value. Just because not everyone is doing it (yet) doesn't mean it's a failure/scam. 

It's also two vastly different technologies, so trying to compare the same timeline relative to adoption is ludicrous.

author: Ash Nair
comment:
James, your editing skills, and music choices make me feel like I’m watching a YouTube documentary made by David Fincher. 

But I have to say, your choice of language, and bias point of view, like calling Crypto and Web3 fuelled by hype and delusion completely misses what makes it important. The current version of the internet and centralised finance desperately needs an alternative, even if it’s something as nascent as Web3. It is evolving technology and can only get better with time. 

Any kind of centralised structure, especially one that prints money whenever it wants to, is ripe for corruption and can never be a good thing. Web3 and crypto is not a perfect alternative but it’s a necessary alternative as there’s never been any pushback to the current centralisation status quo. Is it perfect? You obviously made some good points, even though the video was a hit piece that lacked journalistic integrity and never highlighted any of the positives with careful consideration. 
It’s pure propaganda that will most likely fool the non critical thinkers. 

Web3 and crypto will evolve, and some regulation is required to reduce overall risks and fraud. But most of the worlds financial fraud takes place within centralised banking institutions anyway. The free printing of money, political kickbacks in the trillions that are funnelled into shady shell corporations and paid to power brokers and politicians to fund proxy wars. Central banks are complicit to way more corruption than your ‘cryptobros’ but none of your videos ever highlight the real problems in the world. The problems that mainstream media doesn’t cover. Yet you attack a rising alternative that is breaking down some of the current power structures, which makes me have some suspicions on the hidden intentions behind this. 

I still commend you / your team, on your editing skills. The ominous background music really adds to the disturbing tone in your messaging. It’s almost too polished. With your skills, I’m surprised you’d rather make YouTube videos attacking grass roots movements like crypto and network marketing companies instead of putting your skills to make documentaries for any of the big streamers. 

Perhaps you could have shared how refugees escaping war torn countries got out of their dire situation with Bitcoin, or how ppl protesting against the government and got their banking facilities shut down survived on crypto donations, or perhaps the most important question of all, what financial alternative do people have to oppose a future social credit society that can shut your ability to buy basic necessities like food? I suppose none of these real world scenarios matter when all we care about are clicks.

author: Sule Man
comment:
I am a cryptocurrency investor. When NFT's were a hype I doubted it thinking it was a pumped hype. I still invest in Cryptocurrency which has a utilitarian user case. Blockchain & Cryptocurrency is here to stay with ever growing global public interest and investment due to the fact that people are free to invest their valuables in what they independently chose. It's a digital asset but hey internet is digital, right? The fact that internet is digital would it lessen it's usercase value? Photos we shoot are digital mostly -not paperprinted. The messages we sent, the contracts we make, the business, government records are digital. What is digital? You never ask this - fundemantal question. Where digital takes its value from? What are its usercase borders, limits? You never ask these fundamental questions which are essential to define the present and increasingly emerging new reality. Blockchain, cryptocurrency is here to stay with increasing user cases and international public interest, investment. The value we attach to Gold and diamonds is subjective in its essence. The fact that blockchain & cryptocurrency is digital does not make it less valuable & dependable than gold or diamonds or government printed paper money. Its "we" who attach the meaning, value to these objects. Who can say or claim that gold or diamond has better usercase than blockchain utility backed cryptocurrency? NFT scammers, cryptocurrency scammers? Sure, they exist and they will exist as much as fake gold, fradulent diamond and paper money scammers exist. Does the fact that there are fake paper money, fake gold, diamond scammers invalidate the monetary system or gold, diamond markets? You need to ask questions again but this time impartially.
NOTE: Cyrptocatch words such as "hodl, wagmi,  early investing, diamond hands" which you criticize are valid investment principles applied and recommended by stock market investors such as multibillionarie Warren Buffet. Didn't you know this? Check your facts.

author: Antonio Lim
comment: As for this electronic decentralized  currency called "Crypto"...remember that it is NOT like regular currency whose value is computed by its ties to actual physical goods in keeping and stored by the nation and institution issuing the currency...Thus the assigned value...this explains the convertion rates. In this "Crypto" system the assigned value of the currency is tied to nothing of accountable physical value thus it is like trading using a peice of collectible memorabilia or art as currency...the value is whatever the beholder/s feels it to be so. The fundamentals of currency systems is is simple...to standardize value so that a certain level in fair echange in goods can be ascertained (even this is not that perfect in regular currency-think agricultural vs tech products exchange)...so think what value does this form of "crypto" add to this kind of environment and what possible ways can it abuse the prevailing system or abuse itself for that matter. Remember that the Darknet used true Crypto-Currency for a very particular purpose and it is not for the regular daily consumption types.

author: Michael Stow
comment:
Anyone describing crypto-currencies as a Ponzi scheme is not understanding how a Ponzi scheme works. A Ponzi scheme has elements not found in crypto-currencies, and crypto-currencies have elements not found in a Ponzi scheme.
People hear words and phrases and use them without taking the trouble to understand them.
I've heard many people describe situations as being "Catch-22" when they're nothing of the sort.
Ditto the word "exponential".
Ditto "order of magnitude"
Ditto "gridlock".
Ditto "penultimate"
and so on.

Sorry to be a smart arse, but I just can't help myself.

author: JB W
comment:
While I agree with you that NFT's are just hugely overpriced JPEGs, Bitcoin is a different argument altogether. It was "intended to be a Currency. However!, it has become a "Store of Value" (Like Gold). Thats's what it is. Digital Gold. All Fiat currency is currently backed by Physical Gold. The world is becoming more and more Digital everyday. Fiat currency is not the answer. Fiat is an Analog Technology for a Digital World. We need a Digital Currency. Perhaps its Ethereum, or some other altcoin, or maybe CBDCs. But whatever the currency of the future is, i guarantee you one thing, it will be "backed" by Bitcoin. Imagine if you were an early adopter of Gold? Wouldn't you hold it as long as you can? 

And by the way, the way you described a ponzi scheme, is literally how all stocks and commodities work. People buy them with the intent to sell them at higher prices. Someone will lose money. Thats how the market works. 

Its crazy that you don't understand how that basic function works.

author: JESSEverything
comment: The term Ponzi Scheme has become a pejorative for something that is a scam.  But the things that people are claiming are a Ponzi scheme, such as Bitcoin, do not meet any of the criteria to actually be a Ponzi Scheme.  Literal Ponzi Schemes are actually fairly rare.  Bitcoin, undboutedly, is not a Ponzi Scheme in the literal sense.  If it were one there is no way that the CME, aka the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, would have listed futures for Bitcoin.  Anyone who I hear screaming that something is a Ponzi is almost always advertising their own ignorance.  Just go and look up the basic definition, read up on the history of the first Ponzi scheme, and learn about the critera that must be in place for something to qualify as being one.

author: Thecat66666 Thecat6666
comment:
You asked what the use case is for crypto, and the only answer I can give you is "illegal content". 
Honestly I feel like the whole investment aspect of crypto is its biggest fundamental flaw. This stuff has the potential to increases security and/or anonymity for users, I mean, that is the whole point of decentralizing stuff. 
When you have a dispute between 2 people, a non-bias 3rd party can help resolve a conflict, like a judge/jury in a court case. But what do you do when the 3rd party has a bias? you get fucked. Decentralization is the attempt to eliminate bias from the 3rd party or to eliminate the 3rd party as a whole. It also protects users from a 3rd party forcibly involving themselves.

Now that is pretty dam cool, but it opens up a whole new can of worms. Illegal activity becomes a whole lot more feasible. And I believe that the blockchain's major flaws have gone and completely overtaken the technology. To be honest, in a future where the block chain is a fundamental technology in humanity, none of this investment nonsense will be a part of it, or if it is, then it will be compartmentalized. 

 while I do believe that some things need a 3rd party due to our inability to predict every possible conflict that may occur, I also wish for the day whare the internet is a little more free and equal than it is now. I believe blockchain technologies is one of the fundamental technologies to achieving that goal. As it is now, it's not even close, and this investment crap is leading the tech astray.

author: Section 7
comment:
Satoshi Nakamoto was CIA and all the crypto "mining" was data processing for the Large Hadron Collider. They knew they would need a massive network and began planning in 98 using new and existing ideas and concepts, such as e-Cash idea from the 80s (or e-Cache in reality). As LHC began experimenting, the data that needed to be resolved was outsourced to the crypto "mining" networks. Easier to pay monkeys to do the work and deal with overheads and maintenance than build the world's biggest most expensive data processing plant. Now quantum computing and soft matter data storage has evolved to the point of replacing worldwide networks into a single room which makes all the monkeys redundant.

Edit: Also, Bernie didn't die - he had already traded the lives of his sons to secure his place after the reset. He spent enough time in "jail" for cover and continued his work in other fields. He was saved by what he knew, but still needed to pay a penalty.

author: Daniel John
comment:
I remember when everyone thought the internet was only for nerds and laughed at the idea of people spending money and buying things through the internet.    Or like when people thought a cell phone capable of taking pictures was just a gimmick because why would anyone want a phone that takes pictures when we already had digital cameras to take pictures.  Most people couldn't see the potential . 
And now we have crypto and just like before people can't or don't want to see the potential of Blockchain.  Just the fact someone can transmit value to anyone virtually anywhere in the world 24/7 in a matter of seconds with a cost of mere pennies per transaction, while also  having the potential to eliminate the use of  central banks and their scam of creating $$ out of nothing, lending it to the people and their govts , charging interest on the loans and then using this ability to manipulate the economy through inflation and control the population with debt and then taking control and amassing huge amounts of physical assets and leaving the general population broke and enslaved to the banks which ensures they continue to maintain control of damn near everything - is huge! 

 a bankster once said "give me control of a nation's money supply and I care not who makes the laws"   
and so here we are being fudded about crypto as a whole by directing the publics attention to and placing the focus mainly on ridiculous NFT art while remaining silent and conveniently ignoring the the very real potential of cryptos ability to free mankind from the control of the banks and our  enslavement to their debt based monetary policy. 

With that said, this FUD video makes me bullish on crypto/Blockchain as a whole.   Be fearful when everyone is greedy and be greedy when everyone is fearful.

author: NoneNoneNone None
comment: Whoah whoah whoah, at 33:20 you are giving misleading information that could not be more incorrect. How do you think images are stored on a database? Your profile picture on Twitter, Facebook, or most other websites is nothing more than a link to somewhere else. Lol. This video completely misses the point of crypto and NFTs. Being able to verify that you own a digital asset is an important technology. Most people can not grasp it yet. Silly pictures were just the first phase of what’s really possible using this technology. The truth is, it’s become the “cool” thing to hate crypto and NFTs. So it’s easy clickbait for videos. Everyone thinks “I knew it was a scam! This shit was so complicated” and they use that as their exit to feel better about themselves. If you do any real research into what crypto or NFTs are, and are able to see past the money madness, only then can you understand the long term commitment to crypto current technology.

author: Arvid Uebelacker
comment:
Crypto will always remain a speculation asset, and "profits" from "investing" in any crypto project will remain just a bottom-up redistribution.
That is unless there will be widespread adoption as something like a legal tender to give it utility. 
In contract, for blockchain there will exist a number of use cases in the future. It just won't be anything close to an investment asset, just the technological properties will prove useful in some environments, e.g. supply-chain management, or things like land register. And applications like these will require regulation. Something that will come anyway and people are even starting to ask for it. 

2021/2022 was a bullshit mania. Ah, and simply looking professional does not legitimize a crypto project, nor give it economic viability.

author: bspus
comment:
There is a lot of truth in your film. Most of the media coverage, even within the crypto scene is indeed about scammy projects or far fetched ideas that are doomed to fail.
However I still see a lot of value in bitcoin specifically. Not as digital cash but as digital gold. There is a large percentage of people in crypto (mostly called bitcoin maximalists) who see this as the main use case for bitcoin and consciously choose to separate themselves from the rest of the crypto space. In fact it is a glaring omission that you didn't mention this whether you agree with this position or not.
There is also the case of layer 2 solutions like the lightning network which could address scaling and fees issues to a point where it could be worth reconsidering the use case of payments sometime in the future. But we are certainly not there yet. Regardless, it would also have been worth mentioning.
Those are the very things that fly over the head of most crypto new comers. They find this stuff boring when indeed that is the true innovation. A potential worldwide settlement layer that is decentralized and fully digital. But no, people want to hear about get rich quick ponzi schemes implemented with a blockchain. Sad... but I consider the "revolution" far from over.

author: Pichseth Sothy
comment: James, that’s a great demonstration in your video but man is investing in crypto more than just getting rich. People usually have this tendency to see things as black and white, meaning that it’s either crypto going to become a global currency and people abolish current money system or crypto will fail and no one’s gonna use it. The reality is that it is a revolutionary technology, so its useful case is going to blend with current money system in some ways or another. I don’t believe that people are decent to use money without any regulations the same way as I don’t believe government should have too much power on people’s personal money. The fact that cryptocurrency creates an alternative is powerful enough to inspire people to find ways to utilize what we do better to improve current money system.

author: Lloyd Diliz
comment: I'm a reasonable believer of the potential of the cryto technology and skeptic at the same time. I don't see it as a get rich quick scheme in anyway. I was genuinely interested to see what I could learn from this hour long video but all you did is make a list of scams that were run on the back of the hype that goes around the cryptosphere, with dramatic music and effects. Your case for how it is a giant Ponzi if barely backed by evidence. The main piece of the video revolves around nft which, of course, just like the art market, is a highly manipulated market. Nothing new. Of course there is a bubble of overinflated prices because there is a hype and scammers will jump on the opportunity. There is a lot of naive reasoning like the comparison between a smart contract and legal contract. Of course its different and the saying "code is law" doesn't actually suggest that (I won't elaborate. DYOR if you want to understand what is actually meant by that). Granted, you do a good job at making a compilation of various dodgy characters and scams (which have already been called by others like coffeezilla) and dissecting some of the more toxic traits of the cryptosphere culture but on the whole, there aren't many of your claims that actually backed by much more than anecdotal evidence, if at all. That doesn't make for a strong case supporting the big claim of the title. It just sound like those conspiracy theory documentaries. There is an interesting theory that is proposed but it's very weakly backed. In the end, for all I know, you might be right but if you are, it will merely be by luck. I call it clickbait.

author: test uploads
comment: This video should be titled, the great bitcoin scam. Because most of it is specific to bitcoin. There are multiple cryptos out there now that have real world usage. HBAR is used by international airlines to run their payroll systems using smart contracts. BAT is earned by spending time on websites and can be sent to websites you enjoy browsing as a way to tip them for their work. ADA is already used across the African continent to pay for mobile phone services to reduce the cost of owning a phone for people with little money. ATOM is being used in democratic voting systems to make voting transparent and more secure. It's easy to pick crypto scams and say look here's some scams, therefore it's all a scam. It's no different to any growing industry, scammers see an opportunity and the industry becomes temporarily flooded with them until regulators step in and make it so scammers can be punished

author: Bradvani
comment:
It’s so tragic that Bitcoin’s name, image and reputation gets intermingled with everything negative that happens in the decentralised web. There are over 1000 blockchains with all kinds of consensus mechanisms that are all trying to compete with each other. The collapse of Luna, FTX and now the Genesis-DCG dispute are all outside of Bitcoins core ethics and values - few get this. 

The value is only driven into them by the communities that use and believe in this revolutionary technology and frequent them for means of trade, finance, savings, social validation and building.

Every cycle features a new breed of trends that ultimately always collapse after a mega atomic bull cycle.
