author: MightyJabroni
comment:
I am glad that a guy with your reach calls it as it is. I have been saying this for years: Bitcoin may have been an honest attempt. But it was more like an honest mistake. The incentive structure of a deflationary asset cannot and will not create anything, that can be used as money at any meaningful scale. And incentives create outcomes. This thing ran the exact course it was always destined to.

And blockchain is nothing but a Merkle tree. A cryptography finger exercise that has existed since the 70's and that has severely limited application, because it scales poorly and it's irreversibility makes it almost wholly useless for most real world use cases. It remains the amazing solution for almost nothing. That is also why all the talk about crypto being oh so “revolutionary”, “the future”, this, that and the other is incredibly low-brow.

author: Daresto8
comment:
It's important to recognize that the US dollar, like many other fiat currencies, is not backed by a physical commodity such as gold. Instead, it is backed by the full faith and credit of the US government, which has the ability to issue new currency as needed. This means that the value of the US dollar is subject to fluctuations based on a range of factors such as inflation, market demand, and economic conditions.

In contrast, cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin are decentralized, meaning they are not controlled by any single organization or government. This decentralization can provide some benefits, such as increased transparency and reduced potential for manipulation or interference. Decentralization also means that no single entity has the ability to issue new currency or to control the supply of the currency, which can help to maintain the value of the currency over time.

Overall, while both fiat currencies and cryptocurrencies have their own set of drawbacks and risks, it's important to consider the potential benefits of decentralization and to make informed decisions about where to keep your money.

author: Not A Retail 212 Male
comment:
Crypto isn't a scam, it's just that many of you simple refuse to do ANY kind of research before you jump head first into a sector where you clearly have no understanding of what is going on. 

I'm sure many of you will disagree, but the reality is when you look at what projects have failed, ask yourself this; why exactly are people jumping into these "new" projects, schemes, lending ideas, blah blah blah when there is realistically only ONE coin you should be considering.

And what is this "coin" you might ask? It's not Litecoin, it's not Ethereum, it's BITCOIN. NOT ridiculous "defi" schemes, not projects backed by shady VC's, not exchanges ran by a person who is the second largest donor to the democrat party, not meme coins, not NFT's ( how anyone fell for buying pixel at is beyond me), I could go on and on.

If you are reading this and you have lost money in the last year, YOU lost because you became greedy and chose to chase after shady projects to make a quick gain, not because crypto is a scam. I know this because I have been in this space for a very long time, in the good and bad times, and the people who always complain in the bad times are ALWAYS the people who make the WORSE DECISIONS.

ONLY buy Bitcoin. When you buy Bitcoin, keep it on your OWN personal wallet, NOT on an exchange. If more of you focussed on the only coin that makes sense, maybe you would make some money instead of losing your entire life saving.

And before anyone tells me you can't possibly buy Bitcoin, it's too random, you never know when to buy, blah blah blah, watch this: When Bitcoin crashed from 20K the first time, why did it crash? When the ETF launched, right? So when Bitcoin crashed AGAIN from the 65 - 70K range, what launched? Oh wait that's right yet another ETF yet so many of you are soo blinded by greed that you missed the key selling signal.

I could honestly go on and on but if you have made it this far, hopefully you get the point. Stop calling everything a scam, do your research and you will be this fine, and to be honest ( and this is my personal opinion ), I am glad all of these things have happened so you people can finally focus on Bitcoin instead of fluff.

author: Neehize
comment:
Crypto is neither a "scam" nor "the next big thing". At its core, the blockchain is just a technology that can be leveraged to build decentralised entities like banks or authorities. The people who bought BTC from 2009 to 2015 understood this and invested in it for what it really was.

It all started to go haywire around 2017-2018 when people started to realize they could use crypto as an investment asset. These people either completely ignored what crypto real was (FOMO) or speculated about what it could become in the next few years. As a result, tons of money got poured into crypto, and obviously, where there is money there are scams and there were indeed quite lot of scams in crypto.

Just like with any stock exchange, some people got rich, some people got poor, but in the end no value was created. What's more, most people still have no idea what crypto is. The people who call crypto a scam are either the same people that blindly invested in it or the people that think the people who invest are being controlled by a higher entity.

From my point of view, the core of the problem is that we (the people) need to do better when it comes to investing our money. Educating people on how to invest would let them take their responsibility and stop crying when they lose their money or screaming "scam" to anything they invested in that didn't work. Again, crypto in itself is not a scam but yes, there are a lot of scams in the mix.

Personally, I never invested in crypto and I still think it's well overrated for what it really is today, especially BTC who is a dinosaur crypto that doesn't scale at all and that isn't even worth $1 in my mind. If fiat banks were to collapse I would rather buy gold. But who knows, maybe in the future I will buy crypto instead.

Anyway, thank you if you read my boring opinion and remember: it's never always black and white!

author: Anon Anon
comment: I never post as I am anonymous but thanks if you read: I think your looking at it wrong and underestimate the time it takes for adoption. Google the history of the internet. It started in the late 1970's and only took off in early 2000's. Take a step back and look at real good projects such as Cardano-Ada. A good project should incorporates Governance,  Decentralization, Scaling and Smart Contracts/Communication. Most, if not all the projects you mentioned lacked all of these. I find it troubling how a majority of your video focused on NFT's when to a real Blockchain enthusiast, NFT's are droplets in an ocean. author: Dinos
comment:
Pyramid schemes. A story as old as the sun. The cryptos remind us of just any other banking/investing pyramid scheme. The NFTs remind us of the... Dutch tulips! If anyone knows the history of the Dutch tulips he understands : the tulip was not a Dutch flower originally. The flower itself comes from Minor Asia (the region of modern-day Turkey). So, back in the Ottoman era, in the mid-1600s, a Jewish merchant who traded between the Ottoman Empire and the Dutch state and who also served as a diplomat, he saw tulips and loved the flower. So he brought some back to Netherlands to impress people. People loved the flower so much that a whole trade was set to import tulips from the Ottoman Empire. Since cultivation of tulips had not yet set in the Netherlands as the plant has to be accustomed to the northern weather and humid soil, there were so few tulips that their price was exorbitant. Which, as one now would expect, attracted investors who started investing in... tulips! Mind you, we don't mean "tulip futures", they were literally investing in tulips, the very flowers. How long does a tulip live? If you cut it, how long does it live fresh? Well... people were diving in and buying tulips like crazy. This was the 1600s, and the Netherlands had recently become the richest part of Europe after Venitian (very often of Jewish ancestry) bankers had moved there from Venice -  they were divesting from Venice and investing in the North, namely in the Dutch and British East/West India Companies (the very reason why you keep seeing translations of Venitian names and Venitian-inspired flags). So people, surfing on the affluence and promise of an even wealthier future were diving in to invest. There was the case of a rich widow who during a dinner ended up buying a single tulip at the price of a new house!!! All that just before the ponzi scheme collapsed.... the price of tulips dropped ot the bottom of the sea as soon as people realised what a pyramid scheme it was and everyone woke up from the smoke and fumes of the tulip crazy, realising that it is just an effing flower, not gold or silver or copper. 

Honestly, I believe the NFTs to be an even more ridiculous ponzi scheme than the tulip.

author: Jarrett Swisher
comment:
It’s important to understand how everything explained in this video, also happens in real life. 

Based off the ability to get a loan at such a young age, college is a scam. 

Based off the ability to buy a house you can’t afford, the housing market is a scam.

Based off the inability to access all the money you have, the banking system is a scam. 

Every idea that is ever created could be considered a scam, because realistically, there’s always winners and losers.

Now is there scamming in the crypto world? 100%

Is there scamming in the real world? 100% 

That doesn’t mean there aren’t good companies and good people in the crypto world that are trying to actually change the world, and help to evenly distribute wealth in some way. 

The idea still needs work, but everyday there’s more good people jumping aboard to help make this idea succeed.

Great video btw.

author: Mojitotech
comment:
I beg to differ. 

Bitcoin, given its deflationary and limited supply mining characteristics, is actually a transactional commodity. Think of it as a form of intangible and easily accessible digital gold where the price of a bitcoin is actually based on basic economic demand and supply principle. 

Yes, I do agree that majority, >90% of the cryptocurrencies have no legitimate use case and they are more of a money grab. However, there are still valid use cases to some of the projects. 

As for NFT(s), indeed there was a hype surrounding it and the hype has probably died down. But, you gotta realise how NFT has transformed the art world in terms of verifying and validating the authenticity and ownership in just a matter of a couple of clicks. The use case is still strong and I do believe that NFTs are here to stay and could even extent beyond arts for e.g. National Identity verification, Mortgage ownership etc.

What this space and industry TRULY Needs is clear and tight regulations surrounding the creation, promotion and custodian of cryptocurrencies. I firmly believe that regulations will bring greater clarity and protection for all stakeholders in this space and will act a form of deterrence against bad actors. 

If crypto is a total sham like you said, which I highly doubt so given that various high net worth individuals, banks, boutique firms, sovereign wealth funds are investing millions and millions dollars into the development of the space and crypto related products.  I highly doubt they will pour millions to billions of dollars into something that doesn't provide a decent ROI.

author: Timothy Swan
comment:
I was a studied computer scientist who understood algorithms when I read them before bitcoin was released.

When I finally saw how cryptos worked, I immediately knew "oh yeah, it works just ike Star Wars credits" and was happy to see that a legit currency (instead of fiat) was finally made.

Then I loved how NFTs could prove you had a file at a particular time (to show a contract or an invention).

When people starting buying cryptos on centralized exchanges and claiming that NFTs are scams because they were minting images (you can change an image slightly and it will have a different NFT) in order to "trade" ownership of said image, I figured these were just a few people who didn't know what they were doing. Duh, of course if you treat a currency as only an investment and not actually use it for its purpose: to trade, it is the same as if I made an "Empty Company, Inc" and had stocks invested into it.

Now people think crypto itself is a scam? LOL It's just a legitimate data structure and the only reason it took off as a currency is because the data structure works so well it actually functions better on its own than if a bank or company were trying to emulate it. Crypto itself is no scam. It's completely surrounded and veiled with scams and social insanity just like gold and oil was. That doesn't mean that gold and oil are scams, it just shows how legit they were as the "things" they were.

Sorry, but if this documentary is what I suspect it is, it's just a foot in your mouth.

author: JurnellGaming
comment:
I watched many of your vids and I usually love the work you do but this one here wasn't fair and just. 

Associating NFTs and NFT scams to Bitcoin is unfair of you. Your aim seems to be to defame bitcoin and the amazing blockchain projects out there.  Associating criminal activities to crypto when ciminal activites also are done using fiat isn't a good argument to make. Crypto has saved many countries around the world finantially and many ppl still use it today as a store of value and to send to their family and friends, especially in non first world countries. 

There are amzing things being build on the blockchain. Pointing out scam projects makes no sense cause scammers are everywhere and in every industry.

-Many mining rigs are using renuable energy sources rn and many crypto projects don't even rely on mining. 
-The production and use of fiat uses extream amounts of resources, including energy.
-Money that can be printed out of thin air isn't as valuable as something that is finite, cannon be controlled and you can see a history of all transactions. 
-The value of the dollar has gone down and is continuing to go down. Bitcoing from 2009 to today is up and will continue to rise for a pretty long time

Anyway, everyone is freee to believe and do what they think is best. I'll belive in Bitcoin and continue to use crypto.

author: wugy07
comment:
Crypto currencies are a revolution in the sense that we can actually create a commodity based currency that is entirely bound by energy consumption. This is truly the revolution that Friedrich Hayek envisioned, a commodity based currency that is backed by something more valuable than gold.

However every revolutionary idea gets initially manic by the charlatans, until the idea is allowed to permeate the minds of the stoics.

Cryptos are a revolutionary idea, but what we currently have, is a free for all by people that don't understand how to earn a modest living.

That will change, as Hayek's work is still to this day, way ahead of its time. Peace through trade? We're not there yet when we have a government that profits from war.

author: sunilshah-cape-town
comment:
'There are more examples of bubbles and crashes that lead to vast value, none more so than the Dotcom boom and crash.'

I find it so amusing when crypto fans broadcast booms/busts in equity markets as a justification for similar events in crypto.

You don't seem to see the boom/busy in equity was grounded on wildly bullish/ bearish assumptions about :TAM, forward earnings/prospects discount rates etc of the entity, to arrive at the (dynamic) underlying intrinsic value of the equity.
Whereas what's the intrinsic value of bitcoin? 
Zero, that's the underlying extra utility of bitcoin vs an alternative payment medium .  

The price is predicated PURELY on the greater fool who's willing to pay more for it.

Did you see the difference?

author: Rens Tillmann
comment: It doesn't change the technology. All these people just invested money without knowing how things work. They put lots of money on central platforms. Then you just really have no clue what you are doing. The point is to be decentralized. Even though it might not be 100% possible. It's meant to be as close as possible. There are a lot of cool things being worked on. This is all part of the growing pain. People will learn. Just like people still learn about scams on the regular internet like phishing emails and what not. There are always scams no matter what or where. But at least YOU are the one in FULL control over your "money". The thing with blockchains are that they require a "token" to function. What it's use case might be depends. And as an example it might even change (Bitcoin for example). Also there are always different types of people. Some are afraid to take risks, some take to much and might be careless. But that's ok. It's your own life, you decide your next moves. As a passionate developer I do not even follow the news to much about blockchain/crypto space. I only follow three projects, one being very closely. I am not going to name them here. I know how that ends up in pointless endless "discussions". I do me, you do you. It's a "free" world depending on your geo location. Me myself, I just look at the tech and what I believe to be valuable for/from a developers point of view. And with value I am not referring to money wise. I didn't like NFT's, never will. Some others will. And that's ok. You are at least free to do with your money as you wish, without anybody monitoring/knowing it. Is that worth anything to you? This again depends on you as a person. It's never as black and white. As long as you are passionate about whatever it is you are passionate about, you will be happy. And the rest is just a nice +1 to your life. Good luck to all in 2023 and may your wishes come true! 🥂

author: Martin Sparkes
comment:
At 9:50 you undo all your good work. Bit coin is not deflationarry - it si a finite resource so that you can't print more - that does not make it deflationary. 

Inflation is an increase of the money supply
Deflation is a decrease of the money supply

Bit coin is neither - it can not increase or decrease as there are only a finite number of them. 

SO it does fulfill the function of money in that it is a medium of exchange and as store of value.

Here is a list of problems that blockchain technology has the potential to solve:

Double spending

Fraud

Lack of trust

Middlemen

Centralization

Lack of transparency

Inefficient processes

High transaction costs

Long transaction times

Lack of security for transactions

Lack of ownership records for digital assets

Difficulty in verifying identity

Lack of interoperability between different systems

Difficulty in enforcing contracts

Inability to easily transfer ownership of assets.

author: James Robertson
comment:
9:38 just to answer this one question for anybody interested: Bitcoin is still inflationary as long as more coins are being produced. This will continue every 10 mins until some point in the mid-22nd century. So technically it is incorrect to call it a deflationary asset for now. 

More generally, I think there is a case for saving your money in deflationary assets. Many countries have been victims of aggressive inflation in recent years, and this is, according to some, the result of irresponsible practices by central banks. Printing money and dumping it into the supply. 

Bitcoin offers an alternative with no central bankers, and no currency debasement. I agree that there are plenty of scams in crypto, but the one great (and unique) thing that Bitcoin has going for it is that it cannot be debased.

author: Romar Boer
comment:
Although I agree with a lot of your points, you seem to want to sketch the entire space in a negative light. Which is the exact same thing as an influencer trying to get you to buy an ape through hype.

I’ve been in the space since 2020. And it has changed my life for the better. As artist I was unable to make a proper living or execute my own visions. Nfts made it possible for me to create a world that is new and interesting. It allowed me to be creative in different ways. And connect to all kinds of people. Value = subjective . It’s a belief at its core. And that’s exactly what you see happening all the time. Folks invest because of hype, then get rugged. But that’s the thing, in a decentralised space you are responsible for what you do. You alone confirm the transaction. It’s an unfortunate truth there are bad actors out there, that abuse your optimism and make false claims. But the opposite is also true. Value can be created, through many different factors. The internet has value because it allows you to communicate directly to one another. At least that was its first use case. These days you can do countless things. Blockchain is one of them. Sending money in seconds to any part in the world is huge. And the fact that if you wanted to, hold complete power over that virtual cash is huge. That’s a big undecided.  Because money is power. Trusting the current financial institution is like trusting a pyromaniac to stop a fire. An institutions first and foremost purpose is to stay alive. And it can only do so by harbouring the interests that keep it in power. What happens if you want to take out 50k in cash? That’s not possible. Why is your wealth on a bank account any different then that on the blockchain? Belief. 

You might not see the value. Especially after this crazy period. But you can argue this for everything. Cryptos true value is the ability to iterate through this communal effort. It’s allowing individuals like myself to have a voice and set a different example. It’s a space that still has a lot of growing to do. And I personally think it will.

For me there are a lot of moments where I am like, why is this not on the blockchain? For example, government spending, apps from the AppStore, in-game items, community proposals , mortgages funded by a community rather than big banks, supply chain tracking, and of course art. And I reckon as the digital world takes us over more and more. Wouldn’t it be great if we had a decentralised foundation to make sure that this digital world we interact in is actually our own? 

That said, great documentary. To be honest it made me feel not so great as my entire livelihood depends on this industry. And quite literally pays my rent and bread. As artist there is not that many opportunities. The starving artist stereotype is real. And the idea of going back to that is quite honestly terrifying. So I hope nfts , web3, crypto keeps growing, innovating and finds ways to get rid of these bad actors. So that we can actually enjoy the decentralised nature and beauty of this digital landscape. 

Cheers

author: Allison Hart
comment:
it's really sad, because the broader idea of a decentralized currency that could bypass, for example, bank's transaction fees and processing times, in order to very quickly send money back to your family living in a 3rd world country, for example, is awesome. the idea of an entire population going around their corrupt or defunct government by having a viable global currency to use instead IS cool as hell, especially if that currency were actually stable.

obviously that is NOT crypto. but even in Satoshi Nakamoto's vision and white paper back from 2007, you can see that – as a broad concept, libertarian in the true sense and not far-right sense – it was supposed to just be a decentralized, "free" P2P monetary system.

i wish people would talk about this more because even if the idea itself wouldn't work, talking about the problems and solutions created and solved by such a thing is important.

author: Maycon Cruz
comment:
You know, that part where it says "NFTs are a solution in search of a problem" isn't entirely true. If you look at it coldly, the whole concept of crypto is basically trying to convince you that there is a problem, and that problem would be called "we don't have enough monetizable stuff to speculate on". And that comes to light when you better understand what Web 3.0 proposes.

Broadly speaking, Web 3.0 is a concept that says the next step for the internet is to be an integral part of real life. Your everyday life is always connected, your possessions are always connected and most importantly... the economy is always connected. It would be a kind of "Schrödinger's Virtual Reality", where everything is both tangible and real, but also has a virtual presence. And if you recall, there is one more technology that many companies were trying to push as the next evolutionary step for society: metaverse.

Basically, all this effort is primarily aimed at overthrowing the importance we give to the tangibility of things, so that we can migrate this to a virtual environment. As the video itself exemplified, not only money could be assigned to a blockchain, but also real estate, contracts, patents, diplomas... Everything from goods to monkey JPEGs would have a blockchain, and everything could be traded and monetized. 

And this is how, my friends, a cyberpunk dystopian future begins, more specifically Ernest Cline's Ready Player One, where everything revolves around a game along the lines of a metaverse where people live, study work and consume using it as an intermediary made of blockchains...

An intermediary where men in suits would be free to monetize every aspect of our lives and control who should get rich and who should settle for being just another cog in their system, thus defining the sizes of the slices of the great pie of hyperconsumerism.

author: BWAProject
comment:
XRP and XLM can transfer value anywhere in the world in 3 seconds. Traditional correspondent banking takes 1-3 days. 
XRP and XLM can transfer value anywehre in the world for $0.0001. Traditional correspondent banking charges anywhere between 25-250 basis points. 
XRP and XLM remove the need for pre-funding, a requirment in traditional correspondent banking (for liquidity/collateral/trust), freeing up trillions of dollars of dormant capital. 
XRP and XLM can source liquidity using native infrastructure. 
XRP and XLM are hugely scalable at 1500 tps min, and use next to no energy. 

Go and look at the companies Ripple or Stellar, and how much headway thet are making in the cross border payment space. They are the literal definition of utility and a disrupter of incumbent technology. 

I agree that most chains/tokens are silly, hyped up garbage, but some have actual utility.

author: Iangamebr
comment:
This is one of the worst videos on the topic that I saw. Instead of talking about the technology, you just jumped between examples of scams and fraud like it's the absolute truth and the only thing possible to happened inside blockchain. Not only that but every minute or so you talked about something that straight up wasn't true or it is the omission in some aspect of what happened or it's just said in a very contrived way to reach a point/conclusion that you laid out for yourself beforehand. 
The internet in a great deal is used for porn and scams and it's already more than 3 decades old, does that mean internet is bad? Obviously not. At the same token crypto only being a decade old and it been directly tied to the financial system it has scams and fraud, does it make inherently bad? Obviously not. 
So crypto doesn't have any actual use? Yeah go talk to all the people in Venezuela, Sri Lanka or countries in Africa that would literally be dead by starvation if not for the crypto that they use daily for making transactions, saving lives for me is a valid use. Crypto is as scalable and as secure as it can get, much more than any other system in reality right now, that's why there's layer 2 and layer 3 solutions for scalability and thousand upon thousands of transactions per second is a thing. 
The malpractice of this piece of content it's either misinformation by lack of research, straight up disinformation by malice of the creator or mitigated research that looks to confirm a bias that the creator already had, while ignoring all the obvious counter points that the piece of content laid out.

author: PerfectPencil
comment: I've been yelling this shit as loud as I could to everyone I know since before bitcoin broke $1000. It has ALWAYS failed at the single most important part of its very premise... being a CURRENCY. The single most important thing for a currency to have is STABILITY. For bitcoin to actually be a currency, it should NEVER "go to the moon" it should ALWAYS be stable. Who wants to go to work getting paid in a currency that could drop in value to be utterly worthless right as you cash your paycheck, and then spike up right after you buy your weekly groceries? That's absolute insanity. This shit was ALWAYS a ponzi scheme. One of my best friends had a retort i think most people agree with "who cares if its a scam and as long as i cash out before it crashes?". And honestly, thats how we all got here. People deep down know what all of this is... a game of hot potato.

comment:
32:16 I minted apes and NOBODY promised me any money. I just liked the community. I understand NFTs though and coukd instantly see the value. None of us knew of the airdrops to come and the mutants at the time. Celebs were late to the game.
Of course people wanted in but didn’t know to handle crypto. Moon Pay is an easy way for new people to buy who has no prior experience in crypto. The dinosaur banks don’t know. Though the banks use blockchain and buys tons of ethereum. They’re building on it. Yet no media talked about it because they want the prices to remain low until, they are finished buying as much as they need.
We who bought NFTs early were inundated by people who wanted to buy cryoto and NfTs. Moo lay was an easy way at the time. Since then, coinbase has a NFT platforms.

Whilst you’re at it, You should have covered how the stock market is run as well.. talk about insider trading and shorting perfectly great Americans companies (greed, grifters)…
 
I wasn’t wrong when I believed in some of the NfTs.  Celebrities joined a year later…  I still believe in HfTs as it’s a mind blowing technology that will so,be a LOT of issues we can’t in todays system. 

Btw, Why don’t you show the full tweets and other tweets?
And you put real grifter  Ryder Ripps in this documentary? It’s such a one sided coverage, so anyone reading this, please do more research.
Talk about the biggest grifter of all, fooling ignorant NEW people to buy his new NFTs. He just copied the apes and minted a new Bored Ape collection (not verified obviously, using copyrighted art). His NFts are now worth nothing, but he managed to fool many newbies.
We tried to warn the newbies constantly about that guy.  
He’s being sued by the Bored Apes for copyright breach and defamation.  Where’s that news of him ripping off new people??

Why aren’t you calling him a grifter? And a thief, stealing other artists work??? after him? 
Yet no mention of that? Hmm…
Have to say your coverage so far is very anti NFTs , that it seems that your aim is to steer as many new peo9e away from crypto and NFTs as possible.

This is internet web 3. Imagine if we weren’t allowed to participate and use internet! That’s madness to even think of today, when folks understand what it is. But they didn’t understand it 20 years ago.. Same story then. It was all a fraud, ponzi..
The governments wanted to ban it! Where would we be ? We would be third world countries.

This is the new 1990s in tech on steroids..
Where there’s money, there will always be criminals. 

Get onboard or get left far behind.

author: vonSmash
comment:
Look, you might be correct that crypto has no future in the real world but this isn’t the proof to say it won’t.  It’s extremely slanted and does not give a full picture of crypto and blockchain.

I can’t tell you if we all will be using the blockchain 10 years from now but pretty much all of the points and views you bring up here can be done the same way for companies and the stock market as well. 
There will always be scams, there will always be people
 who see opportunity to make a quick buck and swindle others, it has happened throughout human history and it will likely to continue, but that doesn’t automatically tell you that the systems that these schemes are built on are themselves part of the scheme and destined to fail.

So I would love to see maybe a follow up or remake in the future that tells a much much wider story and not only focuses on the scams and people who manipulate the infrastructure.

author: Nikolay
comment:
Brilliant work.
I'm also grateful that you didn't dismiss the earlier bitcoin community, because even though people who joined pre-2013 might have seen the most profit, we were also the least profit-oriented wave of cryptocurrency enthusiasts.
The shady individuals that took over the space in 2017 do not represent our initial ideals. Even when the space was taken over by grifters, the ICO mania still managed to provide a lot of utility, something that you seem to dismiss because of the noise that the scams generated in the meantime.
But we now have:

- The beginnings of a global computer
- Smart contracts that ABSOLUTELY can replace some traditional ones (emphasis on SOME, and the fact that this does not require a new crypto token)
- Systems designed to tell between truth and lies coming from an outside (non-crypto) source that could greatly enhance said smart contracts
- New consensus algorithms that genuinely provide a huge breakthrough for cryptocurrencies, with instant finality and low power consumption, without sacrificing decentralisation and censorship resistance
- The most downloaded app for the past 3 years in Venezuela which saved millions from poverty, while also working on a network that should reinvent money (using non-crypto assets as backing) to provide inflation resistance for the middle class
- A web browser that protects its users from a significantly darker and more malicious world of online advertising networks than the low-level crypto grifting influencer crap that you've exposed here
- A significantly more convenient to use version of the US dollar
- And a few reinventions of traditional financial institutions on top of a blockchain, that provide legitimate improvements over their centralised counterparts and which I actually use on a daily basis

And plenty more projects of actual use. I'd argue that the NFT craze was the first crypto cycle that provided nothing but scams. There have been other cycles, in which to an outsider it does appear that everything is a scam, but that absolutely wasn't the case. Value was being created, from which money was being made, which did attract influencers and grifters wanting a share of the pie, who then took over all the social media and communication channels. But hidden in the corner, the value creation process was still there, it just wasn't given attention because it didn't promise riches for no work.

Last but not least, darker times appear to lie ahead. Cryptocurrency can provide censorship resistance and protection against malicious government actors and dystopian political regimes - the very first reason for its existence. IMO it is naive to think they will not be of use in the future, even though we're all hoping that things will not turn as dark as some of the predictions. But it wasn't long ago when a journalist who dared to expose those in power had his ability to bank stripped away, only to be saved by bitcoin.

author: Drunk Ancestor
comment:
The comparison to legal contracts is interesting and I think you didn't spend enough time on that...

Here's the thing.

Any artist can create an artwork and then make a legal contract that says that they get X% of any secondary sale. That's very true and in that one specific way the contract is similar to a smart contract...

But the reality is that only already wealthy big name artists can afford the lawyers required to chase down and enforce that contract.

Smart contracts did enable a whole new generation of artists to make a living and collect royalties in a way that was always owed to them *legally*, but smart contracts was the first time they could actually enforce those royalties in a meaningful way.

So for many artists code really is law because the "law" has so far been meaningless for the little guy.

author: veritas liberabit vos
comment:
Block chain and smart contracts have business cases - having something like ETH which is used to pay the services that verify the blockchain record being committed or doing other work for contract execution is a good way to do things (user pays environment). This is basically what other currencies (Dollar, etc. do) - it is the legal form of exchange within a country (Allows the government to control commerce within their country and collect taxes, etc.). To imply all are MLM or other scams is incorrect. Bitcoin was developed as proof of concept for digital currency and solving the double spend / entry problem by having validators verify the records and have consensus to accept the work in the blockchain history.

NFTs - Sure I would agree they are worthless and that this is just people gambling with their money. And yes people can make a copy of the picture or the database that holds the picture could go offline - thus you have no access to what you paid for. Yet the underlying idea of property ownership and having that validated and verify by an impartial and distributed system is a great idea. It means governments cannot stop people from transacting on their property, which they can do by putting you on naughty lists with banks. There is still the issue with onboarding / off-boarding money from the blockchain through exchanges.

And yes, most of the thousands of cryptos will fail and be worthless. This has happened throughout history of new technologies coming to light and failing and just a few surviving to dominate till something else takes over by offering a better solution. That is what is happening here and there are people who have coming in with the intention of just making money (Many through NFTs and some through crypto and rug pulls and other ways) some cryptos fail due to the project being a bad idea and like a company failed in the market (You think all venture capitalist investments win, not even close, most fail. It's the few that do win they win big and deserve the big returns in taking the risk and hits for all those that fail.)

Governments and regulators need to come in and put laws in place to provide more protections. You will see in the coming decades national currencies going digital. Saves on a lot of resources being wasted (paper / plastic production and disposal, printing presses, security and transport and storage) these all have costs and digital may help to reduce these. And that is what a market economy is about, allowing the market to determine what is the best solution for now.

Notice in all this I'm not talking about making money, I'm talking about solving problems and introducing features / products we may learn to improve our lives (like iPhone did over the old Nokia flip phones). The issues with counterparty risks (who owns the wallet / crypto - like exchanges being a bank where funds are pooled to having your own wallet and you manage the risks - how can this be made more safe / secure / user friendly / protections, etc.)

Blockchain is not just used for crypto, Oracle has been looking at it for database transactions.

This is bigger than what this video is about. This video, rightly, points out the shit fuckery that a lot of people get up to when it is hard to hold them accountable and a lot of people with little knowledge can make really stupid decisions that impact them for life.

author: mariopot789
comment:
This is such an excellent video , having worked on an indie game during the entire wave of this crypto maniaput me into close proximity to so much of this and it's excellent to see a complete narrative tying all of it together. 

From when crypto Kitties burst on the scene t and there was a curious optimism to seeing the surge of NFT " art" projects where friends of mine had there art and music mercilessly stolen and repackaged by people organizations they had no clue about to me recalling having meetings with publishers who told me I needed to convert my VR game into a Metaverse NFT project along the lines of Axie Infinity if I REALLY wanted to make some money. I recall an interview where a guy mentioned halfway throug hthe project was an NFT game project because clearly the studio was getting rejected left and right by talented devs hwo wanted nothing to do with them.

However I  also had friends who abandoned traditional game studios to work on Crypto projects, I watched as other indies tied their boats to crypto because merely mentioning crypto in a pitch deck guaranteed you money, I think of situations like Ubisoft trying to do a quick NFT cash grab that I think had triple digit numbers of users  for Ghost Recon Breakpoint  , I sat on panels where people asked me questiosn with wide eyes about the value of NFT's for games which I  had to reverse and ask Do any of us REALLY want to turn our game experiences into a constant day job ? 

The craziest part  though is at every step of the way simple questions.. the MOST BASIC questions about why NFT's and Crypto pervading games and other technology spaces was a good thing was met with the MOST INTENSE denial I've ever seen without addressing any concerns .   

It wasn't just normal fanboyism people connected their lives, hopes, and dreams to something they barely understood . Truly a mania and so well documented here this took me for a ride as someone who just kept watching the NFT castle being built and second guessing myself if it truly was a nothing burger wrapped in shiny buzzwords or if somehow I was overlooking the biggest opportunity of my life and missing a key detail.

It's been fascinating to be so close and yet on the outer fringes of a bubble pervading my industry .  I feel like I could have dove into the crypto space at anytime but it never felt like anything but empty promises and hype to me definitely an example of trusting my gut because if I followed my greed or the people I knew swayed by greed i'd be in a really hard place right now.

author: JayTrades
comment: All you did was call out everything in crypto that was doing crypto wrong. Bitcoin sucks as a store of value because of its scalability problems, yes! But other currencys are solving this problem. You spoke about garbage made on the ethereum network, but no about ethereum itself being used as a store of value. The idea of crypto that actually has held its own and gets stronger every cycle is decentralised store of value. Games, NFTs, most tokens, all fail at this. And bitcoin cant scale due to its proof of work. While ethereum is limited by gas fees but that can be solved eventually with work from the developers. We have rising interest rates, so ofcourse everything will go down. Thats common sense not just crypto but stocks too, an example of why decentralised store of value is. When Afghanistan took back over the country, all the banks shut and people lost thete money, and money is just a tool used to exchange for value. If they stored there exchange for value on the blockchain it would of been immune to the banks closing. Kanye west had millions of dollars frozen on him in the bank, if he had his value on the blockchain, this would not have happen. The reason crypto is so volitile is because people try and do things that dont work and fail on the blockchain, when truly it should be seen as no more as a store of value. Crypto is extremely volitile and has been the whole time because people seem to think its made for other things, and buy into scams and nfts and failed ideas and false projects, people spread fear about it and dont understand what its actually supposed to be used for. A peer to peer exchange of value or storage of value. Yes at the beggining you said bitcoin sucks as a peer to peer network because of its slow speeds and electricity consumption. That is true. But there are other alternitives that are faster, can support more transactions, and dont consume anywhere near the ampunt of electricity. These systems are known as proof of stake. Proof of stake networks are the only viable thing in crypto that actually hold a purpose and a usecase. Ethereum, and bnb are 2 examples of a proof of stake network that can be used as a store of value, all this other shit is garbage and if you invested into it and lost your money, its because you didnt do your research, ADA is also another example, xrp is another example of proof of stake. author: SanziL Madye
comment:
When something doesn't have a intrinsic value it's a Ponzi scheme

Is Amway a Ponzi scheme, everyone believes so but it's still up are running, since at the end they still sell consumable products, may it be overpriced or through cult like marketing techniques but the product exists.

The thing with crypto is finding that value, and it all comes down to centralized vs decentralized architecture. Almost all and any technology can be implemented in both fashions, centralized is relatively cheaper and easy to maintain. So if you follow what ain't broke don't fix it approach. Web3 and all these other peer to peer use cases would never see day of light and crypto won't have any legit use case. But if trust of people in centralized things is damaged enough there would be reason to adopt decentralized architecture where crypto can play some role and thus creating a value and no longer being a Ponzi scheme. 

Will that ever happen is the question?

Blockchain is not a buzzword it is a very real software design/architecture but with a  very niche use case and even higher cost of implementation and adoption. 
Will any use case cross that barrier? I don't know.
And to run things on these Blockchain some kind of incentive will always be needed to keep the peers running. And that will be value of the coin, the real life electricity you burn to run the network.

author: Sprinter
comment: Personally I believe in crypto, I really do I dont believe its a giant scam rather that its riddled with scams and people trying to take advantage of others. Personally I believe that Bitcoin has too many technical problems to ever become a global currency, rather it will become an asset that you can back other things against, like gold. If that is sustainable, I dont know. But similar points could be made against traditional investments like Gold, and Bonds. But there are real use cases coming along, crypto currencies are helping people in Africa where they dont have large financial institutions or a stable currency to get paid in. So they use bitcoin which is peer-peer so its safe. They also dont have to worry about there Bitcoin being lost. Like in centralized banks, because while Bitcoins value could collapse, Fiat currency and centralized financial institutions also have similar risks. I mean whats backing the value of the dollar. But you have cryptos like Helium which you can use the coin to buy wireless network service from. So while bitcoin does have problems and so does every crypto, I think that traditional finance has even more problems. With NFTS I do believe there core technology also could be extremely useful as well. I completely agree that PNG's of horrible art is way overpriced I believe they give NFT's a bad rap, NFT's have use cases, like what if we could make documents like, diplomas, house deeds etc. On the blockchain, it would be impossible to forge a document and it would be completely secure and couldnt be destroyed in an accident like a real house deed or diploma. Also while Bitcoin uses a lot of power it also uses only about .5 percent of the worlds power. And I get it thats a lot, but there are a lot of different ways to cut power. The crypto space has also been trying to be more energy friendly as Ethereum switched to Proof of Work recently and cut power consumption by 99.5 Percent. But overall this was a good video and I do think it is good to call out problems you see and to make people aware but at the same time I wish you would have also talked about crypto currencies benefits and the short comings of traditional finance which also suffers from similar problems as crypto currency.

author: Artur Milczarz
comment: Your criticism of bitcoin, is very basic, and as it usually is with such - it shows you have no understanding what really Bitcoin is. For example the scalability issue, is not a bug, its a feature, it can process only so many transactions, so any person in the world can have all transaction from beginning on off the shelf computer. Its easy to have more scale, but then it would not be decentralized, as people in Africa cannot afford expensive databases to store millions of transactions. Scalability of bitcoin is solved on so called Layer 2 - Lightning Network, and similar projects. This is just one answer to your criticism, which are as I said very basic. You did a documentary about something you don't understand young man.

author: philthy941
comment: I'm only a few minutes into the Bitcoin section, and you've just repeated every point of outdated FUD I've heard for the past 5 years. I'll keep watching later, but a quick correction: Bitcoin's supply is fixed, but its issuance is disinflationary, not deflationary. Compared with fiat currency issuance which is highly inflationary (i.e. $USD purchasing power is guaranteed to drop over time because the supply increases ~10% per annum. Hence, you can't save in USD, only in USD denominated assets like housing which only increase in price over time, as the value of the currency against which it is measured decreases).

author: Simon Peck
comment:
James, you’re a juggernaut. This video is masterfully produced, well thought out and executed. I am coming away with a few questions.

At the highest level: is it fair to blame an underlying currency (or system of currencies) for the fraudulent acts committed with it? I think every type of scam outlined here has a cousin that has been committed with the US dollar, a perfect example being the eponymous Ponzi scheme. No doubt that many currencies were created specifically with the purpose of making their creators rich, but as you point out, the core motivation for creating new currency was the desire to remove power from established financial institutions and corrupt systems of government. Aren’t the motivations for this even stronger now than they were 15 years ago?

Maybe the decentralized nature and technical complexity makes crypto a ripe platform for scammers. NFT hype is one of the most destructive threats to the viability of crypto by creating confusion around the purpose of crypto and damaging its reputation. If someone saw crypto as a threat and wanted to restore faith in fiat currencies, the implementation of NFTs that we have seen was the perfect way to do that. 

Perhaps I’m still optimistic, but I think there is power in the concept of governance and great utility in smart contracts. One promise of crypto is the ability to enable a large group of people with different perspectives to quickly come to agreement on something and execute on it, all within an arrangement that doesn’t require trust.

Keep the content coming. I’m a fan of your channel.

author: Filip Projcheski
comment:
IMO, what will end up happening is the following:

You have more and more countries trying to roll out CBDCs (some smaller ones already have it). CBDCs are really similar to most of the Altcoins in existent, meaning centralized and controlled by the entities that hold the most of the supply. Some of the counties developing and even some in the EU (I believe it was Lithuania) already prefer to use Digital payments i.e. Credit Card payment, refusing to accepting cash. This brings the CBDCs idea even closer to fruition in the developed world. If I am not mistaken, Australia represented their idea of digital identity. That will not only include every information about you living in 0s and 1s, but it ties nicely with the whole CBDCs idea. Ripple is one of the first that has a platform where you can create, destroy and manage CBDCs.

You see in order to make the people accept new norm, you need an independent entities like the companies/organizations/communities behind the crypto. You let them invent, create, destroy and rebuild. You let them live, so you have a sandbox environment, that does not really affects you, but yet when they screw things up, you can hit them with regulations, bringing their value down (and with that their power) and having access to their tech and progress, so you can bring it closer to your end goal.

Now, what happens with everything that is already build on the web3. Well, some of the coins will stay as one of the first, having supply limit, might become some sort of commodities (which they already are ), maybe some of the will have some extra use cases, who knows. In terms of NFTs...I don't see anything else except of a cultural value, except the ones tied to a product (like and exchange, or some sort of software) so the NFTs you own represent a share in the product.

As a way to finish my rant, I would say that I am glad this era exists, true it is filled with scammers, but it also has strong communities of people that are interested in learning and creating new technology that might benefit us. And also, there are as much as nice stories, of people coming from nowhere that changed their lives for the better.

author: Ian Rooney
comment:
All i can say is of course there are going to be scams in everything if there is money to be made, you can scam people with anything, its a new technology, ever since NFTs got hyped up i knew most were ponzis being funded by incoming money and royalties with nothing to offer that would eventually dry up, it was always easy to spot them if you knew what you were doing, id say maybe 5% of the NFT projects will survive.

The big picture that youre missing is what they will be used as in the future, all of these profile picture collections were like test runs for real world applications, anyone buying an expensive jpeg has money to waste to test it out, people used it to scam people.

In the future and what will come of all of this and the underlying tech is tickets, titles, deeds, pictures, anything that could be owned digitally being an NFT that you store in a wallet on your phone rather then in a bunch of separate apps that you could lose your assets on. People wont even know that they are NFTs at that point, everyone will just have a wallet that stores certain digital items.

This whole run people got burned because its the wild west and a test phase of all of this, but all of the nonsense will fade and what will be left is the actual real world use cases.

Try to see the bigger picture, the title should also be "most NFTs are scams" because NFTs are just a sector of crypto.

author: k98killer
comment: The Bitcoin base layer has about half the transaction throughput of FedWire, with the caveat that it functions 24/7 rather than shutting off every week night and weekend. Lightning Network currently has transaction throughput approximately equal to a card network. Right now, there are more people transacting daily on the LN than on CBDCs. So the idea that Bitcoin is dead as a currency is divorced from reality.

author: Jeff Beats
comment: Blockchain is the advanced computing solution for an attainable enterprise internet system that is efficient and affordable. With blockchain, Maersk and IBM have been tracking shipping internationally for almost a decade. De Beers uses blockchain to track diamonds' progeny to reduce conflict diamonds on the market. Estonia uses blockchain for its e-business and e-residency. The fact most people do not comprehend how or why blockchain is more efficient does not make it untrue.

author: k98killer
comment: Very poor understanding of Bitcoin on display there early in the video. You don't compare a final settlement system like Bitcoin to a payment clearing system like Visa or MasterCard. The appropriate comparison is against FedWire. You wouldn't buy a coffee from Starbucks with FedWire, so neither would you do so with the Bitcoin base layer. Bitcoin, like FedWire, is a gross settlement network, and the proper use is to build payment clearing and net settlement layers on top of it.

Crypto is only different because it’s transparent and available for all to see.

author: Luis Augusto Fretes Cuevas
comment:
This video is like 80% right, 20% wrong. The problem with crypto/blockchains is not that they're not in principle able to deliver actual value by offering good services.

The problem is that the entire industry is consumed by a get rich quick mentality that devolves into token speculation immediately. It's easier for devs to make money by releasing tokens than by building actual products.

Even legitimate projects like Dydx, Uniswap, Maker, they all devolve into token mania. 

If crypto fails to create a meaningful number of useful applications and can't grow beyond token speculation and functioning as a ponzi facilitator, it will be because tokens ruined developer incentives.

author: TheVoidIsShining
comment:
I watched my husband get sucked into this via specific avenues and use all the cult terms - fud, diamond hands etc. I explained to him that those who get rich are the first who buy at the right time and sell at the right time and essentially run off with everyone else's investment, thst drives value down, and theres no way everyone gets rich. Its scammy. its inherently a scheme. He said "you dont understand" condescendingly over and over. 

*This almost ruined my marriage. It was an addiction. It was an obsession. He got out of all of that, thank god. But what it all did to his psychology was awful.* He acted like he was rich before he ever even made more than 500 bucks in a trade. Like a total ass. It was really bizarre and all he ever talked about literally. It drove me to a dark place. Him too, and he still doesnt see that!!!

author: Juliusz Kociński
comment:
There's one thing that REALLY hit me and it's not highlighted in a narrative.
The main, pretty much only advantage of Blockchain-based proof of work is that decentralisation. The ability to check for sure record of something, immune to unauthorised inputs, yet without central institution...

And you're telling me that main NFT record refer to entry in a database? Then why TF even bother with blockchain in the first place? This is centralised database, unauthorised by that proof of work. One day the owner could swap 10 of the most expensive ones into nudes of his/her ex. Why don't just put the ledger of transactions in that database?
That single thing pretty much destroys concept to me unless secure distributed storage of that database is provided

author: D Ro
comment:
James confused crypto currency with digital assets, of which there are many categories. 
He also confuses real tech value and innovation - a dozens of private blockchains that have replaced legacy systems - with scammy applications and ideas.  

He misses very relevant and key pieces of information:

- web 1, 2, and 3 are very real evolutions but web3 will take quite a while and not everything can or should be decentralised (see the Blockchain Dilemma), and much will be mixed eg, blockchain gaming where a game is centralised by assets are NFTs / tokens 
- there are Bitcoin scaling layers such as Lightning Network 
- BTC uses far less energy than the traditional banking sector
- yes energy is needed but it also guarantees a level of security never before seen!
- illicit use of BTC is very small (3%) and we all know the Trillions of dollars of fiat money used for illegal activity 
- if centralised exchanges have failed (and the point at which criminals get caught trying to cash their crypto!) then what does that say about centralised systems and governance??!!
- I suggest people do a simple Google search to see the dozens of companies allowing BTC transactions

I agree:
- that price volatility of BTC is a threat to adoption 
- relationships between projects and influencers is generally an absolute disgrace and I know exactly how these work
- security is a big problem but thats a symptom of innovation relying on insecure "web2" infrastructure as much as web3 infrastructure

author: Moggzzz
comment: Some fair points, but you didn’t touch on the royalties that nft creators get for each transaction nor the benefit to an owner of selling. I am all for the fact that most nft projects are scams, the majority being useless companies or pointless trashy art. However for memberships, Nfts provide an interesting approach. On launch of a club, the creators get paid for their time, effort and costs from the initial mint. If I join then join the club at a later stage, the creator receives a small cut of the transaction - a reward. If I want to leave the club, and the club’s value is perceived to be high by outsiders who want in, I can leave and sell my entry. I get rewarded. It’s a win win for me and the creator. As long as the club is doing all the right things, and it’s members are happy or need to free up cash, what is wrong with the creators and members being rewarded? Any other club you join currently, you pay monthly in fiat and it goes straight to the creator - you will never see any of that money again even if the value of the club is increased from a financial and social standpoint

author: 1995pearson
comment:
Amazing video. I personally believe crypto is divided into 2 groups. Bitcoin and everything else. Everything else is long term going to loose value and would be regarded as awful investments. 
Bitcoin on the other hand I do believe has a future. But it shouldn’t been seen as a get rich quick scheme, I see it more as an insurance for if fiat currency ever collapses. Just like gold etc. sounds unrealistic but I would say the probability is greater than 0%, maybe less than 10% in my lifetime. 
BTC has never changed since it began, and most likely it never will. In the technology we trust. 
Anyone thinking of putting all your money into it, good luck to you, I think that’s stupid. But say <5% of your worth as a hedge against the failure of fiat currency, I think that makes sense. 
It’s been an interesting journey

author: Miiike03
comment:
I find this video interesting, mostly accurate and I agree 99% of crypto space is a scam and pure greed. Great job on pointing out a16z 👍.
However the part about Bitcoin is *poorly researched* and I find it disappointing you only choose information that fits to *your narrative.*
At 14:50 you describe hope of buying something and selling it for more later as a Ponzi. By this logic buying a stock, gold, or a house and selling it for more would also have to be a Ponzi. There are no payouts from new Bitcoin owners to the previous ones as you wrongly show in the video.
Also the mainstream convinced you to believe "blockchain" is the revolutionary part about Bitcoin, but blockchain is simply a BS buzzword.
What is revolutionary is the combination of cryptography and mining to secure the network and the inability to print more money, which in these times of 20% inflation in some European countries I find weird you didn't even mention in this video.

author: Karl Svensson
comment: You are 95% right. Everything "crypto" like NFT, blockchain etc are ponzis and scams. Bitcoin on the other hand has a chance and the criticism presented of Bitcoin has been debunked so many times. We are in the adoption stage which means holding and not spending makes sense, although people that only has bitcoin as savings or bitcoin as income are active spenders. The very problem with fiat that Bitcoin solves is that the value is depreciating. The 7 TPS isn't really true either, it's more like 14 tps now and Layer2 networks like Lightning that people use for payments has thousands of TPS. Mining is not wasteful as it solves the decentralization problem and it will always move where energy is abundant.

author: Devin Konopa
comment: Bitcoin is great for what it is. It's not a Ponzi scheme. It's how currency works. Zero sum game. As the US and other countries continue to print money and over inflate currencies people will flock to safer stores of value. Real estate. Gold. The problem with real estate and gold is they kind of suck to trade with. Bitcoin solves this. It has similar properties to gold as a currency. Fixed supply, only so many can ever exist. But it can be sent anywhere in the world in 10 minutes. Without permission or need of any middle man or intermidiary dealing with the  transaction. It's going to pump up and down in the meantime as people speculate on it but it's not about getting rich. It's about having an alternative to this fiat federal reserve ponzi scheme everyone has been a part of since the 1980s.

author: AnthonydoesYT
comment:
List of hyperboles and omissions of fact(s): 
1. "Bitcoin is a 'Failed Revolution'" 
2. Bitcoin can only handle 7 TPS( transactions per second) - This is false, was true for a while but not after the release of Lightning Network
3. Bitcoin mining is insanely wasteful of energy - again, this is plain false. Bitcoin and crypto mining incentivizes green energy usage to keep mining costs as low as possible, and in the early days the hash rate was so low you could mine thousands of coins on a laptop. His whole statement here was plain false.
4. "Bitcoin survived despite all it's failings" - This is plain WRONG, again. You are even contradicting yourself here, first you say "no one is using Bitcoin EXCEPT for online criminals". The fact of the matter is Bitcoin was WILDLY successful upon release, it just was within a niche community as you said yourself of "tech anarchists", I remember the types that would be talking about Bitcoin were almost like the same people you would see at Devcons and Hackathons, in the early days. And even IF this LIE was true, criminals tend to be the first adopters of MANY new technologies. Anyone who is anyone knows that early days of drug-buying in the 80's and such drug dealers were infamous for using "Beepers", similar to modern day cellphones.
5. "Anybody that buys Bitcoin is only doing so because they want you to buy at a future date", this again is PLAIN FALSE, and AGAIN ignoring the VERY HUMBLE beginnings of this "libertarian anarchist" project. People buy Bitcoin because it CANNOT BE HACKED, and is ON AN IMMUTABLE LEDGER, MEANING IT CAN NEVER BE HACKED, STOLEN, CONTROLLED OR CONFISCATED. author: Daniel Moksmann
comment:
James, let me take a stab at it. There is one (relatively simple) use case for the blockchain I can think of: replacing notary public officers. Not replacing contracts, but having a public ledger not backed by any government entity... In which you can certify the validity of documents/statements referring to you or your activities. Countless countries to this day rely on official stamps, official signatures and government certifications to validate private documents. Instead of paying a government official to put a stamp on my property deed (a stamp which in many countries I have to pay quite a lot of money for) or my application for citizenship, wouldn't it be simpler and less dependent on real-world authorities if I could just show that the document has been validated in the blockchain?

My point is: if there is real utility for the blockchain, it is not to replace banks necessarily, but to replace costly, bureaucratic and inefficient notary public officers. We already have this nowadays with digital certificates, but those are provided to us by companies that validate our private keys - so it is far from a decentralized solution.

author: metaleggman18
comment: Yeah, it's really sad to see the blockchain, which is a fantastic bit of tech that still has a lot of potential, get turned into essentially that thing that makes crypto go brrr. While ether and bitcoin are probably about as "stable" as crypto might ever be, pretty much every other coin is either a subset of those two, or is a literal scam, like nfts, tokens, meme coins, etc. My friend works in crypto, and he's adament the only people legitimately making money on crypto are the people facilitating the trades. And this makes sense given that's how most of the traditional markets function, whether it's stocks, bonds, commodities, or forex. It's also part of the reason that most of the grift in these spaces, including crypto (except for the outright rugpulls and other scams), is to make money off of people wanting to make money, usually in the form of expensive training and seminars, where the grifters don't even make money off of the thing they're teaching you to get rich off of. No, they're just getting rich off of you.

author: Yes No
comment:
Something that most people don't see, (both enthusiasts and skeptics) is the clear middle ground. Crypto without value is a pyramid scheme, crypto with value is a tool. It is similar to the internet but not to the same scale, the internet has billions of uses and crypto currencies wont scale as much, but think how much the usefulness of the internet has grown since the beginning, crypto will be similar. Right know the main uses for crypto are for security, decentralization, and resistance to socio-economic change; but this list will expand in the future.
The real problem here is that everyone is acting like this is a get rich quick scheme, if crypto is treated like a get rich quick scheme and not the tool that it is, it will continue to be a pyramid scheme. This whole thing has already happened to websites, in the early days of the internet, it wasn't used much. As the internet grew and more people began to join, the idea to get rich became popular. Everyone began to create their own search engine (like how people create unique crypto) and buy up domains (like investing in crypto), this was a fruitless endeavor and only a few made it (Ex: Google for search engines, and Amazon for domains). Even so, those who made it became rich and were/are leading the internet for many years. The difference that separates the ones that succeeded from the ones that didn't is that the ones that succeeded were seeking to use the tool to create value, rather then get rich quick.

author: Jason Kalweit
comment: Im half way through your video, and i can agree with what you say and your point are valid, however much of what you say is invalid to your argument that it crypto isnt a currency. You must understand the difference between a currency and a security and in fact, the government is trying to combat the scams involved. There is nothing wrong with crypto or code or a ledger, but because the govt hasnt gotten their act together to provide clear regulation its allowed this idea to be used with malicious intent. I agree people should not purchase crypto without the understanding of the code or a trusted auditor doing a code audit. The tokenomics are pretty important in identifying a scam. But by your own description of a ponzi scheme, the house you live in would be considered a ponzi scheme. You hear all over the world that real estate is a great investment. Well, what is it? An investment? Or a place to live? If you purchased property you likely paid more then the person who built the house or last purchased the house. You lined someone elses pocket. Does that make it a scam? But whats ironic is the property you own, someone else has control over. Thats why bitcoin was created. To truly own your own property in a liquid form. Bitcoin itself is just a description of freedom written in code. My theory on where this video is coming from since being bullish on crypto to now claiming it is a scam is that somebody lost money in ftx and is jumping on the bash crypto bandwagon. But open your eyes to everything trusted crypto projects are doing. There is also something called an oracle which can validate for legal documents btw and people can be oracles and people can be part of smart contracts. Im not an expert at crypto by any means, but believe me i try to educate myself the best i can and id love to see you do the same. I appreciate the fud content in all honesty because people are entitled to share an educated opinion, even though i believe i may know some things you are ignorant to

author: opensaucerer
comment:
Maybe cryptography and Blockchain aren't bad inventions. Maybe we just happen to have bad actors that preach wrong motives. These technologies aren't meant to make anyone rich rather to help solve payment issues in areas that need them the most. I guess this proposition is what we find in stable coins. 

For example, I worked one time for a firm in Singapore and there wasn't any easy way to send my payment down to Nigeria. The only solution that guarantees that I receive my payment cheaper and on the same day was stable cryptocurrencies. 

I'm just sad that many have toyed on the ideas the original designers had and exploited people of their fortunes. But I believe that while cryptography and Blockchain technologies may have grown to have bad reputations now, in times to come, they will usher in a more positive change in everyday lives whereby they truly allow for trustless payments with bindings towards truly stable values.

author: Dan S
comment:
All these dorks spouting drivel like ‘duh money is just made up too lol bro’.

Not it’s not.
Trade is a real thing.
People trade either a good or a service and it becomes a liability to the purchaser.

The liability is then paid for by money, because barter is not scalable.

This is double-entry accounting.

A piece of money is not supposed to be valuable in itself because that would simply result in hoarding (which is why we don’t use gold anymore).

Ideas like ‘money is worthless’ means ‘trade is worthless’.


Stop believing nonsense assertions by idiot boys who think accounting is just for nerds.

author: Doug Jacobson
comment: During the move up and the two peaks, I scoured the internet for actual use cases and came up short.  I wanted to believe in the tech but kept telling my friends (who were all long crypto at the tops) that I hadn't seen a good use case and was not investing.   The closest thing to a use case I found was an upwork using this tech -  but I soon found out they still used credit cards and had the same Stripe fees that any other normal marketplace would have...so in essence the same ***ing thing!     I still do believe an actual use case will happen, but it will be something that most don't talk about.  Bitcoin proved a decentralized system can work in theory.  The next step is removing the proof of work aspect of it, and doing real-world testing in more advanced things like fixed income etc.  will take years and tons of changes to get right!

Invest only in bitcoin as it does have future. It won't be currency if fiture, it is a digital gold/scarve commodity. Please do more research.

author: Keith Moore
comment:
Very well done when covering crypto hype and scams, but I'm still holding on to the idea that Bitcoin itself is still in the early phases of a potentially amazing revolution. Government manipulation of currencies (inflation) is ripping the world apart at an accelerated pace and a secure, decentralized digital currency like BTC might be the bridge to a better financial system...especially when no entity can start creating more of it.

The Internet in its early days had extremely limited use until companies built layers on top of it improving access to the masses--Amazon, Google, etc. Solutions such as the Lightning Network on top of Bitcoin suggest similar acceleration.

author: Cody
comment:
Incredible work James. I work full time in the industry, so my views are a bit biased, but overall you did a fine job touching on all the hyped and insane parts of the industry. 

One point I'll make is that many new technologies begin as a solution looking for a problem. The 40 years of cryptography leading to its first successful distributed network, Bitcoin, is quite the breakthrough. Unfortunately people iterate the tech to make ridiculous things like BAYC.

The discovery of electricity didn't immediately iterate light bulbs. The network developed in the 80s by the military didn't immediately iterate to the internet we know today.

Both of these innovations needed time to grow into its potential -- "a solution looking for a problem, or something to improve" at the time, as some might say. If there's one thing that history suggests, it's that you do *not* bet against technologists.

author: Kirsten
comment:
Glad to see such hard work be posted after all (I recall the post you made about the youtube copyright acting up). So many people know that NFTs are bad, but not the how and why, so this is great to have on hand.

I know this may sound demanding/presumptuous, so please don't take this the wrong way. But the whole "rebranding the scam/shitty thing to try to make it take off again" ... yup, it's happened again with "AI" "art." It's the same money-chasing, passionless people that have hopped onto this utterly soulless "get rich quick" bandwagon - they even use the same obnoxious, gaslighting and victim-blaming arguments! As an artist it is especially infuriating and insulting (these feel like understatements, honestly. I've gone on about it enough. I'm so tired of trying to get through to these blockheads.). They even claim bullshit like "it's helping disabled artists" when it's actually hurting them. 
What I'm saying is, I hope that your next/future video is about how awful and unethical and anti-humanist "AI" "art" (the name is intentionally misleading) is. I suppose you could say this is a request? "Suggestion" would be a better way to put it. It is truly awful. If you are interested, I could let you know of some of the things I have witnessed. Either way, I will continue to follow and appreciate your work!

This technology  is far from a scam, bad actors and scams are in everything new 100%. A lot of crypto is trash but so were a lot of companies that went public in the dot com boom and bust.  Look back the media itself blasted the internet as a scam, a fad that would soon be irrelevant but here we are. Penny stocks on Wall Street, majority a huge scam. I am honest I’m a little bias because i have made some money with crypto but when i see something that can solve real problems (blockchain technology) i can’t deny it. Your video even pointed out some of those problem just on your prospective of it. It may be too early to invest in this technology but look at the people who invested in Microsoft or Amazon at launch. Regulation needs to come soon to keep everyone in line and let this space grow. This is just the beginning. I know no one asked but i just thought i would share my opinion. Kick ass video man keep it up.
