author: Stetbro
comment: To answer your final question, the answer is never, the crypto bubble will never pop. Lets say your a wealthy celebrity worth $50 million. You invest 5% of your portfolio/net worth into crypto. You now own $2.5 million in crypto/nfts/whatever. It's in your interest to hype it because it climbs in value when you and others do. Even when the currency takes a big hit if it loses 90% of its value, you still have $250k tied up in it. What do you care if it goes to zero? Its only ever a small portion of your overall investments. And next week it will be worth $500k, or a million. Volatility shakes off the little guys that are hanging on. When you realize that you're just a remora suckling at the trash that comes off these celebrity sharks, life becomes a lot more palatable. Its easier to not live in their dystopian delusions and skip the crypto, and rather, accept that you don't need to be rich to be happy. Learn to disconnect from the FOMO and it will simplify your life. The government wont step in to fix this because it has no incentive to, nor the jurisdiction unless they want to put laws on the books about it. Here we are 13 years after the inception of bitcoin and I'm unaware of any laws in the US regarding crypto scamming.

author: Mai Fantasia
comment:
I do not understand this cryptocurrency.  Several questions.

If I have 10 cryptocoins, how do those cryptocoins accrue interest?  After a year, if I don't buy any additional cryptocoins and I don't sell any, do I still only have 10 cryptocoins?

At a set point in time, one credit (dollar, pound, peso, whatever currency you wish to insert) is the equivalent of one cryptocoin.  I have a company that produces widgets.  As the credits and the cryptocoins have the same value, I sell my widgets for 10 credits or 10 cryptocoins.  Tomorrow, when compared to credits, one cryptocoin is now worth 100 credits.  Do I still sell my widgets at the price of 10 credits or 10 cryptocoins?

From my very limited understanding, these cryptocoins only appear to have any value when compared against a fiat currency.  Many that are pro-cryptocurrencies continually predict the downfall of fiat currencies.  Yet, those that claim to be getting rich  can only quantify the value of their cryptocurrency against a fiat currency.  If fiat currencies have zero value, would that not also hold true for the value of cryptocurrencies?

For example your account holds some NFT character and can be used in multiple games and your private data will be safe from selling it to other companies and your crafted or hard earned items could be sold directly on the marketplace earning you some cash.

I don't think that the technology is a scam as a whole but there are a lot of scammers who are exploiting this new born technology....

Only time will show the results of these speculations.

author: Richard Fenton
comment: Bitcoin and Blockchain Technology are definitely a scam. Just like the Internet was a scam. To quote Paul Krugman, "The internet's impact on the economy will be no greater than the fax machine." Sorry, but that didn't age well. And this video will not age well, either. All new technologies have their share of scams, and blockchain is no different. But to say that blockchain technology is a scam is to say the stock market is a scam because some stocks are scams, or that all hedge funds are scams because Bernie Madoff's was a scam. Attack the scamsters, James, not the technology. Blockchain technology - Bitcoin, in particular - is revolutionary, and it will change the world. Hell, it's changed the world already. PayPal, Visa, Starbucks, Blackrock, Fidelity Investments, and hundreds of other large corporations are embracing it. Why? Because it's scam? No. The world is going digital, and Bitcoin and blockchain technology are leading the way. As I said, James, I LOVE your work, and watch everything you produce. I am especially looking forward to your "I was wrong" video in 2030.

author: Saxonian
comment: You don't know what a 'Non Fungible Token' really is do you? Or the wider use case for NFT technology? Sure, there have been plenty of NFT scams (using them at their most basic level, i.e., 'art'), but imagine having your ID as an NFT so an oppressive government can't confiscate it. Imagine having your health or education records as an NFT so when you flee a country because of civil unrest, all of your key information can't be destroyed or lost. Last year I transferred funds to friends in Ukraine through crypto because you'd be surprised to know they couldn't just pop down to their local bank! You've researched 0.01% of the facts and then clickbaited it into this parody of investigation. This is like tabloid journalism masquerading as something more informed. Seriously, don't tackle subjects you don't even have a rudimentary grasp of.

author: CryptoWizard -
comment:
Richard Heart (Hex & Pulse Chain) agrees w ur trashing of NFTs. He says if you can sell this shite, good on you. But never buy any. The art/pic is not even on block chain, its linked via an online content host (I forget who).
I also agree w you that BTC has failed. However I will quote RH again "Crypto has proven that free money IS possible".
Its obv that crypto as a concept is here to stay. However I expect the extensive evolution of implementation of an online currency. Crypto & BTC as the initial implementation of an online currency may well be superceded eventually.
Crypto will prob react to the inevitable introduction of CBDC (big brother Central Bank online currency), being the OPPOSITE thesis of crypto. Cryptos reaction will most likely pendulum swing to the opposite of big brother, meaning privacy.
BTC is the beginning, not the end-game.

There are scams that pretend to have something to do with crypto, educated people do not touch them (FTX). 

There are scams in tradfi markets, educated people do not have a choice in whether or not they touch them. 

This video is going to be even more cringey in 3 years. Go do some research instead of this shallow crap.

author: Artur Gaio Pinto
comment:
People making videos about bitcoin and they don’t even know how it works or how the financial system works. Super sad. I’m a Computer Scientist and Satoshi solved one of the greatest computer science problems that were unsolved. He doesn’t even know that VISA and all the others takes several months to settle and relies on trusting a 3rd party to be willing to give you your money (see canadas truck drivers protest, where government froze their money). Bitcoin reaches final settlement within 10 min on average, with no trust in 3rd parties. I could go on, but it’s clearly done by someone who doesn’t understand financial tech nor even Bitcoin itself…
 Bitcoin not crypto. 
NFTs, crypto, etc those are all scams, 100%. 
Bitcoin is still the only human invention where the people has more power than the richest - read the Blocksize wars for context.

edit: Oh lord. Have a great day everyone, stay hydrated and remember:  The Rich are our enemies, not our neighbors, doctors, engineers or fellow salarymen.

author: Rn Kn
comment: On a practical level crypto just works better for banking and finance, but like any market a net inflow increases value, and a net outflow decreases value. And in that sense, I would accept all of the criticisms and the praise targeted at crypto, with one caveat. That is, on a fundamental level, crypto is not different from the wider capitalist economy. Crypto is a ponzi, just like national economies and global finance. Except the economy, through the financial sector is insanely over leveraged, drowning in unpayable debt, and extracts untold sums of wealth from society by positioning itself at the focal point between savings and investment. And most importantly, it is entirely unsustainable, without constant growth it will trigger a collapse. Finance is the only industry that has not been disrupted since the advent of digitization - and this relentless campaign to delegitimize that process is not surprising. There is a lot of money and power at risk. But when the legacy financial system finally fails the crypto architecture will be unencumbered, and able to provide an effective replacement.

I even created my Coinbase account in 2013 when those first became available. I was also early in the most recent bull run as I happened to start working in a fairly popular crypto exchange in 2019. With all that said, I agree with everything said in this video and am now firmly anti-crypto and want to see its total collapse within my lifetime.

author: K Cb
comment: A lot of it is smoke and mirrors, 90% of crypto, NFTs and other projects are useless and are built on hype or a cash grab or both. but acting like there’s no use case already is a bit much. Take Bitcoin for example, the fact that you can send 2 billion dollars from one btc wallet to another and pay $20 in fees while if you send $200 through western union you’re paying the same amount? Also without a third party. And sending USD through banks they take what sometimes 3-5 business days btc is sent and recieved in a few minutes to a couple of hours or less. If people don’t see the value in things like this obviously it won’t go anywhere, and crypto in general will probably die, but there’s already a use case, and crypto companies are becoming better at building technology off their own blockchain. Imagine if Fortnite created a token that gave players tokens for doing certain messages, there would be people that play the game for the money of course but It also incentivises players that are already good at the game that they can actually make money for doing something they love

author: Travis Travels
comment: OK I agree with the majority of the takes in this video, except for his opinions surrounding bitcoin itself. Implying that it has no chance of ever becoming a widely used currency is jumping the gun. You can very literally see on the Blockchain that adoption is actively increasing along with nation states legalizing it. And as far as speed, his comments are just disingenuous. Bitcoin serves as the base layer, meanwhile, layering solutions will help it scale just like our current financial system. On top of that, it’s pretty much the only truly decentralized “cryptocurrency” on the market. It’s why a lot of people don’t like it when bitcoin is grouped in with the rest of the garbage out there. And finally, it’s use case isn’t just to be a currency… it’s also a store of value. He basically describes the greater fool theory in this video when talking about Bitcoin and doesn’t realize he also just described the gold.

author: Matthew Shiers
comment:
_"At what point does the ticking time bomb go off?"_

Perhaps it already has. The former co-founder of FTX, Sam Bankman-Fried was arrested on fraud charges filed against him by the US Securities and Exchange Commission two weeks ago. My own understanding is that this guy's company bailed out and bought up a lot of failing crypto projects, taking on a lot of bad debt. Sam Bankman-Fried then misused funds from FTX customers to basically cut and run, cashing out and fleeing to the Bahamas.

But this wasn't isolated to the world of crypto. FTX was tied up with a lot of traditional finance, as a result of bringing all those smaller exchanges into a single, very precarious basket. And you know what they say about putting all of your eggs in one basket...

Maybe Bankman thought that customer faith in crypto (and by necessary extension, FTX) would be restored if it was all brought together, who knows? But clearly, faith was not restored and everyone wanted to get their money back. And without enough potential new marks to palm off FTX tokens to, there was no way to do pay out all the existing marks. And there are a LOT of existing marks!

Maybe crypto currency _did_ destabilize established traditional, centralized expressions of wealth. Just not in the way that the founder of Bitcoin initially said it would. Because we haven't seen a switch from FIATT currency to mass adoption of crypto here. Just a lot of people's hard-earned money siphoned off to a few extremely lucky individuals and very rich scoundrels using extremely convoluted methods that not enough people truly understood.

author: Ty Gorton
comment: It is clear that world governments are quickly moving toward CBDCs. The name of the game is.... voluntary adoption. How do you get people to embrace a CBDC? I think crypto has a role to play. Initially, Bitcoin and crypto served one purpose: to convince people that purely digital assets have real-world value. What I see happening is this: when CBDCs are officially launched, crypto holders will be offered a VERY generous amount of CBDC in exchange for their crypto holdings. It's the cheese in the trap. Crypto holders will be handsomely rewarded for their faith in the digital currency space and governments will be rewarded with millions of instant adopters of their new, shiny CBDC. Nice and tidy.

author: pepelapiu2004
comment:
Your hit piece is full of misinformation.
For example you claim that people would not want to spend their bitcoin because they all believe it's value will increase over time. Therefore, if people don't want to use it to buy something, it can't be money. But that is completely ignoring how money works. I suggest you look into the Gretchen's law which explains that bad money chases out good money. Simply put, people will spent first the currency they don't want, and save the currency they do want.  If someone he gave you two $10 coins, one made of 100% gold, and the other made of scrap metal, and they kept telling you they are both worth $10. You would likely spend away the scrap metal coin and save the pure good coin. Because indeed the good coin is better money than the scrap metal coin. 

People choose to save their Bitcoin because it's better money than fiat. It holds it's value over time better than fiat which loses value over time.

author: volimsir
comment:
Hey great video as usual, even though I disagree about the bleak outlook.
The main reason is, because there are good use cases for crypto right now. Like sending coins from one wallet to another is way easier, and faster, then doing an international bank transfer. Or using NFTs as digital receipts, as you said. Even for your internet example at the end - there were a lot of skeptics13 years after it's conception, that didn't understand why you couldn't just read the paper, or watch the news on the TV, or pick up a telephone to call your doctor.
This is why it's called investing - you're investing in the potential you see this technology achieving at some point.

However, I do agree that there are rampant problems at the moment with scams, shitcoins, and people wanting to get rich quick. But I do believe that the underlying tech has a lot of potential, and will become a big part of the future.

author: Johnathan Henning
comment:
Blockchain technology still seems extremely wasteful and unsafe, but even if there was a Web 3.0 using a digital currency, it seems like it would go the way of the internet protocols where only one - not thousands - became the standard - and it doesn't seem like any digital currency could be worth much more than a dollar for all that to work efficiently in any kind of new internet iteration.

The "tokenization" of everything just sounds like something from a dystopian sci-fi story. This is more kleptocurrency promoting some kind of future techno-kleptocracy.

On the other hand, the recent catastrophes of digital currencies seem to be rapidly reconstituting the disasters during the development of our current economic system, like the Wlidcat Banking era in the 1800's and earlier crashes like Tulipmania, the Mississippi Bubble and of course the original Ponzi pyramid scheme of the 1920's. In that sense, maybe crypto/klepto is the future, but it is still a nightmare.

author: Kuky
comment:
You are completely wrong in claiming that Bitcoin doesn't scale and even more so that its very creator made it that way.

Satoshi has literally said that Bitcoin can scale at greater than Visa capacity already, all the way in early days, with then existing hardware and internet network capacity, so it is an absolue lie to claim that he has said Bitcoin can't scale or that it was designed with some flaw. These are all inaccurate narratives created by BTC developers who took control over the BTC code base and changed the protocol in order to cripple the system and prevent it from scaling, that is what actually happened. BTC is not even the actual Bitcoin at all, it is a fork creaked in 2017 by BTC Core developers.

Every single thing I wrote here is 100% independently verifyable, not from someone else, but from the mouth of Satoshi himself, the Bitcoin white paper and how BTC blockchain works in comparison.

author: Vadim Kozlov
comment: As much as this obviously took you a lot of effort, I think it's important to state that you are very biased which clearly impacted your research. The topic is much more complicated than how you present it and your oversimplification and biased approach to your research makes it so that you portray bitcoin and crypto as a whole to be fundamentally flawed. Global adoption takes time and the tech is still in it's infancy, the problem with people speculating on the value is their own fault and not by design. At the end of the day it is flawed and there is a lot of progress to be made in order to cross the chasm of global adoption. However, it's still infinitely less of a scam than all of the fiat currencies. I appreciate your effort and your video but you shouldn't be making documentaries on things you don't understand on a deep level.

author: LethalBubbles
comment:
This video made me realize that the crypto bubble is essentially a repeat of the Savings and Loans crisis in the 80s (ironically a major contributor in the Enron scandal and 2008 economic crisis as well, which was the catalyst for the creation of bitcoin in the first place)
But yeah, in the 80s, Ronald Regan deregulated banks and telecommunications so banks were able to lend out risk-free loans and televangelists were able to collect money on TV in those famous scams.

The pyramids essentially funneled from the working class and new homeowners to bankers and politicians. Exactly what we're seeing happen to the people losing out these scams in the form of FTX, and the other financial middle-man, as made necessary by Bitcoin's blocksize Achilles heel. Individuals are getting lured into this no-mans land where venture capital can dominate unquestioned. This time it seems more targeted at the middle class as it drains fortunes from people who benefited mobility-wise from the last tech bubble.

author: Amoroso Gombe
comment: As a graduate level economist, supported by, only the head of the IMF, I've been trying to tell people from the start that cryptocurrency doesn't meet any of the definitions of good money in formal economics but so many people don't want to listen, they just want to make a quick buck. Widely accepted. Portable. Fungible. Store of value. Standard of deferred payments. Test cryptocurrency against any of these criteria. It fails. Can I buy a loose ciggy at the local kiosk with bitcoin? What is the price of $45 Adidas vs $42.50 Nikes compared in bitcoin? Can you imagine paying a mortgage in bitcoin with its volatility? Or reprinting restaurant menus every hour? And what about all the compliance kyc and aml issues? You can't just wish all these things away! Cryptocurrency is nonsensical.

You make NFT looks like they are just images, and that's not what an NFT is. God how long did you talk about NFTs and not even try to differentiate from images? author: Always Here
comment: We live in a world that is truly evil. I've been researching population, and I can tell you with increasing certainty that it's not just a loss in the United States, there is a loss worldwide, we're evil! What can we do? More of us are consciously evil than not. Less are stupid, so unaware, god so unaware. What their parents parents thought was mania, conspiracy not to be pushed to children, even now, their children suppress the idea that something could be on the whole wrong, and that somebody must do something. What are we? We, who for loss of a better word, grovel over memories of so many experiences we could've had. So many memories YouTube has given us. But for what. What now, while they delete our old gods words and works online and wrought poison pedophilia and filth throughout the hallways of our dreams? What do we do now? I see the real world, and I see so many around me, into the real world, although they know not why they feel sad and how the "real world" is diminishing. Can you see it? The real world diminishing. More and more the even furthest reaches of the nature, abstraction, I know not what to do in my youth, and only as I realize the very memories I myself shed genuine tears for aren't mine. None of it's real. "Which brings us to the apes."

Web 3.0 - decentralized) for you to profit from ‘your’ data if you so choose

author: lgrs5
comment:
Im a software engineer based in Vietnam. I develop mobile apps, REST api's, database driven apps, all that full-stack good stuff. I create solutions that solve real problems, for businesses. Its all very practical and the utility speaks for itself. 

Early in 2022, Chinese New Year, i met my wifes Auntie, she was enthusiastically telling me all about her son who is in "blockchain, crypto and nft". Her eyes lit up as she spoke about it because he was "on the cutting edge". Naturally I was skeptical and warned her that there wasnt much longetivity in the space, and i advised her to try and steer him away from it. She was deeply offended by what i had to say.

Later that day her son came to meet me. I told him he should focus on more conventional programming such as app dev, website dev, etc. It was like speaking to a brick wall, he just wasnt interested, he had been sucked into the mania. Since then he has been laid off from the New York based agency he worked for (they went bankrupt) abd he is struggling to find a similar job. Ill be meeting him again for the chinese New Year, it will be quite difficult to avoid saying the words "i told you so". Poor kid drank the koolaid and wasted a year, he really should have took my advice.

author: THE SAXGOD
comment: The cool thing about smart contracts is it eliminates the legalize that confuses non lawyer types. So when you’re coding the contract everyone or the parties involved will know exactly what is agreed upon.  Everyone will know the loopholes and everything else. You won’t have a contract thrown in front of you that’s pages and pages long trying to hide outs for the one producing said contract. That’s the point. Lawyers hate it because you’re making it easier to understand what you’re agreeing to or signing up for. Now there are some cases in court now but you’re right that they haven’t been agreed to but with the US govt passing a law in the early 2000s making a digital signature equal to a physical signature smart contracts can spin from this as well.

author: Yankee Stacking
comment:
EXCELLENT VIDEO!  Bitcoin disciples have the right intentions, but have been deceived by the latest version of a Ponzi scheme.  “There’s a sucker born every minute,” and this mother-of-all, get-rich-quick cult is no different regardless of the “power to the people” hype.

Central banksters and power-obsessed governments will regulated private crypto into oblivion all in the name of “safety” and “protection” of the masses.  No one will care about Bitcoin by the end of this decade when thousands of dollars worth of stimulus is directly injected into people’s non-blockchain digital wallets. The populace will sadly accept CBDCs as quickly as they give up their privacy to Tik Tok.

author: Crypto World
comment:
This was a well edited video, but it's a shame you brushed over Bitcoin so quickly and associated it with NFT's as if they're the same thing (when they are completely different).

Bitcoin is already being used as a legitimate currency, especially considering the fact it's legal tender in 2 countries now. It's also the most censorship-resistant currency in the world, and is the first form of currency that cannot be confiscated (when stored in self-custody). Bitcoin also allows people to transact where the banking system isn't - such as friends & family sending money between Ukraine and Russia (since Russia has now been cut off from the SWIFT banking system). Bitcoin is already a valuable technology from the start.

author: VinceSamios

There's some really fundamental misunderstandings in this video, like "limited to 7 transactions per second" (actually unlimited) to conflating the people who pump the value of bitcoin with the actual utility of the technology. It's not perfect, and there's endless truly valueless pump and dump coins, but one must understand the fundamentals of the technology to understand why we are experiencing a surge in mining energy consumption and why this isn't a problem in the future, and why there have been mad fluctuations in price, and why actual use as a currency is low. 

This is just echo chamber hype imho. And I don't care about the price of bitcoin.

author: Dragos Stefanescu
comment:
Maaan ... I love your content, it's so spot on. Even this video does an amazing job at calling out the specific grifting happening in crypto. I do feel super dissapointed though, mostly because of the framing of the video. I agree that crypto has had a lot of bad stuff happen (in this general frenzy that we've had because of money printing), mostly because it is unregulated still (which I hope gets a balanced solution soon). 

But it seems dishonest when you don't also research the great stuff happening in crypto - there is  a reason so many brilliant minds are still hard at work to improve this technology. I am aware that most people from the outside don't have a view on the inner workings of the Ethereum community, but I highly encourage you take a closer look. The scalability while keeping decentralization is fully under way and probably solved within the next few years. True use-cases ALREADY exist - crypto is much better at remittances than any other banking system (just use regulated stablecoins), micropayments will probably be a reality soon (once scalability kicks in), decentralized finance gives you more transparency and use-cases than the traditional financial system and the NFT tech ... well, I truly believe in NFT infrastructure, but it will need more time to be properly built and incorporated (in games for example). 

Most of all this marks the current sentiment and hate towards crypto (which probably means the bottom is super close or already here). It will take a few years, but it's likely this video does not age well (in terms of bundling the technology with the grifting - I totally agree the grifting in this space is appaling and needs to be fixed).

author: V R
comment:
This may help at least one person, but the idea of getting rich quick has mainly been magnified by the uncontrollable desire to flex on social media. 

Social media validation and attention can also lead to the disease of addiction, and the main difference between the much of the past and our modern first world is our increased unmoderated access to instant gratification and our greater sense of self-importance only rivaled by Caligula. We are also dismissing as "toxic" many of the external stressors that spark evolutionary development and the high pressures that turn you into a diamond. 

If you want to start finding clarity in this clearly chaotic world, practice more gratitude and more self-sacrifice. Much of the anxiety and depression should dissipate since you're not really meant to be overstimulated this much.

author: Mental Traps
comment:
Another awesome documentary, mr Jani. It was a pleasure to watch it!
But allow me to criticize you a bit. 
As far as I know, Bitcoin is one of the official currencies in Central African Republic and El Salvador. Madeira also considers making Bitcoin its official currency. And the transaction speed for Bitcoin, thanks to Lightening network, is now much faster than any of the payment systems you mentioned (Visa, Paypal, etc.) Also the energy consumption of Bitcoin mining seems to be bloated out of proportions.
I don't have any Bitcoin myself, I'm just learning about it. And maybe I am mistaken. I may very well not see something that you see so clearly. But I think you didn't do justice to Bitcoin.
As for NFT's and all other cryptocurrencies, I'm pretty much on the same page. The financial incentives are doing their dirty job to people's minds.
Thank you for your work!

author: Quix Omega
comment: I was into Bitcoin about 10 years ago, when it was a fun technology experiment. Since the dumb money (in this case bankers and get rich quick scammers) started piling in I got sick of it. Since then Bitcoin has proven positively unsuitable for it's original purpose (and people keep trying to rewrite this so they don't look stupid). That purpose was as a decentralized payment system, and high fees, ridiculous energy costs, slow transaction speeds and low supply make that wildly impractical. I still think the technology has some interesting uses, but Bitcoin itself is more of a prototype Blockchain than a real store of value.

author: hollowedboi
comment:
This is where it felt and still feels awkward as a digital artist to get people who see your work and say/said, “hey have you thought about making NFTs?” And now “is that AI art?” Or “that could be fed into our systems” or shit like that.

Like without regulation and how discourse was online and in the real world from some of my experiences, I had to stay skeptical and look into all sides of the story to not get scammed or waste time where someone may take advantage.

Anything that’s a get rich quick thing usually ain’t it. Usually being smart with time and where your efforts go towards is where it’s at. Easy money is enticing but for a scam this wide scale to be mainstream, we gotta be wary and scrutinize and call out everything.

author: Darkfireice
comment:
The funny thing about crypto; it's just private money, which casinos (and video games, but that's basically the same thing), companies, localities, and even Disney have employed (and failed).

And they all failed for more or less the same reason; with no State backing, manipulation is both easy, and usually legal (and so typically unpunishable, or at not enough to act as effective deterrent.)

It's only amount of time for someone to counterfeit any crypto, and the whole thing dies (unless States subsume them.)

author: Thomas Walma
comment: This video is definitely cherry-picking the negative aspects of crypto, for example, the low amount of transactions per second of bitcoin, without mentioning the improved transactions per second of other cryptos.  And it spends like 40 minutes talking about NFTs, and only like 5 or 10 minutes talking about people trying to put useful stuff on the blockchain, mostly just by showing a handful of cherry-picked, unquestioned quotes where a guy says something like "if you think x should be on the blockchain, you don't understand x". I agree with your assertion that crypto came first and then people are later trying to come up with use cases to justify it. But I don't think that means it's a scam. You could say the same thing about the Internet or the Apple Watch or any technical "platform".  The video also says that "if crypto is so useful, why haven't useful crypto applications been implemented yet". My response is that it's much easier on a technical level to put a link to an image on the blockchain than to engineer a working micropayment system or supply chain tracking system on the blockchain. So it makes sense that these simplistic, scammy/fad things like NFT images would be invented first. I don't know if crypto will ever be useful. But this video didn't convince me that it won't

author: Daniel
comment:
You shouldn't conflate Bitcoin with scam cryptos. SEC is pretty clear about how these new cryptos are nothing like Bitcoin and why they need to be regulated. Bitcoin is not trying to replace VISA cards for buying a coffee, and sticking to that story today is just silly. Bitcoin is a truly decentralized investment and it's not hard to see why many people find it attractive as a long-term alternative to gold, land or real estate.

In regards to the energy consumption, you can't make any judgment on however it's wasteful or not. No one can and that's a good thing. Taking such a stance would lead to cancelling 49 % out of all energy-focused activities because the majority didn't approve of said activities. It's not just Bitcoin that uses a lot of energy. Better to focus on making more of it.

author: Nick Louw
comment:
I really don't see anything new or informative here - NFT promo schemes are nothing new, other than the name, art has always been a questionable and dark industry not used for what one would typically think. 

With all due respect, as I do value your content and professionalism, this is a very one sided video highlighting none of the positive impacts this space is having. The video's main highlight are the flaws in humans, our greed and how certain people are happy to take advantage of others via whatever channels that are available to them. Nothing new - this has been happening since the dawn of time.

Historic money cycles, developments, ''revolutions'' and mania periods echo with what's happening (and has been happening) in Crypto. 

Who knows were it will go, but if you fell into the NFT trap,  a "VC's or Influencers new coin", phony ICO's, or FTX type exchanges,  and are looking to get into crypto as a get rich scheme, you're very likely to fall into any other scam out there - for one reason greed. 

Its a fact, people are going to use crypto, blockchain for bad purposes - the same way people have used and still use other avenues for fraudulent purposes - like the internet, the telephone and even the postal services. 

All the people commenting in the thread here, if you did not know this before or only learnt something for the first time here - stay away from the crypto space unless you are willing to do a lot of your own research.  There are bad actors, who will take advantage, very similar to the rest of the world outside of crypto/blockchain.

BTC having a limited supply and being deflationary is a fact, but its one piece in a much bigger picture than you have covered - was it supposed to be a revolution? who knows or even cares but its very uninformed to compare it in anyway to a Ponzi scheme or Bernie Madoff, which is sensationalism in my view.

Other blockchain projects (which have great promise) aren't also trying to impress anyone with how quickly they can get the project out or to "prove" something until the proof of concept is ready and generally these technologies require the buy in of a lot of stakeholders and there is a massive education process which needs to happen, and will delay things.

VC's/Gov's coming in with projects via this channel with nefarious motives are at least doing it in a space where it is slightly more transparent to the public. Remember before, the rich/entitled were still doing this but there was literally no transparency. 

Smart contracts not being able to be enforced by a judge because of the myriad of subjective circumstances is very valid. But remember that system is also filled with biases, stereotypes which have caused massive, irreparable damage to society. I don't think the idea behind smart contracts was to jump into these complex issues anyway .

The biggest issue we face in the world today I believe is trust/reliability of source etc. which maybe a simple decentralized "spreadsheet" as you mentioned could help resolve this issue. 

Don't believe any hype, don't invest money in a new unregulated space you can't afford to loose (as you most likely will), do your own research and/or leave it and move on with life.


.

author: Me h
